properties.description:
Professional and makeshift yard signs (not permanently affixed;;indicative of a locally viable business market)observed recently include: lost pet with $ reward; silent dog fences; mosquito control; storm inspection repair including terms "hail, roof, siding";yard sale; private home alarms;collegiate banners of local and distant schools; day camps; private youth schools; for sale; voting related; and road closed detour. Birds seen and heard in the peri dawn hours today include: geese, dove, crows/blackbirds, songbirds, woodpecker, hawks. The recent rainstorm resulted in redistribution of curbside matter including pine straw, drink containers and leaves. Some grates were 80 to 95% obstructed with 6 inch high accumulations of fresh pine straw. Two typical pine straw samples measured 6 to 7.5 inches long, terminal dark colored hub measured 0.5 inches long. The straw appeared crayola "burnt sienna", "tan", "tumbleweed", "desert sand" colored and did not have a strong odor of decomposition or decay. Crickets chirping at slightly different tempos and pitches were abundant this morning. // There were no signs of wind damage or flooding, but there were some curbside piles of tree limbs and branches cut, broken, or sawed from weekend yard work. Yesterday I observed 5 to 10 yards using sprinklers prior to 5 AM. This morning, on a different route, there were two yards using sprinklers after 6 AM. edit 8:30 PM water quality..the faucet mounted water filter was changed today pursuant to the color coded change indicator after approximately 100 gallons filtered. Using color coded qualitative test strips for swimming pools, water was sampled and tested from the old filter, the new filter and another unfiltered faucet. The dry, new filter weighed 5 ounces, the old filter weighed 8.7 ounces (wet). Weight of old used filter will be repeated after >48 hours drying time to estimate particulate removed from tap water. Results of tests in order 1) used filter 2) new filter and 3) unfiltered residential water 8/28/2016 evening. HARDNESS: very low, very low & very low CHLORINE: ideal, low, & ideal to high. FREE CHLORINE: low, low & low. pH: 7.0 +/- 0.2, >8.4 & 7.0 +/-0.2. ALKALINITY: very low to low, low to OK, & low to OK. comments: the filter is meant to improve drinking water in far more ways than this simple qualitative test. This test does demonstrate that there are significant differences between residential tap water from a new filter, an old filter, and unfiltered outlets, most notable in the pH and chlorine categories. These simple results do not attempt to argue a better or worse water supply or quality, but demonstrate arguably different water supply and quality on different days/times with and without new and used filters.

weekly report. The soil remains wet, too wet to plant. Moderately wet. ( not squishy )
High temperatures and wind did a lot to dry things out.
AGRICULTURE: it has been commented that the soils are too wet for the farmers to work.
BUSINESS/INDUSTRY: no impact
ENERGY: a/c units were used at least once or twice over the past week as temperatures rose to the 80's.  However, generally no heating or a/c was necessary most of the week - so energy usage should be low for most.
FIRE: no burn permits as the ground is wet - however, winter-dead grass could present a fire threat - until we receive more rain - which is expected within hours and throughout this next week. Fire threat is low.
PLANTS: BLOOMING: dandelion, henbit, dead nettle, plum trees, hollies forming buds, camellias blooming, snow ball viburnum, popcorn spirea, daffodils,  maples done as are leather-leaf mahonnia, redbuds and sweet gum are forming buds and leaves.
LAWN GRASSES are starting to grow (centipede is just starting to get green ) - plenty of weeds such as sand spurs, clovers - which are starting to flower.
POLLEN FORECAST IS AT HIGH LEVELS NOW AND INTO THE NEXT WEEK - TREES ( Birch and Cedars)
WILDLIFE: Birds are plentiful ( cardinals, house finch, wrens, kill-deer, doves, mockingbirds, buzzards, crows, hawks.  Have not yet seen blue jays, blue birds, martins or swallows, canary (golden)finch. 
RELIEF: N/A / SOCIETY & PUBLIC HEALTH: generally it has been sunny and very warm - so folks are outside working and seem happier.  Many have had serious upper respiratory issues throughout January and February, but that seems to be abating now that we are in March.
TOURISM & RECREATION: no impact, other than positive.
WATER SUPPLY & QUALITY: river levels remain high - with minor localized flooding in "the usual places"

properties.description:
TWO WEEK report: Rainfall for the past two weeks was only 1.14 inches. One event saw .83 so in reality, the rainfall has been light - too light.  We could use some precipitation locally.  With the storms of this past week, only 8 miles away saw more than an inch, with some wind damages reported.
AGRICULUTRE: Soy looks good, dark green foliage.
PLANTS:  Crepe Myrtles are just about done, with an odd bloom here or there.  The Natchez variety is still holding leaves, while the Muskogee is starting to drop their leaves. Tulip Poplar leaves continue to brown and drop.  Pollen count over the past week was up in the 6.8 range; with ragweed and grasses being the main sources.
Our Bees continue to lay brood, and have plenty of both pollen and nectar.  
BIRDS:  Barn Swallows are now totally gone; Hummer are feeding frantically ( 2 gallons every 6 days ); Finches still present ( canary and common ); Blue Grosbeeks; Blue Jays; Crows; Doves; Quail; Cardinals; MockingBirds;   Dragon flies are starting to be less - although still here.
Butterflies are present.
Vitex is reblooming as are roses, abillia.  The camellias that bloom in November / December are forming buds.
The ditches are damp in appearance, but haven't any standing water.  We estimate the water 'table' to be down about 3 feet in reality. Spiders are more prevalent now ( fall is always a 'big time' for them  )
NO public activity was impacted by weather events over the past two weeks to my knowledge. Water Levels in the rivers remains constant ( we have been out sailing multiple times on these rivers recently ).
Mornings are cool in the upper 60's but the days warm to just over 90.  Swimming Pool water temperature is dropping due to those cold nights and NNE winds generally above 10 kts.
River Birch Leaves are definitely turning; oak appear to be 'ready to go' - just not quite yet.
New growth showing on evergreens such as hollies, eleagnus, cedars and pines.

The humidity from all these rains that have never stopped since spring starting way back and now the high heat, has outside workers either, they can not work cause of the rain or they are getting sick with the heat. I have talked to many construction people who have been unable to work by both. My husband works as an HVAC Technician, elderly people with old AC units are having them break right and left. These folks are in there 60-90s and can not take the heat either. I don't know if AC has helped us over the years as our bodies are not accustom to lack of cooling, coupled with people do not know how to stay hydrated. This is amazing for me, I grew up in the very very south end of Texas. We would get 115 close to the Gulf Coast and humidity would be out of this world. As an Epidemiologist and Public Health nurse I find this amazing. I researched some articals to try and find the name and recipe for the World Health Organization - Oral Rehydration Salts, that you put in water and it helps with hyrdation. Well, no one up to Bethesda at the National Instatutes of Health or the corrisponding agency working out of Baylor University in Houston Tx had never heard of the stuff. I found it, One packet makes 1 liter of water for rehydration in third world countries. I have been usuing pediolyte with my husband as he has had heat stroke once already last year on a tar roof fixing a commercial airconditioner. But someone needs to recommend this stuff to the public with in the US. I don't work anymore or I would (Retired Medicare Consultant here.) But the American Red Cross just says stay hydrated. But you drink too much water your electrolytes become thinned out and you have hyponatremia. This is serious! This out door healthy workers need to stay healthy, I found out in Houston/Glaviston area due to flood this year, they have roofers colapsing on roofs from heat exhaustion. The rehydration salts will work! We use it for diarrehial diseases, vomiting and other things like Cholera as oral rehydration is better then IV. The gut can take more fluid. But I am not a nutritionist, nor am I high enough in public office to effectively get this message out. But I was shocked the Military is not using this stuff in the Middle East and we are not using it in the US, but Africa anywhere knows about it. This stuff is sold in the US on line for 50 packet s only cost 34.99 but you can go on line with a gram scale and make this stuff from supplies at any health food store. YOU CAN NOT USE SPORTS DRINKS THEY HAVE TOO MUCH SUGAR/GLUCOSE which makes dehydration worse. Just staying. Crops and everything is suffering the effects, but these lighting strikes too, in this rural area is pulling down phones, power lines and taking out trees. I don't know what to say. Just reporting.

properties.description:
TWO WEEK REPORT > The first week was hot ( upper 90's ); windy, and dry ( well, humid, but no rain).  Rain came on a Friday in the area, but at this specific locale - not a drop. So VEGETATION, mostly annuals, were very much in a state of stress at the end of that week.  Some loss of plants occurred ( squash, annual flowers etc.); AGRICULTURE: soy beans that were planted at "just the right time" are flourishing - but any that were planted late remained small and were hurt by that first week of heat.  The second week we saw rain well spaced out that benefitted plant growth.  **  I have to note here that lately, forecasting has been really inaccurate - timing of rain(storms or otherwise ) as well as anticipated precipitation has not been as predicted.**  
Vegetables in OUR garden that are producing now are: tomatoes; green beans; cukes; cantaloupes.  Worth noting that peppers are beginning to flower again in the second week - the first week was just too hot, small peppers just wilted and fell off the plants. 
CLOVER is all but disappeared at this point / crepe myrtles and mimosa are blooming.  Soy locally is not flowering as of yet.  Honeybees are still bringing in nectar, but pollen levels are decreasing at this point.// Lawn and field grass needs continuous mowing to keep under control ( we always try to stay ahead of this, so that if a tropical storm comes we are ready  for it // Barn swallows are amazingly on their third batch of babies.  We are pleased to see an increase in the blue jay population - adults are visiting feeders and taking it back to their squeaking brood / hummers population is up now, and so are their visits to the feeders ( they had all but stopped visiting feeders for about 2-3 weeks ); the first week had birds looking for water - the second week not so much. First week roadside ditches were very dry - now they are not holding water, but the soil is wet // Local area rivers are seeing algae and vegetative growth floating around, especially in the shallower areas.// WILDLIFE:  SNAKES - yep, we have been seeing quite a lot of them; mostly roadside or in open fields and a lot of those have been rattle snakes. // BEARS - one local community is having some issues with young bears which has been making a lot of local press - we have not seen any evidence of them - but as beekeepers - we have an battery operated electric fence around our apiary - as we are adjoining commercial timber land // Lots of RABBITS - which means plenty of fox too ( saw one last week )// Wild turkey are walking around with their nearly adult offspring //  Mosquitos in fields and woods are high this year - we have barn swallows near our house so that is a benefit if you can deal with the poop.//
Gladiolas are blooming/ abellia just starting to bloom / vitex is done / swamp sunflowers and "Mexican" petunias just starting to bloom / mums are forcing a few early blooms which is typical for this area.//
We JUST returned from a trip to the western portion of NC and we could see the difference in precip. effects - much dryer west than down east.// LOCAL EVENTS: none seem to be effected by weather events at this time - although last month the BIG ROCK had some issues with wind offshore // 
Right now - the best way to describe conditions is MOIST - HUMID - HOT - DAMP - feels "mildew or musty" - nearly tropical.

properties.description:
TV news today local broadcast "not under drought conditions" now. View of municipal water supplier web page shows no activation of drought plan conditions now. So these observations considered "normal". ::Numerous short mushrooms sprouted along stream side edge of recreational athletic field within 72 hours of mowing. Abundant four winged flying insects (look like dragonflies) are seen in flight and perched. Deep purple pokeweed (Phytolacca?)berries are seen along woods edge. Several "mimosa" appearing flowering trees are seen in purple bloom near creek crossings. Occasional freckle sized grey/black circular mold colonies appear on the underside of the residential commode seat surfaces within 48 hours of cleaning.  :: Using a digital multi meter with positive and negative probes submerged in water less than 3 inches apart, the DC voltage measured in standing water within the outside water meter to access shut off valve for this residence was ~4 volts compared to a similar volume of water in a plastic container indoors 0 DC volts. Resistance was also markedly different. (for emergency water shutoff planning and response). Measurements have been repeated with slightly different voltage, but detectable voltage at the shutoff valve both days in the ever present stagnant water. edit: At 1520 Morrisville Parkway community park behind the maintenance building on the creek bank I saw what appears to be a Mimosa tee (Albizia sp) in bloom with feathery purple/white semi spherical flowers. This may or may not be an invasive species. I also saw three rabbits in the park, one of which was juvenile. In  another neighborhood I saw a large shrub growing inside a curbside storm grate with more than 9 long branches protruding from inside the grate above road level 15 to 20 inches long with healthy green leaves.

properties.description:
During a 2-hour outdoor morning walk today near Grace Park near Alemany Drive I sneezed more than 5 times in two hours and developed light sniffles outdoors (the dog sneezed some also). Both of my feet are currently breaking out in red rashes after commuting last week in the morning/afternoon rains without a change of dry socks. The stagnant water color at Grace Park near Alemany Drive appeared olive green with some redder brick colored tints near shallower sandbars. The was wind creating small pond surface ripples. The wind direction of the small puffy mid-level clouds was markedly different than the apparent water surface wind direction. After allowing the portable thermometers 15 minutes to acclimate, the ground measured 76 in the shade, and topsoil below the surface was 66 at 10:15 AM. I did not have appropriate protective gear to take water measurements today. 
Plants and animals directly observed today in the absence of drought include, but are not limited to: 5 Canada geese in the water, a black vulture in flight, more than 30 amphibious turtles leaving shore for water or already partially submerged with  their heads near the surface, 5 to 10 large tadpole looking fish swimming near the shore, pickerelweeds on the eastern shore are not showing purple flowers yet, one flying red bird, one or two terns, a heron in flight, a few small swifts or swallows darting quickly above water, and a few dragonflies.

I also saw a stagnant trail side puddle measuring about 3 feet long by 1-foot-wide and three inches deep. A multicolored surface algae bloom was showing bright yellow/green-granny smith apple green algae covering more than half of the water surface area this morning. (color references from the closest match to a Crayola 64 pack of crayons.

properties.description:
NOAA all hazards radio broadcasts an "increased fire danger" message and refers listeners to their webpage for impacts and further details. On most if not every day, municipal fire suppressing vehicles are seen operating on the roads in emergent (lights/sirens)and routine(no lights/sirens)situations. On a few days in the last year, I have smelled distinct odors of cooking food on grills and burning wood. Rarely I have seen outdoor burning of trash piles in rural areas in the last year. I have seen three recurring campfire sights in wooded areas in the last year. On many days, I can also see privately owned "damage restoration" vehicles on the road and parked at residences that advertise repair and restoration of water, smoke, flood, mold, wildlife etc. property damages. These businesses also advertise in the yellow pages. (edit added) The creek water just outside the park boundary was flowing slowly today. Surface debris was moving about 6 feet downstream in 20 seconds. I submerged a paper coffee filter supported by a kitchen strainer for 120 seconds. Although no debris was visible with the naked eye, many (more than 15 less than 30) small dark particles were visible with the aid of a handheld magnifying glass. The particle size could not be measured with the tape measure because of the small size. The surface water temperature at this time was 52 degrees.Topsoil on the creek bank was 48 degrees in the shade. The light colored sandy smooth slopes of the creek bottom were visible several inches below the water surface on the left bank, but the bottom was not visible on the right bank at this location. Many gnat-sized flying insects were observed in flight above the water surface. I observed one wild adult rabbit and one adult stray cat in the park this morning.

properties.description:
Brief ditch survey: this morning, water in the service road ditch leading to the community park was flowing rapidly and 6 inches deep at this location where the ditch was 16 inches wide. During April, this area was observed to range from dry and flow less, to trickling,  to overflowing and gushing. The bottom was visible in the shade and overcast conditions. Water surface temperature was 64 degrees at this spot. Plant life on the ditch bank included mature flowering 3 leaf clovers, tall (>4 feet tall)wildflowers with slim white petals of ~1 inch length encircling a round yellow middle, dark green moss on the banks with stems measuring 1/2 inch long, and some mature trees. I removed one large stone from underwater that was partially buried in the grey/brown dark sandy bottom. The rock measured 12 inches long, 5 inches wide and 4 inches thick. There were no signs on invertebrate life or other life (algae, moss, etc) on the rock. The colors were mostly greys with relatively clear and straight lines of color demarcation. One area of dark green was on the rock but it was not slippery to the touch or otherwise representative of viable plant life at that time. In the park and the park parking lot corners, there were several areas of standing water measuring 1 to 3 inches deep. I recently observed a gallon of regular gasoline advertised at $2.19 9/10 per gallon. There was very light rain/mist at the time of of ditch observations. {{edit same afternoon 5/3/16}}: A cluster of 7 berry trees was observed by the ditch near this site. The eye level circumferences of the more than 6 tree trunks measured from 14 inches to 25 inches. Bright red and black or purple/blue berries were observed on the tree from eye level up toward the treetop more than 30 feet high. The berries appear like the common blackberry seen in markets in the produce section. Using a blind over shoulder toss of a metallic ring with 8 inch diameter, I counted berries within the area of the circle where it fell. Toss #1) 7 berries. Toss #2) 11 berries. Toss #3) 10 berries and toss #4) one berry fragment. The berries measured 1/2 to 1 inch long. Some were partially decomposed, but all were moist (lack of drought conditions). As a control, I walked across the street toward magnetic north and tossed the ring four times over the shoulder and did not encircle any berries. Other plant matter on the ground included sweet gum balls and pine cones. The aforementioned airborne white filamentous snowflake appearing floating plant matter was observed drifting with the gentle breeze at his site.

properties.description:
weekly report:  HOT temperatures have been the impact of this past week.  With "in the shade temps" near 100 degrees every day, the heat index warnings just kept being issued - and appear that this will trend over the next week as well. //  PRECIP. for OUR direct area fell short of even one inch ( .70 ) for the week.  With hit-or-miss afternoon showers, nearby areas received either considerably more or less //
Drying is becoming a concern with the combined westerly winds generally between 6 -12 mph.//
Watering of vegetables and ornamentals is necc. due more to the wind, than the lack of precip. // Roadside drainage ditches have lost any standing water ( in this immediate area) //
AGRICULTURE:  Soy bean seedlings benefitted from rain, but now are facing extreme heat with little precip.  Struggling would be my observation.  // Insects and bugs are becoming evident, especially near anything that was artificially watered.//MOSQUITOS are worse this year - at this time - than they have been in past years.//  Honey bees ( we are keepers ) are doing all right; continue to have current brood / have plenty of nectar on their colonies - but are slow to turn it into honey / cap it off.//
Honey crop is still expected - but now about on month later than normal - effected by a loss of forage in late March ad early April due to late freezes.//
Outdoor Public activities continue with good attendance - especially if they were planned for early morning or evening events.  //  
ELECTRICITY : usage is no doubt high - surges and outages are occurring randomly. // Swimming Pool water temperatures are no longer refreshing - over 90 degrees //  WILDLIFE:  Another rabid ( raccoon ) animal within the county this week.// Hummers re slowing on the feeders - heat AND he trumpet honeysuckle is blooming.// Other birds feeding at feeders - but generally in the early am or late evenings //
Our Tap Water is not "cold" any longer - in fact, I intend to take a reading this week just out of curiosity. // River levels are  ( again driven by wind ) generally a bit on the low side it seems( we are boaters )

properties.description:
Two week report //  precip. was 3.62 inches //  This report begins with the last day of TS/TD ANA being here.  There was some flooding upriver on narrower rivers, streams, and creeks.  Rivers crested ( in those areas ) from 1 to 2 feet above flood stage // a small amount of area was effected - however - housing was effected with damages and health concerns .  The waters receded very quickly. //
The temperatures have been mostly mild, being cool in the 50's at night ( which helps ). Winds have been moderately high, which has a drying effect. // We are watering vegetable and ornamental plants at this time /./  Rainfall is quickly absorbed or drained off - no puddles or standing water remains //
AGRICULTURE:  The local farmers were scrambling to prep and plant fields in between forecasted rain events.  They are all planting soy this year.  I spoke with one who told me that it had been their intention to plant some corn, but the wet and cold spring delayed them to the point that corn was no longer viable for them this year //  
PLANTS: Red Clover has been mowed in // White Clover is diminishing now - if cut it does not reappear //  TiTi ( or persimmon ) is blooming and the honeybees are foraging on that heavily // Magnolias are blooming.
BIRDS: The barn swallows have hatched their first set for this year // The Hummingbird population had a literal "overnight" dramatic increase in population  - it seems it has to be more than just hatchlings //  We have seen one pair of Yellow FlyCatchers //  The Blue Birds are feeding young // All birds are attracted to water provided in bird baths or ant traps // 
GARDEN VEGETABLES:  DONE: Strawberries, Peas, Asparagus.  COMING: Blueberries are ripening ./ Tomatoes and Peppers have small fruit / Cucumbers and Lopes are vining ./ Squash is flowering ..//
With Memorial Day, there have been many outdoor events.  Weather has been Sunny, and dry. // As a boater, I noticed that there have been more folks boating on the rivers over the past week then previously.

properties.description:
Road crews were out yesterday in the back areas of Chesapeake as such. Ran across at the junction of Indian Creek Road where Baum Rd runs into it, the inside corner (sharp 90 degree 20mph curve) has a swamp running up next to it. The area got compacted  down into the swamp area and the water was undermining this patch of road. The asphalt was going to crumble This imbankment is poorly designed as there is not any larger boulders and mesh to reinforce it going into a swamp/marsh. I don't know who deep the march/swamp is but it is vast. The shoulder is not even 6-8 inches so it is imperative they maintain this curve to prevent crumbling and rebuilding, accidents and potential loss of life. Farm combines, buses and semis have to get up and down certain back road. As I said my son is a building foundation/asphault/soil labratory tech/concreate civil enginer... and now the project manager for his company that is charged with building the new NASA Station. I consulted him on some of these issues a couple of days ago... He stated their is a fundamental error in how these roads are being made cause they should not have all the failing of pot holes and sliding. NE-NC would do good to consult some civil engineers from the mountains areas of the Smokes in this state... and VA would do good to do the same. Just my thought for a prevention strategy start. There are things they need to have those engineers reevaluate. (This eastern area of NC and VA has a Univ that teaches engineering, and it could be a project for the students to help with. The University is in Virginia Beach that boarders this state line area of Eastern NC and VA.

Other then that, things looking good. People continuing to clean up the winter here but farmers on my drive are tilling their fields, a couple did it a couple weeks ago and crops are coming up.

HVAC and mechanical companies are scurrying all over to repair heat pumps and other kinds of HVAC systems that are needing good repair from this harsh winter.

Dogwood blooms and stuff are starting to fall... Cherry blossoms are in bloom, still have yellow pollen covering cars and buildings. People dealing with allergies are bad. 

Beginning to see some Humble Bubble Honey Bees, Butterfly's and small dragon flies... Pollinators... saw a toad, but no frogs yet for to which this area is known for.

properties.description:
UGH !  What a Week !   We got hit on Monday night with several hours overnight of freezing rain. This caused SO much tree damage that it was equal to the damage caused by Hurricane Irene some years ago.
Especially the evergreen trees suffered. EVERYTHING was encrusted in a layer of ice that was just about 1/2 inch thick.  The branches broke, falling onto other branches that were barely capable of holding their own weight. 
That was ( is ) our property.  The area full of pine tree farms suffered too.  Electricity was knocked out.  We were out for about 12 hours ( thank goodness for a generator and enough propane to run it ). The electricity was restored overnight on Tuesday, and was out again on Wednesday, probably while more lasting repairs were made.  Not all in the area were out - just us few "lucky" ones. ( ha )
Ice on the grass was like little knife blades - dog did NOT want to go out.  Driveways were worse than roadways as the day progressed.  Friends came to get water so that they could provide water to their kenneled hunting dogs - theirs had frozen solid.
And so the week was... temperatures just making "melt the ice a bit" so that it could refreeze in sheets.
NOT a fun week.  
Schools on delays - and closings; businesses closed.
BUT.. then, we did not have what the Northeast had; nor did we HAVE to travel anywhere during these periods - so we were much more fortunate than many were last week
We did feed our honeybees - although they seem not to have been feeding on our offerings - having been bringing in pollen ( and nectar?) and using up their honey stores.
They DO get out when those temps are above 50 and anything ( like dandelions ) are blooming.

properties.description:
Winter precipitation Tuesday though mid-day Thursday with total accumulation of 5.5 inches (1.75" melted equivalent).  Frozen ice layer from a night long sleet event made it difficult for ground feeding birds to find food, but several species were noted at the backyard feeder: Roufous-sided Towee, Cardinal, Goldfinches, Carolina chickadee, Black-capped chickadee, Carolina wren, House sparrow, Mockingbird, Titmouse, and even an Eastern bluebird.  They seem to be favoring seed over suet.  Some garden perennials had remaining green foliage before the snow, though edges were singed by the sub-freezing temperatures last month: Dianthus, Daylilies (evergreen varieties), Coreopsis, Sweet William, and Snapdragon.  First shoots of daffodils are about 4" tall.  Rabbit-eye blueberries are full of buds; they seem a bit too swollen for this early in the year.  Roads have been nearly impassable due to ice/snow cover since Wednesday. Residents in our area have been asked to stay off them until mid-day today.  Many local businesses have been closed since Wednesday including our local gas station, pet store, dry cleaner, veterinarian, and my husband's manufacturing facility.  He left early this morning in a 4WD truck to pick up and transport enough employees to run a half shift, and will repeat the process tonight to bring in another crew.  Most people in our area do not own vehicles capable of navigating snow and ice packed roads.  Though temperature has climbed to the 50s today, the forecast calls for refreezing each night through the weekend, so it could be Monday before business is back to normal.  Schools dismissed early Tuesday afternoon and have been out of session Wednesday through today (Friday).

Hopefully, we will get some relief later this week from the tropical depression going into the Gulf of Mexico.

properties.description:
This morning between 4 and 7 AM, I observed 4 juvenile frogs on the sidewalk, two large nearly dead or dead insects that make clicking sounds. The winged bugs measured 1.5 inches anterior to posterior thoracic segment with wings extending an additional 0.5 inch for a total lentgh of 2 inches. The undersides were mostly bright white. There were narrow green streaks bilaterally where the wings attach to the thoracic segments. I saw one bat circling a streetlamp near the creek. I saw and heard three hawks on the ground and in flight. I saw two separate areas, > 1 mile apart, where 3 or more modern streetlamps were not on and coincidentally or causative also had very wet sidewalks, obstructed curbside storm drain grates, and automated water lawn sprinklers. These issues affect the supply/demand/maintenance/repair of all who utilize or pay for utility services ($). I saw more than 10 people walking/jogging/cycling in the morning darkness, although some may have been the same people making rounds around the block, it is difficult to discern in the dark. (recreational sidewalk usage during day and night is the point) . The creek water appears quite stagnant this morning with a dull film or sheen that was previously noted and continues to increase in size due to lack of recent creek flow to wash or rinse the organic sheen of unknown origin (leaf decay/spill/decomposing deceased animal/seepage from underground/other), downstream.edited 8/28/2016 afternoon:: today this sheen and film is completely washed away, apparently by the thunderstorms of last night. The water is shallow, clear and slowly flowing. Less than 20 small minnows (<2 inches long, multi colored) were observed treading water without making headway up or downstream. A large rectangular piece of trash resembling a cooler box top (~2 to 4 square feet area) is washed up on a sandbar.   PLANTS: although much of the foliage remains green, a particular type of tree in a residential yard was observed today to have freshly fallen, brown, dry, crispy, brittle leaves. The tree circumference measures 28 inches and 29 inches at eye level. One larger ground level trunk splits into the two smaller trunks. The tree is approximately as tall as the one story residence rooftop apex is high. A representative leaf measured 3 inches long, was teardrop shaped, 2.5 inches wide at the widest and had a stem one inch long. Best crayola color match was "tan" on one side and "tumbleweed" on the obverse side. (many are smaller, a few are larger). I tossed a ring of 8 inch inner diameter (a stove top burner ring) six times from over/behind my shoulder while near the trunk and counted the dry leaves within the ring. RESULTS: 17 leaves;77 leaves;24 leaves;26 leaves;16 leaves and 19 leaves. The tree bark is a paper thin type and partially peeled from the tree trunk. Even in the few minutes I was counting leaves the gentle breeze caused a few leaves to fall in sight during the count at around 10 AM.

properties.categories: Plants And Wildlife,Water Supply And Quality
properties.description:
This morning I observed an adult great blue heron wading in the shallow, slowly moving, almost stagnant creek waters from an automobile bridge on Davis Drive.  The closest ditch is dry today. The closest creek is dry today. This week I saw two wild animals that were longer than cats, shorter legged than dogs, with pointed triangular ears, and long bushy tails, travelling one in front of the other three hours before sunrise.  The animals made loud, short duration, unusual sounds (not a bark or a howl, more like short hisses or grunts) at me and my dog as they travelled through the parking lot into the nearby woods. Coloration of the mammals was not discernable under the distance and light conditions. I saw ~ 8 adult mallards and <8 mallard ducklings in the water in Grace Park. I have seen a few slugs and moist slug trails on residential door structures in the morning. One slug measured ~ 2 inches long and had two antennae that varied in length with retractions and extensions as the animal slowly moved vertically upon the building structure.  I saw two herons in flight at low altitude (below streetlight level) yesterday evening.  When commuting on bike in rural areas before sunrise, I see pairs of eyes along field and wood edges on a daily basis with the aid of small battery powered handheld lights. Some are deer, others are assumed to be stray cats or other animals that have not shown outward aggression towards me. Occasionally a domestic dog will bark from their land as the bike approaches.  I continue to hear mourning dove calling and woodpeckers pecking but have not seen as many geese in recent weeks. I saw a small flock of pigeons on apartment rooftops today and still see an occasional tern near the intersection of Davis Drive and Morrisville-Carpenter Road.

AVERAGE: We had only about 1/3 inch of rain this past week; temperatures have been high; it has been windy.  So the past weeks of wetness have abated.  
LAWN MOWING has stepped up pace; with most having to mow more than every 7 days.
AGRICULTURE:  soy beans continue to look weak; small height tobacco plants are flowering; corn is about 5 feet tall and tassling
BUSINESS:  N/A//
ENERGY :  A/C units are used, but not over taxed - only one day in the past seven was extremely hot ( near record setting for the date)//
FIRE: Levels appear to be low - although the winds are high//
PLANTS:  LOCALLY crepe myrtles and Mimosa are just starting to bloom / magnolias are blooming / vegetable plants are just now starting to seriously produce - with tomatoes having a two day setback due to high temperatures// WILDLIFE: turkeys are about done with their broods - seen less and less foraging / all birds are hatching their first clutches / RELIEF: NA // SOCIETY : they say a pollen alert is effective -but it is not noticeable // TOURISM: no impact
** other than gale force winds impacted the Marlin Fishing Tournament due to extreme wave conditions ***
Water Supply - river levels are all right - wind driven -
** an early fish kill signals that oxygen levels are too low on both the upper and lower layers of the 'big' river here ( there are many rivers here ) - an annual event -yet everyone is always looking to blame someone - for run-off/pesticides/city sewage treatments etc. .. yet .. it happens EVERY YEAR - it is just a little early this year - by a couple months actually

properties.description:
WEEKLY REPORT: 1.6 inches of precipitation over the past 7 days; that followed 2 inches we had rec'd just the day prior to this week.  The ground remained too wet to work, or mow.
Grasses are growing - everyone is having difficulty keeping things mowed, and weeds under control.
During the past week, the nights have been pleasant in the 60° range, not now - it has warmed up to the point that night time temps are in the mid to upper 70's.  Today is possibly a record-setting high near 100°.
Breezy most days - so drying is happening quickly. 
Our deep ditches ( roadside and property ) were up to the tops - which means about 4 feet - now there is hardly a trickle in the deepest areas, and the others are dried back out.
AGRICULTURE:  Corn looks good, and some are beginning to tassel.  / late planted soy is looking weakly.
BUSINESS: N/A
ENERGY: Air Conditioners are running
PLANTS: Red Clover is non-existent, white clover is beginning to die down ( heat ); BloomingL gladiolas, spirea, queen anne's lace and sambucca ( elderberry); magnolias; the persimmon trees are done; our crepe myrtles are just forming flowers - not blooming yet - they are blooming 8 miles away in town; our mimosas are not blooming yet - and again are blooming in town; 
WILD TURKEYS had their babies - small clutches this year.   They had been foraging on white clover.
We have a "new to us " woodpecker eating at the seed feeder.
The Barn Swallows have all had their first hatch.  Hummingbird population increased too.  All the 'usual' suspects are around the feeders.
RELIEF: NA / SOCIETY and PUBLIC HEALTH:  we see there is a high pollen alert.
TOURISM: nothing effected - good traveling weather ( the beginning of the week had a tropical depression that barely effected us here - about 50 miles inland from the Atlantic Ocean ); WATER SUPPLY: seems fine here.  River Levels will be impacted - but had plenty of water from prior two weeks of rain
FIRE LEVEL:  Wind will be a concern - but it has been wet - that could change this week.

properties.description:
While walking on some of the local side streets, one can see numerous pest (mosquito) control yard-signs advertising for several different small businesses who treat yards for mosquitoes and other pests. Water supply and quality: this morning at a nearby creek side the water quality was a little unusual in terms of "viscosity" or "solute density" or "thickness" of the flowing creek water. The surface temperature measured 64 degrees. Bottom substrate was visible several inches below the surface bilaterally on creek banks. When instruments were submerged for measurements  (thermometer/filter) the surrounding water formed coin sized circular eddies slowly spinning off the instruments (sometimes distinct "V" shaped wakes form, trailing several inches downstream of  the objects). After submerging the coffee filter/kitchen strainer for 2 minutes, some standing water remained in the bowl shaped filter and drained more slowly than usual. (sometimes it is empty when brought out of the water). I scraped a small amount of bottom substrate from a few inches below the surface. The material, at this particular location, was slippery between the fingers, grey colored, clay like, with some small red rusty colored streaks. With the aid of a digital camera and laptop computer, I was able to enlarge photos of the small particles captured in the 2 minute immersion of the coffee filter. The irregular shaped particles are large enough to count the rectangular pixels on the laptop screen when enlarged, but too small to measure with the available tools. Several small mosquitoes were observed at this creek site just above the water surface. The sky was overcast and a few very light misty raindrops fell during the hour.

properties.description:
weekly : in eight days, we have had accumulation of 1.19 inches of rain.  Considering how wet the ground was at the beginning of the period, one would have thought this would pose super wet or flooding situations.  However, over the past week both the temperatures and the wind velocities have been high, so there was considerable drying.
AGRICULTURE:  the local farmers have disked and applied fertilizer in preparation for planting.// It has been a "chamber of commerce" type of week mostly, so with the local tourism in the area, I feel confident it was a good week for business.//ENERGY:  Low usage of heating or air conditioning systems was the norm.  POWER OUTAGE: early SUNDAY morning, power surge, followed some 6-7 hours later by a power outage that lasted only about 40 minutes.
FIRE: With the wet ground, one would think the fire threat is low, but actually there have been some forest fires regionally due to high wind and dried out dead over-winter grasses; No Relief Response.  PUBLIC HEALTH - POLLEN. Water Supply - normal
PLANTS:  some daffodils are still blooming - hycaniths all done ./ Camellias blooming - just about done ./ Pears are blooming - Plums are about done./ Red Maples are leafed out - long past bloom time.  Dandelions, dead nettle, Carolina jessamine, white clover, ( some red clover starting to bloom), trees are leafing out ( oak, birch,maples, cherries).  Hollies are blooming en masse. ( bees are happy with the forage opportunities at the moment )
Still too cool to plant vegetable garden,but working the soil in preparation.
BIRDS: HUMMING BIRD arrival this week/ saw our first Robin, Cow birds are here, wrens are nesting, Bluebird was seen.
( barn swallows have not arrived as of yet ). Saw one canary finch.

END

properties.description:
TWO week report:  This has been an exceptionally WET period.  The surface of the ground is very squishy when walked upon - could not possible drive a lawn tractor on the yard or it would get stuck - sincerely.
Of course, like most in the immediate area we had exceptionally warm weather over Christmas.  We have had many plants blooming : roses; viburnum; camellias; dandelions; blueberries and strawberries;  even some hollies and clover blossoms are peeking up.  None of  this bodes well for the spring bloom period because - of course - we now will barely make it above 32 degrees F. for a day and the nights are in the low twenties.
We can only wonder what effect this will have on the spring blooms - for which our honeybees depend upon for a spring honey/nectar flow.
The rivers locally have all been at least 2 feet or more above flood level.  However, for the most part in OUR area, there has been no property damage.
New Year's Eve saw many rain storms running through - with the last just about 7 pm.  So MOST of the outdoor holiday celebrations went on without much impact from the weather.
Agriculture is at a low activity period ( at least locally - hardly any winter wheat was planted nearby us this year ); the tree farm folks have NOT replanted the stands they cut down one or two years ago.. the fields remain 'fallow';  Birds continue to visit the feeders, in fact, there are more cardinals than previously.
Hunting season ended here, last day was Jan.1; so I'm sure the deer will return to normal soon.  They are all nocturnal foragers now - between the hunting and the full moon.  Coyotes ( big ones ) have been seen a lot lately.
Energy usage had been low - with one or two days right at Christmas that the a/c had to be turned on. Now, we are back to heaters; and now, they are on during the day as well as at night.
Winds remain high ( above 15kts ) and out of the North or Northeast.
Standing water in all roadside ditches.

Treated with over the counter remedies and special care while handling food (gloves).

properties.description:
weekly report: total week precipitation: 72/100. Despite forecasts for storms and accumulation.  On Friday, when the area was experiencing a low off the coast, we were traveling in the area. 25 miles from our location - it rained a deluge. When we arrived home, we hadn't received a drop. Has to start and stop somewhere. Temperatures remained in the upper 90's inland, with overnights a bit cooler. Winds were 8+ ( higher with storm fronts). 
Agriculture: Soy is now 2 to 3 ft. tall; still no blooms right here - depends on when and where it was planted. The Ag. Ctr. is reporting on insects effecting local crops, with recommendations for identification and treatments. Those include corn earworm, fall army worm, tobacco budworm, sugarcane aphid, and loopers. For us, the mosquito population has not been significant at this time ( always here - but not an immediate problem ) The mosquito population for US is generally worse in September; and likely will depend on any tropical systems.
There is a noticeable difference in the color of the leaves of some trees. Some are beginning to show leaf drop. This includes: River Birch / Tulip Poplar / Ornamental Plums / and some oaks.  This is a LOW BLOOMING period: crepe myrtles are slowing, magnolias have some blossoms, grasses are 'blooming' a little bit.  Groundsel is beginning to form buds.
Lawn Grass ( centipede and 'the weed of the week' ) is thick as a carpet at this time. Growth is JUST beginning to slow.
WILDLIFE: no snakes seen this week (yeah ).  BIRDS: Barn swallows have abandoned their nests/roosts - not even returning to them at night. Now they are only visible lined up on electric wires.  Soon they will leave.  Canary Finch population at the feeder is greatly reduced. Other birds are not noticeably behaving any different. Cardinals, Grosbeak, Common House Finch, Cowbirds(small pop.),mockingbirds, wrens, Blue Jays, Crows, Hawk(s), Mourning Doves, and we sometimes hear both quail and whip-poor-will.  RIVER water levels appear normal by observation. The "cold" tap water is still very warm.
Sorry. I keep forgetting to measure the temperature of it.
Its that time of year when green starts appearing on the north side of buildings - washing time. properties.description:
weekly report:  We haven't had any precipitation over the past 7 days. The temperatures have been hot ( especially in the late afternoon ), but no heat advisories have been issued.  This location is 58 miles from the Atlantic (roadway driving miles); there have been some sea breeze storms over the past week, but they didn't make it this far inland ( nearby 10 miles or so, but not here ); roadside ditches retain a damp look only on the very bottoms, but are not ( as of yet ) dried or cracking.
Humidity has remained fairly high, there is a light fog most mornings. 
SOY beans look flourishing - not quite flowering HERE as of yet.  Area rivers are normal, although there is plenty of vegetation growing on the surfaces near banks and in slow moving estuaries.  
Winds have been +/- 8 mph, varied in direction.  A drying effect considering temperatures and zero precipitation.
VEGETABLES: cucumber and lope vines have succumbed to the conditions; peppers and tomatoes are suffering, but hanging on; green beans are doing fine, as are carrots.
FLOWERING: crepe myrtles, some slight knock-out roses. For pollinators in this locale, this period of time has a dearth of foraging possibilities; it effects how much brood they produce.  ENERGY:  Mornings are warm, but pleasant. By mid-afternoon most folks are back inside A/C.  No public events that I know of have been impacted by weather related issues.  / WILDLIFE: Snakes - again a week with snakes - we see them in heavier grassy areas ( cottonmouth this week).
Barn swallow young is all flying now, and no additional brood is being raised.  Birds are at the feeders as normal; but they do look forward to water to drink and bathe ( they arrive as soon as I clean and fill them daily )
One can JUST barely detect the effect of diminishing daylight, as leaves on trees just appear slightly drier, less lush. I believe it is due more to daylight than to moisture issues.

properties.description:
weekly report:  the past week's precipitation was just over 1/2 inch.  The temperatures were warm, breezy.  Nights getting cooler.  We will have two days of near freezing temps at night, then back up into the 70's days / 50's at night.  What remains blooming here on out, will depend upon if we have frosts/freezes over the next two nights.
Ground moisture remains fairly high, and there is still some standing water in ditches.
PESTS / INSECTS:  over the past week, both fire ants and mosquitos were truly annoying.  This is likely the worst mosquitos have been in nearly 10 years ( and fall is always worse than any other time of year ).  The fire ants have been fairly significant as well.  Both due to the rains we rec'd for weeks over the past month.
No public events have been impacted locally by weather this past week.
Agriculture:  Soy beans are browned and drying - awaiting harvest.  
Energy:  temperatures have been such that neither a/c nor heating has been required most days over the past week.
BLOOMING:  eleaganus, vitez, some magnolia, groundsel, asters, mums, roses.  Done blooming is golden rod.
BIRDS:  have not seen blue jays, canary finches.  Still prevalent are cardinals, common house finches, wrens, mockingbirds, kill deer, doves.
FOX scat is frequently seen.  Snakes have not been seen THIS past week.
Water levels in our two major rivers remains a big higher than normal ( always wind driven "tides" here ).  Creeks and tributaries still have standing water, if not a bit 'running'.
Fire level is a mixed bag - it is very windy, however the ground and underbrush is quite damp.

properties.description:
weekly report: Precipitation Total For Sun am thru Sat pm was 6.82, with an additional .16 reported Sun morning.
Just short of 7 inches of rain total AT THIS LOCATION.
This past week's rain, has been widely varied by location.
Both east and west of this location have seen significantly higher precipitation accumulations.
This, of course, effects the river levels tremendously. For example - in our county, there is a flood warning for a nearby ( significant ) creek. The area that they are warning for is approximately 6 miles from our reporting location.  The effect on the location itself is that roadside ditches and lesser creeks are not draining quickly.  But there is not any roadway flooding overall. Areas that historically flood - likely have, but most have drained by the time ( Sun am ) of this report.
We are all very thankful that the hurricane did not make landfall.  However, time was spent preparing for that possibility. ( boat secured, yard items stowed or tied down etc.)  One cannot wait till a determination of a hurricane path to prepare.
AGRICULTURE:  We traveled a couple hundred miles west into the middle of NC this Saturday. Tobacco still standing is likely "lost"; but soy beans locally and otherwise will probably still be able to be harvested.  Most corn has already been harvested.  I did not note cotton, but the heavy rains has likely damaged that crop, as it would most likely not have been harvested as of yet.
THE HAW RIVER was most definitely FLOODING.
As we left in the morning -the areas up river on the Neuse were rushing - by the time we returned in late afternoon - they were definitely flooding.
OUTDOOR PUBLIC EVENTS:  Many were cancelled.  This is a time of county fairs.  One major Seafood event at the coast was NOT cancelled ( surprisingly ), and lucked out as the area did not receive the rains it might have on Saturday ( and is looking like Sunday may "squeak by" without significant rainfall. 
WINDS ARE VERY HIGH at the moment.  So the danger of power outages caused by falling trees - due to saturated soil - is still fairly high.
In the meantime: Autumn marches on.  Last lonely female hummer left - last day seen was Wednesday Sept. 30th.
In advance of the storm fronts, cardinals were feeding more actively than normal.  Crows an hawks have been quite vocal of late.  Wild turkeys are seen frequently in large groups.   
MOWING Of LAWNs: has been impossible as there is either standing water, or the ground is so saturated that when walked upon, water comes near shoe tops.  Leaves are falling from oak, and crepe myrtle.  Red Maples are turning colors.  
BLOOMING: Eleagnus / Vitez / Golden Rod ( got pretty beaten down by rains ).
BEEKEEPERS: either harvested early last week ( and did winter-equipment on hives ) OR they will have to wait till the end of this coming week when wind and rains have abated and temperatures are still high enough to open the hives.  It is anticipated that with this duration of not being able to forage -bees will have been eating their stores - so less honey may be extracted than might have previously been anticipated.

properties.description:
WEEKLY REPORT:  It has been over a week since we had just at 1/10th of an inch of rain.  Temperatures at night ( two nights) fell into the lower 50's.  Between the dry spell; the shortening hours of daylight; and the lower temperatures - many signs of fall are beginning to appear:
AGRICULTURE:  Corn stalks ( and ears ) are drying in the fields / Cotton has been defoliated and is awaiting drying and then harvesting / Soy bean foliage is starting to yellow.
RIVERS:  Water levels remain at normal.
ENERGY: Temperatures contain to swing from the 60's at night to the upper 80' and some days into the mid 90's.  Air conditioning units are still humming /  Lawn grass remains lush, but growth has slowed.
SEASONAL: RED MAPLE - leaves starting to turn red / Tulip Poplar leaves continue to brown / Oak leaves browning and falling / Persimmons green leaeved and fruited / Mimosa pods are developed and starting to brown up / Crepe Myrtle Leaves have either fallen or are turning red and just starting to fall - depending on variety.
Riverside marsh grasses are starting to brown.
Mosquitos are around - but not a huge problem/ FIRE ANTS continue to "bloom" / BLOOMING:  Golden Rod / Groundsel / Wild Asters / Queen Annes' Lace ( limited ) / Some Magnolia blossoms / Camellia buds are forming for late winter -early spring bloom / Abellia is blooming as is VITEX /  Roses (especially knock-out varieties continue to bloom )// HONEY BEES - have plenty of capped and uncapped honey - we will get a much larger fall harvest than we did in the spring // Honey Bees are building their over-winter brood populations now // Winds have been about 6-13 generally // VEGETABLE: green peppers continue to produce / tomatoes are DONE / Pole Beans continue to flower and produce / Carrots were harvested / NEW GROWTH ON Hollies and Evergreen Shrubbery // BIRDS: HUMMERS -last female left today ( Sept 21st) / Have not seen the blue jays // Crows abound / as do turkey buzzards // Fox poop prevalent everywhere // Pollen levels seem to have abated a bit - less allergy symptoms reported // No public events have been impacted by any weather concerns.
OVERALL:  We could use a little rain.

weekly report: //  Well, we were in need of rain, and over 5 days of the last week we got it... receiving a total of just at 5 inches.
AGRICULUTRE:  The two local farmers JUST got their soy planted prior to the rains - and now, one week later, the seedling are up.
As for the days of rain - because in this IMMEDIATE area we received no more than 2-1/2 inches in any 24 hour period - we did not have flooding. In town - which is about 13 miles east - they rec'd over 6 inches in one rainfall - and that did cause street flooding.
PLANTS:  Blooming - still a small amount of white clover // the crepe mrytles are blooming here now ( have been about 1 week ahead in town A) // Vitex ( Chaste ) still hasn't blossomed // magnolias are still blooming // various lilies  ( cala, day, tiger ) are blooming - not yet for the big canaa lilies.  Black eyed susans are blooming.
BEES: ours are capping their nectar - honey harvest for spring will be within 3 weeks from now // 
BIRDS:  populations increasing as babies are born.
Finches ( both common red and canary yellow ) have once again taken to drinking out of the ant traps on the hummers feeders  - and hummers abound!!  Barn swallows are on their second batch of brood - most born, just not yet flying.
Grasses are growing heavily with rain, heat, and moderate sun ( cloudy but warm days too ).
Dragonflies are helping with the mosquito population.
RECENT WILDLIFE NEWS IN THE AREA:  In the past month, there has been two separate sightings of alligators in populated areas.  Now, mind you, there are a lot of creeks here, so this is not unheard of.  One was 8 feet and the other 6 feet in length.  
In a town about 30 miles from here - further down east - they are experiencing black bears, bobcats and alligators IN TOWN.
Public events are being well attended with no rain over the weekend; pleasant low 80's temperatures.

properties.description:
Weekly Report:
In the past week, we have had a total of 1.75 inches of precipitation.  More was forecasted, but did not materialize.  There were three days with rainfall.  Winds were on the higher side, so drying was an effect.
Ground Water at the beginning of the week was at about 18 inches.  WATER TABLE: We had to dig a hole at the beginning of the week, and water sucked into it.
Neuse River water level seemed low; but is important to realize that it is tidal, but wind driven. 
BIRDS:  Hummingbird: A male showed up early on Sunday morning April 5th.  By the end of the day, there were two at the feeder that was quickly placed.  At the end of the week, only these two males are evident.  Canary finches are now at the feeders.  A blue jay was seen, and the bluebirds are more actively foraging.  Still seen - cardinals, a variety of finches ( mostly common house finch ), red-winged blackbirds, cowbirds, crows, mockingbirds, robins, and wild turkeys are foraging ( and mating  - and hunting season opened here on April 11th ).
AGRICULTURALLY , we have seen little activity.  There has been some preparation in the pine farm to replant after the heavy logging throughout the fall and winter. They have mounded up the rows to plant in.
NEWLY BLOOMING PLANTS include Carolina jessamine, wild wisteria, cherry trees, azaleas are just starting HERE, snowball viburum is mid-bloom.  Done blooming: crab apples, redbuds, forsythia, popcorn spirea. HOLLIES are a concern this year.  The Nellie-R-Stevens were just ready to bloom a couple weeks past when we got hit with a one-night freezing temperature.  The fosteria, savannah, Carissa, oak-leaf,and American hollies have not bloomed yet ( not expected as they follow the Nellie-R's ) TREES: The Crepe Myrtles are leafing out, as are the oaks, maples, sweet-gum, river birch, and bay laurels.
Weekend Public Activities went off well, despite a forecast for rain on Sat. morning ( little rain fell).
We live "rural" and our public water supplied pressure has been extremely low all week.
Fire warnings have been made over the past week, due to winds.
Overall - we are concerned that the predicted "wet spring" may not happen.  Winds and temperatures have been more an effect than the precipitation.  Temperatures at one point went from 35 degrees to over 86 degrees in less than 12 hours. That makes it tough on spring garden plants ( such as lettuce, spinach, peas, beets, onions, etc. )

properties.description:
Oh, what a beautiful morning. Except for piles of snow in parking lots, it's all gone. But the yard is one big wet mess. It will take several days of sun and a good March wind to dry it out. Saw a pond yesterday that has land jutting out, leading to a circular sitting area. The pathway was under water and the sitting area was about half its usual size. I've never seen the water that high in the 25 years I've lived in this area. Hyco Lake reached a high of 411.10 on March 6 but has settled back to 410.83. It has been steadily increasing. As a result the cove is quite muddy in color, a change from when it had a layer of ice and then snow. But that was beautiful to see. Even the main body of the lake had ice on a good portion of it. Not looking forward to my next utility bill. Fortunately we only had brief power outages. Some were without for a day or more while some didn't loose power at all. Other streams, ponds, lakes in adjoining counties are very high Birds are still very active and enjoying the seeds we scattering. Bulbs are popping up and the buds are beginning to swell. With the predicted warm temperatures pops of color should be appearing. Except for grocery stores selling out of bread and milk most stores have suffered because of the winter weather. Garden centers have had a hard time getting shipments as transport across the country was delayed by the weather. Most businesses are saying February was a brutal month in more ways than one. A few hearty souls are still at the campground. Local fishermen must have cabin fever as the lake parking lot was full of trucks with boat trailers. Hope they had good luck as it was a beautiful day. This activity was good for the lake convenience store - its lot was full of vehicles also.  Farmers are saying they are grateful for the snow and increase in the water table but this has put them behind schedule in preparing the fields. Now we all will make up for lost time - meetings postponed, outside activities curtailed. But spring is just around the corner!

Water Supply and Quality

This is a summary of things I have watched over the last few months. Thank You Amanda for asking me to be part.
Wet Conditions are the problems out here… so close to the outer banks… Humidity and the biological critters that eat and destroy the homes here is a big issue (termites, carpenter ants, carpenter bees, etc.) With all this freezing during winter, the farmers are starting late. The snakes, we have water moccasins here with all these ditches being full and forestry here. They like to get under your house and pull down the insulation for your floor if they can get in. 

Many road projects have been delayed also. The roads are started but the road crews can not get out. Pot holes are everywhere. 

Older homes have not been cared for so much as the economy has been so depressed for so long. They really don’t have so much on French Drains, Vapor Barriers and stuff as either people don’t know, or they can not afford the newer things to make their homes energy efficient. (Many of the older Contractors too are stuck in wanting to do things the OLD way and not the NEWER way…) Wait until we have a hurricane… People have not and are resistant to retro fitting their homes on newer hurricane standards. One day we will have what the older locals say was Isabel about 15 years ago (I guess) and the wind whipped everything… well now that people can not afford to repair and maintain their homes because of Unemployment with the recession and now the weather… these houses and stuff are more venerable then ever to weather issues. The buildings are collapsing.

The other thing is lots of businesses out here (ie farmers, timber/lumber jacks and new starts of home building or restoration and repair) have severely hampered the Employment Base as tradesman and farmers cannot get out in this weather. In some of the areas up to 60% of the males in the census tracts are out of work (18-54 yo males). (US Department of Labor)

Many Plants around here are confused. My roses are starting to have stuff grow and the daffodils and other plants thought it was time… but then we had this last hard freeze. I am watching to see if the perennial plants will make it.

To give you an idea… Story: Dale (my boyfriend) works Industrial/Commercial HVAC. The company he works for is putting a third floor on one of the Sandals Resort Buildings at Duck, NC (close to Kitty Hawk on the outer banks.) Well, they got the roof off in Nov/Dec (other companies part) and then the freeze happened with the rain in December which delayed some things. Went into January and the building was damaged without a way to get the roof back on. B&M Construction, Inc (Electrical and HVAC&R) had to laid off all but 4 of the 35 employees… they are just now going back to work from being unemployed from Mid Jan for 5-7 weeks depending on when they have been called back to work. So it is not only affecting the building industry but the tourist industry too. I have no idea how much money is lost in work? business sales? recreation? farming? AG? Lumber?

People too are getting really depressed as SAD (Seasonal Affective Disorder) has had so many trapped inside their homes. People do not have the cloths for this kind of weather but it has now happened 2 years in a row, unseasonably cold. I will up day you on farming and plant growth.

All the ditches around here have had lots of algae and other growth in them since 2014 with all the standing water. Still having this problem. Not so much a problem with mosquitoes last year. 

The Tractor and Feed Stores are selling chicks and ducks, but with the weather, it is questionable if we can get them outside as Spring may be delayed. 

Lots of Cardinals and Blue Jays few Robins (not so much woodpeckers and others. I am not sure of all the species I see but identify what I know.) The Birds are having foraging problems, as well as the Canadian Geese cause the snow and ice. They can not find food.

properties.description:
weekly report:
Again, temperature more than precipitation has effected our activities this past week.
Actually, we could use a bit more precipitation; although the ground moisture remains adequate at this time.
Agriculture: while some of the soy beans have begun to be harvested, many fields remain standing.   Cotton has been harvested, and as always, the roadsides appear littered with the bits and pieces that scatter.  Former tobacco fields have been tilled.  We haven't seen any evidence of winter wheat being planted in this area this year.
Fall Colors in this area have been the prettiest in 9 years locally.  The Bradford Pears are making their show now.
Freezes have ended the official growing season.
Holiday Events including Veterans Day Parades; garage sales; craft shows etc. are well attended without any obstacles being presented by weather.
River levels remain high enough for safe boating, with some wave height warnings due to northerly winds.  The water temps in the rivers and sounds are now in the upper 60's as is the ocean water near the coast.
On a recent trip to the Atlantic, we saw a group of small sharks swimming very near shore.  ( not dog fish /sand sharks- but small ).  
As for our honeybees, they were left with plenty of food storage for the winter, so we have not begun to feed them at this time.  With a set back from freezes, but then warm times in between, we still have some blooming plants that they forage on during warmer and sunny days - including the invasive species " eleagnus"; the mahonnias; some camillias; and when it is warm enough to set them out, we have some mums - which are not their favorites.  The roses got knocked down this week during freezes, so are no longer available to the bees. A few magnolias are still trying to throw a bloom now and then, but with the recent freezes, this is likely over for the season now too.
The fall planting of red crimson clover ( for spring forage for the bees ) is doing well - staying green and getting roots well established.
Centipede grasses have turned rust brown now - mowing season is over ( unless someone would want to mulch up fallen tree leaves )

properties.description:
wkly.rpt.August 3rd thru the 9th:
Precipitation, humidity and heat. Heavy rain forecasted for today - August 10th.


In a 24 hr.period over the past week, all our pepper and tomato plants wilted, along with their 'fruit'.  This same scenario was experienced by others in the area. Discussions with other growers found they had the same experience.  A discussion with a Farmers Market vendor revealed that four of her produce suppliers have now quit for the season due to this.  ( Local Produce Supply Effected )

Moreover, more than one report of dead out ( areas or total) on ornamental fruit and some fir trees.  Suspected is either phytopthorea or armillaria. Diagnosis pending. 

Tobacco fields were aerial sprayed this week; and then the manual labor force went into the fields over the next days, pulling off flowers and suckers.
The soy beans have not quite started to bloom yet.
Corn stalks are starting to yellow
Fields have not been flooded ( yet - more rain expected today)

Honeybees have slowed brood laying and many keepers are reporting that their colonies are self-requeening. Many keepers are also feeding their bees due to reduced forage caused both by the time of year and too much rain.

Precip. has been heavy at times and in sporadic areas. However, dangerous storms have not been an issue. Some local festivities have suffered slightly reduced attendance due to the weather.

Local residents have struggled to find a period dry enough to mow lawns and fields, many which are laying wet.
Fire Ant mounds are popping up everywhere
Snakes are being seen more frequently ( mostly cottonmouth)
Barn Swallows have finished with their last clutches, and mostly do not sit in their roosting spots unless rain is heavy.
Blue Jays have not been seen in a month.
Hawks are beings seen more frequently.
Hummingbird population has exploded and they engulf feeders are the rain days.
Yellowish bodied dragonflies have shown up again this year, and the others are still around
Mosquitos are beginning to be problematic ( EE reported in the state recently )

Weather forecasting over the last week has been poor.
Days when it was to be clear, it has rained.
Estimated amounts of anticipated precip. accumulations have been incorrect.  Times of anticipated rainfall have been off by more than a little.

Still dry. We did receive a little over half an inch it is not nearly enough. I'm having to water the vegetable garden plus new plants set out this spring. Birds don't seem as active but have feeders and birdbaths ready for them. A hummingbird is a frequent visitor. Some of the bushes hurt but the late cold snap are beginning to come back albeit very slowly. Nice to have slightly lower temperatures and humidity. Of course the grass in the septic field needs cutting but not in other areas. Onward to gardening activities, with fingers crossed for rain. Really feel for farmers, their crops still are stunted. Fresh produce slow to arrive at the farmers market. While there hasn't been any fire warnings I am concerned with July 4th coming up and fireworks. Hope all are careful and have a wonderful holiday. The campground nearby is filling up, much more activity in and around the lake.

properties.categories: Agriculture,Energy,Fire,Plants And Wildlife,Society And Public Health,Tourism And Recreation,Water Supply And Quality
properties.description:
Weekly Report:  Very Dry :  We have had less than 2/10th of an inch of rain in the past week.  Combined with high winds, and cold temperatures at night ( two nights freezing ) makes for everything drying out.
There was a lot of bud and blossom damage at our location on Tuesday night when temperatures fell to 26 degrees, and were under freezing for at least 6 hours.
To note:  areas nearby ( within 5 miles ) did not have this same damage.  We witnessed blossoms and buds the next day in those areas.  Micro-climates exist here.
AGRICULTURE:  With the impending freezes, no planting was done this week.  Crop farmers are applying fertilizer at this time.
LOGGING has begun again.
BUS: INDUSTRY  n/a
ENERGY:  Temperatures have been moderate enough that heat or a/c units were not required, although on two cold nights, and with high winds, some heating units may have been run
FIRE: DANGER HIGH - dry and windy conditions exist
PLANTS:  Our bees were foraging on holly blossoms by the thousands on Tuesday afternoon.  By Wednesday morning - those blossoms were frozen and had turned black. We have begun feeding our bees since their population is high ( at spring brood-build-up) and the forage possibilities have greatly diminished
DAMAGED PLANTS ( leaves or blossoms )  Hollies, Clover (set back), Cherry and Apple blossoms, Azaleas - only got one day of bloom this year, Dogwood, Leaves burned and dropped off of Vitex; Fringe Tree; Figs.
We covered strawberries and blueberries with wheat straw - blueberries have fruit on them -dehydrating without rain - we are now manually watering.
WILDLIFE: Birds are in a similar state as our bees- in that forage has lessened.  This week showed up : BARN SWALLOWS and CANARY FINCHES in groups;  Hummingbird females showed up - the first day of the freeze.
RELIEF RESPONSE:  none required
Society and Public Health:  Wind has been so high, on a recent drive throughout our and a neighboring county, we witnessed clouds of dirt being torn off the tilled, but not-yet-planted crop fields.  Pollen count is in the high level
Tourism & Recreation:  Some outdoor public garden events were impacted by the freezing temps - causing lower attendance in the mornings, and much work by staff to protect plants
RECREATION
WATER SUPPLY - QUALITY
River levels are VERY LOW.  Lack of runoff from the period of no precipitation, combined with the wind-driven tides in the area rivers have made for water levels to be ( likely temporarily ) about 4 feet low this week.

properties.description:
weekly report: Precipitation Total for the Week was : 1.93 inches.  It was a soggy, sometimes humid and uncomfortable week.  Grass is growing ( and shooting up seed heads), but the amount of water on the ground makes it impossible to mow.  At this moment, a walk through the yard will bring water up to the top edge of your foot.  Very squishy.  Needless to say, there is standing water in the roadside ditches.  No flooding was reported; although a middle-of-the-night rain storm brought nearly an inch in an hour.  AGRICULTURE: not much activity due to rainy days - Soy Beans are well developed, some cotton was sprayed defoliage so the heads are apparent now;  BLOOMING PLANTS: some magnolia, vitex, abellia, roses, ragweed, golden rod, and grasses.  Leaves are thinning on the crepe myrtles.  Some oaks are showing leaf damage from catepillars.  Snakes are being seen - very healthy big ones - of the copper head variety ..errg! FIRE ANTS - a significant increase in mounds ( after rains, and seasonal brood build up )
No public events were impacted by any weather event.
BIRDS:  Humming birds are very much decreasing in numbers - within a two week period - we went from feeding nearly 2 gallons a week to over 30 birds, down to maybe 1 quart every two to three days for perhaps a half a dozen birds.  CROWS seem very vociferous these days; blue jay still around; canary finches - population low, but still around; cardinals are stepping up their feeding at the feeders; finches still around as are wrens, mockingbirds, and doves - lots of doves.  Wild turkey are frequently seen in the area. Evidence of plenty of healthy foxes based on the amount of scat found primarily in the middle of the road.
TRAVEL REPORT  - FROM EASTERN NORTH CAROLINA THRU the EASTERN SHORE OF VIRGINIA into the EASTERN SHORE OF MARYLAND:  Northernmost NC had just received several inches of rainfall the day before we drove through there ( stopped at a friend's farm )  They had flooding, but all was drained when we were there.  Virginia - seemed a bit dryer, but not very noticeable.  Maryland, on the other hand, was VERY DRY.  There, they are harvesting their corn; pumpkin foliage was dying ( or dead ) back with bright orange pumpkins in the fields; they are still selling locally grown roadside watermelon and lopes and sweet potatoes; Rainfall predicted for the area skirted it, and they rec'd way less than anticipated during our stay there -there grass is brownish; the farmers were using Reinke irrigation in their fields, their soy is much smaller and less developed than in Eastern NC.   It looked like fall was going to be the next week  - with either sweet gum or maple tree leaves turning colors already.
Our bees are doing well - laying brood for the over-winter period.  We will harvest our honey this week. ( and treat for varroa now)

properties.description:
This report covers Sunday 5/3 thru Monday morning 5/11://
At the beginning of the period, the winds remained high, with moderately high temperatures, so there was significant drying.  Our roadside ditches ( which are about 4 feet deep ) began to dry entirely out - only dark soil without any standing water. 
It was a juggling act to water newly planted items and vegetable garden.  Forecasts for rain were uncertain, and as the week ( and TS ANA ) progressed, forecasts fell short. UNTIL ... Saturday.  In some ways, the storm moving so slowly made the amount of precipitation that did come down a bit easer to take.  The about 4 inches we received here at this location was spread out ( thus far ) over three days.  As I write this, the center of the now Depression is about 100 miles to our north, so we could get some additional precip from it, but the skies are starting to have longer periods of light.
Winds through the storm were their strongest at this location at about 11 pm to midnight on Sunday night 5/10.

JUST prior to the storm's arrival, our local farmer spread fertilizer and lime on the fields.  We are still not certain what he is planting this year. Rumor says perhaps Sorghum.
Prior to the rain/storm, the bird feeder birds seemed to have slowed down their visits a bit ( although the blue jays started to visit the feeders ).  Now, after the storm, we see that many of the smaller finches are devouring the feed.  // As of this writing, although there are flash flood warnings for our county, we do not see any evidence of concern.// There were numerous outdoor public events locally over the weekend, none ( including ECU grad ceremonies) were cancelled.  Rain, if it came, was short lived.  The bulk of the precip. and winds came overnight Sunday to Monday.
