properties.description:
Report of my travels through parts of North Carolina, Virginia, West Virginia, Kentucky and Indiana. No shortage of water. Indiana had received over 7" of rain within a couple of days. Acres and acres of fields around Lexington KY were flooded. Roadside ditches in all states had standing water (and still standing along the road to my house). Runoff was coming through fissures in the roadside rocks creating absolutely beautiful waterfalls. Some flood relief shelters had been opened but that lasted only s short period of time. Going through some national forests signs said fire danger was moderate. But from looking at the ground, it really appeared very low. We would not have been surprised to hear of a fire started by lightning as we saw some very loud and colorful storms. Fields are too wet to work in all the states. Farm and garden activities are definitely behind schedule. There may be a shortage in the winter wheat harvest due to the wet spring. A local golf course admonished golfers to stay on cart paths as the new grass is suffering as it greens up due to the cart wheels. Hyco Lake level is 410.40" going up slightly after each rain. Fishing activity is strong, garden centers are busy despite wet conditions - gardeners are always optimistic. Campers are returning to the lake campgrounds and from what I heard campsites and parks are very active in the other states.Based on the number of tractor-trailers on the interstates, businesses must be thriving. Birds are very active with migratory birds stopping at our feeders for a nourishing refill. Summer clothes have come out of storage, spring is here!

Drought Impact Data: 
StartDate: 2015-03-23
EndDate: 2015-03-29
Is Condition Monitoring Report
Categories:

Currently not affected by drought. Conditions likely to be impacted include: numerous water leaks detected in public and private structures. Homes equipped with community water without individual meters making leak or overuse detection difficult. Can see wet areas on sidewalks when it has not been raining. These leaks are icy when the weather is cold and dry. Wildlife (large populations of Canada geese, pets, ducks), human waste, diapers, and obstructed drainage lead to increased fecal coliform bacteria counts and some temporary odors in creeks. Rain storms lead to increased marine debris movement in creeks (logs, balls, sticks). Local authorities unsure of jurisdiction for water issues (county, town, state, federal, upstream, downstream, atmospheric). Volunteer fire departments check on hydrants that may be leaking. Water company changes cleaning agents (ammonium, chlorine, other) periodically. A large number of recreational swimming pools in this area. Golf courses in area that may want to water putting greens for cosmetic appeal. Some neighborhoods resort to artificial colors to make grass appear green for appeal when it is actually brown due to dry conditions. People build campfires nearby. Air quality reports are made daily and small articulate is a baseline problem many days. A power plant may use water reservoir for electricity production. Local farms are already resorting to using their property for recreation rather than agriculture (hay rides, pumpkin patch, seasonal festivals). Recreational water reservoirs are affected by water levels and issues related (affect boat rentals, swimming areas, fishing, ability to eat fish,).   Other issues may become apparent later. The area is diversely populated with people from eastern hemispheres and southern hemispheres so there is a communication barrier for weather related incidents. These cultural differences also lead to mis-understandings about weather conditions even if the hazards are communicated in other dialects. Lack of economic resources make alternative choices difficult (to buy bottled water, stop eating fish, etc.) People are employed in car washes, laundry facilities, power washing, carpet cleaning, and other water dependent occupations. Bottled water is not always a viable alternative due to problems encountered in shipping or processing (may taste bad, inconsistent product quality, subject to sell outs, price ranges from cheap <$1 to expensive >$3 per bottle). Unable to wash clothes and bedding may lead to increased odors and sanitary problems such as dust mites, flea populations, yeast infections and body odor. Reluctance to properly rinse boats and sport equipment after use leads to spread or increase of invasive species in water supply. If people experience general health problems related to drought, they may have difficulty communicating to health care team in native language. May not follow prescriptions due and have to wait for weeks to see doctor again for side effect monitoring or treatment effectiveness assessments. Uninsured or unemployed not able to encounter health care system. Other local business depending on viable water for production and/or distribution here include: coffee shops, micro brews, wineries, soda/other beverage. People use these beverages for relief of thirst and emotional issues.

properties.description:
weekly report ending Saturday: December 20th
Ups and downs in temperatures, more than precipitation, has been the most impactful this past week.  Very pleasant, basically mild for this time of year.  Although it freezes very night, the large eleagnus plants protect the blossoms inside the shrub and the honeybees are foraging on them still every day.  We continue to supplementally feed them too of course.
Logging continues. What a shame!  We do realize that this is an agricultural crop, and that at some point that crop needs to be harvested.  However, there is so much logging going on that there are vast expanses deforested.  This is definitely going to effect wind patterns over this area for years to come ( until newly planted can grow tall enough to make a difference - which would be 10 years or so)
Additionally, we are sad to observe the loss of habitat that has been in place for years for Pilliated WoodPeckers; Squirrels; Blue Jays; Hawks; Eagles ( golden and bald ); oppossums, although I loathe them personally - snakes too.
It's just a mess. Very sad to have to witness the process.
Not to mention, those who paid for hunting leases are getting totally ripped off by the "company" as access has been denied, and of course, deer and bear, fox, and rabbits and more have all been displaced.  Not so easy to just go somewhere else where another colony of that same critter might already exist.

Water Levels remain more or less constant in the local rivers.. no flooding issues at this time.
Soil moisture is good - not soggy - not dried out.
Soil has not frozen down any inches this year so far. ( has an effect on fire ants )
Trees and shrubbery are growing steadily, benefitting from the moisture and not too cold temperatures this winter.

wkly rpt: June 1st thru June 7th.  Yes - We have drought conditions at THIS location.
For the Month of May, we received only 2.56 inches of rainfall.  For June, we have rec'd only .22 of an inch. While areas very close by have benefitted from some storms, ( as in flash flooding - several inches in an hour or so ), we have not received sufficient rainfall.   Worse, we are not anticipating any precipitation for at least another week.
in 22 days, we have rec'd only .22 of an inch; prior to that, we received only 1.44 of an inch in one overnight event back about mid-May. 
The tops of our 6 year old long leaf pines are turning brown; our river birch leaves have turned yellow, then brown and are falling off.  Our ditches are bone dry and the dirt has long cracks in it.  Birds continue to seek out any source of water ( the barn swallows use our swimming pool/ the finches use the ant traps on the hummingbird feeders). While in town ( 9 miles away ) the crepe myrtles are blooming, here they are struggling to do so for lack of water. 
In addition to a lack of precipitation, we have had usually about 15 knots of wind, and temps about 92 degrees daily.
We spend a lot of time and energy attempting to get water to the most needy of the plants.
Our buckwheat crop has started to dry out ( a bit prematurely). The rows of sunflowers we planted ( 30 rows - 60 feet long ) are stunted, and likely will not make maturity.
The winter wheat is totally dried, and appears ready for harvest.
The feed corn in our immediate area have curled leaves, and are stunted - while in other areas not too far away - the corn seems fine.
The tobacco farmer has sprayed this week for insects (having notified us prior - since we keep honeybees)
We have harvested some honey, but the bees are not finding much to forage on other than yard clover, ( which is beginning to dry out ), so they are consuming some of what they stored earlier on during the honey flow. ( which was somewhat interrupted by temperatures as well )
We anticipate a lower than normal honey harvest this year.
** Last week I made a statement about our barn swallows abandoning nests - I WAS INCORRECT.  I think that they were just so motionless because it got so cool ( for them ) at the nights - like 51 degrees a few nights running.  They are all hatching now, and some have taken flight.
The wild turkeys that raised their broods on our back acreage last year, have just returned.
Local river and creek levels remain high due to "up river" precipitation.. certainly not from anything that happened here.

With only 0.7 inches of rain over the past two weeks coupled with daily temperatures in the upper 8os and lower 90s we are seeing some stress to plants and trees. Approximately 5% of the leaves on the poplar trees are turning yellow. Several other trees are curling their leaves under. The grass in the lawn is turning brown in the areas that get direct sunlight during the day. Some of the flowers in the garden have dried up and only weeds seem to be thriving. The water in the stream and the pond is quite clear with no evidence of algae, however, the flow of water into the stream and the pond is almost non-existant. There is no water flowing from the pond and the level has been dropping slightly every day this week. We are still getting regular visits from the great blue heron. The raccoon left paw prints by the pond while preparing his food. Some snapping turtles pulled themselves out of the water to sun on the logs.

Drought Impact Data: 
StartDate: 2016-08-18
EndDate: NA
Is Condition Monitoring Report
Categories:

Normal rains finally returned during the last week in July and continued through the present, including a period of 15 consecutive days with measurable rainfall.  Even though our particular location for the period July 29 through August 23 received measurable rain on 19 of those 24 days, the total rainfall of just 4.25" was not particularly impressive.  But I think this was a bit of an anomaly for our station (and perhaps a few others) in the greater upstate SC based on CoCoRaHS data and radar loop analysis.  Consequently all symptoms of light to moderate drought have completely disappeared from Oconee and Pickens Counties.  However since our particular station location received much less robust rainfall totals than most, I would have to conclude that "incipient drought" still remains in our location and perhaps in a few other "isolated spots" in the Upstate as well.  To underscore this, our calendar year-to-date rainfall as of August 23 is the lowest since I have been keeping records (since 2003).  No doubt, the high number of rain-days along with accompanying low levels of insolation have much to do with the lack of symptoms of agriculture drought this summer.

The Rain just keeps on coming. We have been sealing up this house ahd both me and my husband have been experiencing increasing amounts of pain and fatigue over the last few months. Well, we found a place where the moisture was not sealed right on the inside next to our bedroom. Well, We killed the mold with 10% bleach and we also sprayed the whole house on the outside where the moss has been growing. Within 45 minutes of killing the mold in the bathroom, we were pain free and awake. We now are replacing the outside siding where the moisture was getting in. It makes me wonder around here how many of these old houses have leaks in them? I know, we have been very very agressive here in this remodel of a forclosure. Also without a real health officer at the public health department, I don't think the environmental director is proactive in human diseases. Mostly only agricultural. I have talked several times to the person incharge of the ground water problem (which came from cattle) he had no idea of all the health issues with water that is standing.

Really, we need a health officer to identify issues. They are not utilizing as much modern technology to fix some of these problems.

properties.description:
The pinpoint arthropod bite that was inflicted while I was visiting the creek has resulted in: fever spikes for more than 7 days; administration of three different antimicrobial pharmacological agents available only with prescription; and other costs/suffering/consequences unresolved and continuing to toll. Recent animal sightings include: high and slow flying buzzards/vultures; dragonflies (one popular variety has a light colored tail section with 4 darker wings, i saw 8 of these perched nearby on the asphalt); a few bare pine cone hulls that have been completely stripped of all their barbs apparently by a type of squirrel; another snake (slimmer than a pencil and slightly longer than a pencil) silently moving from the paved parking lot into the brush at the border; doves calling during certain times at certain locations. On Friday I observed a 15 cents difference in the price of a gallon of regular gas at two convenient stores located less than 3 miles apart, but different customer demographic neighborhood settings. I noticed a slow and continuous water leak at a park that resulted in minor sidewalk flooding. I have not seen the cattle grazing in recent days where they used to graze. I have seen the growth of some green leafy ground level crops that appear like soybeans, but am not certain of the exact crop species.

properties.categories: Plants And Wildlife,Water Supply And Quality
properties.description:
The first week of August has been typically hot (upper 80's) and humid with lots of hit and miss thunderstorms. We have been mostly missed with only .52" of rain and half of that fell yesterday when we got a hit. The last two days of July saw .72" of rain. The garden has been producing well. The hummingbirds are at their peak with all the family at the feeder which they consume in a day. Soon the adult males will head south. Fawns are still spotted, but growing. Deer seem more visible. Lots of bear reports nosing around--perhaps yearlings striking out on their own. With a flower garden full of zinnias and other blooms, the butterflies and caterpillars have been fun to watch. The drinking spring remains at excellent quality and quantity. I always enjoy the nightly chorus of katydids and crickets that are so striking in August. Cicada shells left behind reveal emerging adults that sing by day. School started in TN last week and will begin in our county next week.

Water Supply and Quality

No drought impact.  
Once again, rainfall plentiful and above normal.
Some August figures:  As of today, August 8.
Since Aug. 1, we have had 5.06 ....normal MONTHLY Aug. rainfall at 'RDU is 4.36
Since Jan. 1 we have had 39.27", Normal for YTD at DUE is 26.28
Since Aug. 8, 2015 we have had 67.02", normal yearly rainfall for RDU is 43.35.
We are pretty consistent at approx. 50% above normal.
Just as we were in the fall, from Oct. 1 2015 to Dec. 31 we had 20.69" which was coupled with much higher than normal temps and very little frost.
All this has given us amazing plant growth for this season.  Many trees and shrubs that have been planted for 2-5 years have doubled in size this year.   And some herbaceous perennials that have been in the ground for decades are approx. 25% taller than normal.
Of course, on the other had not a good year for drought resistant/desert type plants that are not in extremely perfect sitings.  
What a year!!

hot, hot, hot; dry, dry, dry.  however, we did receive 0.56" of rain in 3 events this past week - not nearly enough for the high temperatures. ants have become a problem.  it appears that even they are seeking water!  nearly every morning we awake to ants in the sink and drains.  lagoons are dropping, lawns and gardens are stressed.  this is the first year that our hydrangeas have not done well.  they are all in shade gardens, but still did not thrive well.  flowers turned brown right after opening with the exception of the oakleaf hydrangea which flowers earlier than the other varieties.  this summer is, by far, the hottest summer in the 10 years we have lived here.  next report in 3 weeks.  hopefully, there will be some precipitation relief!

properties.description:
At 8 AM near latitude 35 degrees 50 minutes along the Indian Creek trail the following observations: creek was 51 inches wide and 8 inches deep, flowing laminar, color appeared similar to light ginger ale or green tea, air temperature was 76 degrees and humidity was 85% in the overcast shade. Fauna included: >6 macro-invertebrates crawling along the submerged portion of a rock, crickets chirping, a small moth flying off the ground,song birds singing, ants on the ground, a spider on the ground. I removed a lone star tick from my mid section upon returning home (>1/8 inch long < 1/8 inch wide). Plants at creek side included: green moss/algae, trees, grasses, shrubs, old pine straw washed up and suspended from higher water, numerous green/brown quasi spherical berries <1/2 inch diameter on the ground. I filtered ~10 ounces of creek water and found multiple small dark motionless unidentified particles. In situ creek water pH measured 7.0 (+/- 0.2), chlorine low, free chlorine ideal, alkalinity very low, hardness very low. (compared to refrigerated tomato salsa today as a control:: pH ~ 6.2, hardness high, alkalinity low.) During the 20 minutes at this site I observed more than 10 people walking, riding bikes, and dog walking along the path. ///Yesterday I saw a large heron fly away from a drainage pond near the library.

We've been on the edge of the thunderstorms the last week with only hundredths of an inch of rain each day. Over the last 8 days we received a total of .82" of rain, with one day getting .54". This has been a week of humidity and heat--highs about 91°. When we dug potatoes, we were surprised by the moisture in the soil, despite little rain. We're enjoying sweet corn, fresh tomatoes, green beans, and zucchini. The hummingbirds are draining the quart feeder in a few days with a flurry of near constant activity. Goldfinches, chickadees, cardinals, and titmice are eating lots of seeds, while Carolina wrens flit about eating insects. Wood thrush sing every evening. Green frogs are singing up mates. Our drinking spring remains at excellent quality and quantity.

properties.description:
Less than an inch of rain (0.84) over the past three weeks has left an impact on the streams in the area. The smallest stream beds are now completely dry while larger streams have damp stream beds and the largest ones have slowed to a bare trickle. The ponds are still full, however there is almost no water flowing out of them. The trees and vegetation do not appear to show any impacts from the lack of rain. The trees are all leafed out and there is no sign of any leaves turning yellow or dropping off. The wildflowers are in full bloom and the wild blackberries are ripe for the picking. Grass seems to be growing well. The soil is firm but does not appear to be dried out. Wildlife appears to be doing well with several large deer spotted in the woods. The frogs in the ponds are filling the night air with their singing. There were quite a few tourists around over the weekend but they have thinned out considerably so it is now much more peaceful. A long walk on local roads this morning did not encounter any motorized traffic or any other walkers.

properties.description:
With only 0.25 inches of rain in the past week and daily temperatures near or above 90 degrees, we are seeing some striking impacts of the lack of rain. The soil moisture levels are now well below normal. The grass is turning brown and shows very little if any growth. The birch trees are showing stress by dropping dry brown leaves which now cover the ground below the trees. The flowers are still blooming but they are not flourishing except where they are regularly watered. The ground is very hard even in the low-lying areas that are usually soft and muddy. Some tulip trees are showing yellowing of the leaves. There is no water flowing in the stream, the stream bed is dry. The pond is down about 10 inches below normal and the water has turned a murky brown color although it is still possible to see the bottom. We had several white tail deer grazing in the yard in the evening. The paw prints of the raccoon are clearly visible in the mud along the pond bank. Birds continue to visit the feeders.

24 hours following a heavy rain, the following observations are submitted: in a stagnant shallow water puddle beneath a light pole not far from a pond, a struggling slender fin fish measuring 4 inches long and two inches tall was flopping and swimming at 2 PM; a cup of water was taken from the outside spigot and inside faucet with replaceable name brand filter with the following results at 8 PM;; "temperature" 68 inside, 66 outside; "chlorine" ideal outside, low inside; "pH" ~7.0 outside, >7.2 inside; "alkalinity" low inside and outside; "hardness" very low outside and inside. In nearby Carpenter Village at 3 PM, the lake was flooded and the creek upstream of the lake at Morrisville Parkway bridge was unusually stagnant and very high. The creek water at Morrisville Community Park at 7 PM was freely flowing, tumbleweed colored, and not currently rising. Some of the ball fields were closed at the park. We lost electric power for ~4 hours from ~10 PM to 2 AM. Frozen and refrigerated foods were monitored by thermometer and not adversely impacted. I read a news account of a nearby house fire caused by lightning strike and also a number of emergent water rescues and displaced apartment and house residents due to extreme weather.

properties.description:
weekly report:  We didn't have much precipitation this past week; however; the condition remains EXTREMELY WET.
There was SOME drying mid-week, when the temperatures got a lot cooler - "cold air is dry air", and the winds picked up.
However, the ditches retain water, running slowly, but moving.  Beavers have caused a lot of localized flooding in the immediate vicinity. The rising waters are threatening roadway culverts, and drainage pipes; as well as communication posts, which are beginning to go under water.
AGRICULTURE:  We've seen tractors in fields, mowing ditches, and perimeters, however, no active planting or soil prep at this time.
The potential problem with plants that have bloomed too early continues.  Buds form, then freeze at night with temps just below freezing. ( it was a very up and down temperature week).  
BLOOMING:  Leather leaf mahonnia - the best blooms we've ever seen on these plants. Daffodils are up, roses have blooms, camellias ( normally don't bloom till March ) have some blooms.  Blueberries, strawberries.. the list goes on.
Our HONEYBEES are bringing in a LOT of pollen - mostly we suspect from mahonnia, red maple, dandelions.  The hollies are very near to blooming ( usually not till March ).
There is absolutely a solid early brood build up in our bee hives.  This may not be all that good; and will depend on the remainder of the next two months temperatures.
Locally, over the past week, sea turtles got "chilled" and were found on the beaches, near chilled to death. They were brought in, warmed up and either have been, or will be released back to the ocean.
ENERGY:  Heaters on at night, a/c on during the days... off and on, inconsistent usage.
No public event that I know of was impacted by bad weather.
Local rivers continue to be at or near flood levels; without any property damage at this point.
Fire ant mounds are prominent in most fields.  It was recommended by cooperative extension that this might be a good time to go apply poisons - would diminish the spring bloom of these ant mounds.

Ground moisture levels are on the low side of "normal" and appear to be trending downward. Once again we are beginning to see the effects from a lack of rain. Although the trees are fully leafed out, a few of the leaves are beginning to curl under and/or dry out and fall off the trees. Flowers are growing and blooming but not with the vigor they showed when they had plenty of water. The weather has been very hot with daily temperatures over 90 degrees. We are planning to resume watering the gardens next week if we don't get some additional rainfall. The yard is mostly green but we are seeing some dried patches and the grass is thinner than normal. The stream is slightly murky but the bottom is still visible. There is no algae floating on the stream or the pond. The pond is full but the flow out of the pond has been reduced to a bare trickle. There are a few small fish in the stream and pond. We have seen some deer passing through our backyard again which is a good sign - although it is bad news for the hostas.

In the first 12 days of July, we've had 8 days with some rain totaling 2.5". Most of the rain came in downpours from thunderstorms, but we've had no runoff or erosion. Yesterday's storm only brought .11", so the sun has dried the top layer of soil, while the roots enjoy moisture. The garden is growing and yield a bounty of squash, cucumbers, beets, and chard. I've begun harvesting garlic and potatoes will be soon. Wildlife are occupied in the business of raising offspring. Box turtles are prone to venture out often crossing roads. Snakes are active--black rat, eastern milksnake, and copperhead all showed themselves in the last few days. Bees are healthy and active as the sourwoods begin to bloom. We took a super of honey last week.
In the midst of maximum tree transpiration, the turbine is off, although the creek is normal. The drinking spring remains at excellent quality and quantity.

This year's drought seems to have had it's incipient beginning in early May. Since May 2 through the first week of July (July 7) only 4.17" of rain has fallen on this station. This computes to rate of 1.86" per month for a period of over 2 months (67 days). Such a departure during late spring/early summer here is unprecedented here at this station SC-PC-1 in our 14th year of keeping records. One has to go back to the autumns of 2007 & 2008 since two month totals have been that low.  That said, drought impacts here have been fairly muted and restricted to agriculture/horticulture only.  Even premature autumnal leaves on indicator tree species like Liriodendron tulipifera (Tulip-tree or Tulip-popular) have been scarce.  Nevertheless until July 7, the conditions here had been steadily deteorating.  However, this past week has seen at least a temporary return to deep level southwesterly flow and thus more frequent and productive rains which have totaled 1.73".  Thus, in just 1 week we have nearly equaled each of the two previous monthly totals! Hopefully this trend continues, then I can finally cut back on irrigation.

Plant growth this year has been remarkable...both new plants and long established plants.  This has been due to not jus the rain this spring and summer, but the extremely wet fall that was warm and wet until the end of December, then our very mild and brief winter weather.

Lagoons are now noticeably lower.  It has been approximately a 3-week period of constant, extreme heat which we haven't seen for about 3 or 4 years.  There is some chance for rain later this week.

One of the local NWS all hazards radio stations announced a public information statement recently that one local NOAA weather station was off the air due to lack of electric power and the power company was looking into the problem. In situ water screening at 6:30 PM today in a shallow stagnant portion of an ephemeral ditch that connects an apartment complex parking lot and the larger creek branch. Water temperature was 73 degrees in the shade and 1.5 inches deep. The bottom is lined with sand/rocks/pebbles and stones. I overturned several rocks that were apparently devoid of life, but one stone had a dark brown 1/2 inch long macro-invertebrate slowly crawling across the wet under-surface of the rock. pH was slightly >7.0, chlorine was low, hardness was low, alkalinity was high. I took a shallow scoop of bottom material and observed roots, sand, pebbles and other motionless debris (without aid of magnification). A large number of arthropods took flight as we approached on foot. When leaving the site we observed a long (>5 feet) snake slowly slithering across the pavement. The dog sensed the snake from a safe distance, so I can only discern a general predominately bronze/copper pigmentation with some light and dark patterns without determining the species. I recently observed a local farm the had some type of long sheet like material covering the furrowed fields in large strips.

The lawn is growing again and the leaves that had been falling from the birch trees are no longer dropping leaves. The flowers are growing well, some iris have gotten quite exuberant and have grown too tall and have toppled over. The soil is damp to the feel and has softened. The creek is full and flowing with a normal flow. The water is slightly murky but the bottom of the creek is still visible. The pond is also full and there is no sign of any algae blooms despite having temperatures above 90 degrees each day. We regularly see the great blue heron as he comes to fish. The snapping turtles are lining up on the fallen logs by the dam. The spillway which had dried up in my last report is flowing again. There is a wide variety of birds visiting the feeders in the yard.

Under certain undefined conditions (time,place,weather?), large groups of "clicking bugs" are heard clicking with crescendos and decrescendos in unison and solo. I have seen at least 20 full grown showy purple flowering mimosa trees on roadsides and creeksides. They are rather inconspicuous for most of the year but are in full bloom recently. Several younger smaller mimosa trees are also growing along the roadsides. I continue to see bats in flight around streetlights prior to sunrise and sunset.

We're in a good news-bad news situation.  First, the good news.  June met and exceeded it's average monthly rainfall by 0.35".  The bad news is the timing of the rainfall.  Long periods of dryness between rainfalls is the problem, sometimes near two weeks.  Worse, it is now very hot.  It has been in the 90's for the past week with no let up and expecting 100 by the end of this week.  Heat indexes have hit 110 and 111 and expected to get worse.  Some chance of rainfall mid-week is expected.  Constant watering of lawns, gardens and plants is needed.  Lagoons are still holding their own with only minimal drainage.  Best case scenario, hope for adequate rainfall at some point this week.

Wet conditions.   4.13" of rain just this past week.  The yard and gardens are lusher than they ever have been.  Rainfall has been almost perfect all spring and summer.  There was a 2 week period in mid-June that was dry.  Otherwise near perfection.  We have many houseplants in pots that we put out in April after frost.  They have only needed to be watered by hand once since.  Likewise the vegetable garden.  It is truly remarkable.

I saw 5 to 10 bats in flight around light poles two hours prior to sunrise today. usually a single bat per pole and numerous flying insects. I surveyed a randomly chosen storm grate that was >90 free of obstructions with brown pine straw and one small pine cone aggregated in the downstream corner closest to the curb. Insects encountered today include: spiders with webs less than 6 feet off the ground; small mosquitoes that approach soon after exiting the door; a large yellow/black butterfly in flight; numerous airborne fireflies flying between a few inches and four feet off the ground. Birds observed include mourning dove; redbirds, and numerous large birds of prey circling at altitudes too high to classify.

In situ qualitative screening of a roadside ditch water slowly trickling towards the Crabtree Creek--Nuese River--Pamlico Sound--Atlantic Ocean system at 8 PM: pH slightly >7.0; very low chlorine; very low hardness. Clarity was similar to "ginger ale". A bottled sample was removed and the weight compared to filtered tap water. The weights were the same (7.3 oz) hence the specific gravity is ~1. I filtered 8 ounces of the ditch water with a paper coffee filter and observed what appeared to be two dead ants and various other smaller dark specks with a hand held magnifier. I observed one stray cat at the park and subsequently reported the animal with photo to the regional "lost pets" website.

With the aid of a random number generator, I chose one nearby storm drain to survey. The grate was >95% free of blockage. Among the trash in the grate was: one “timberwolf” colored plastic shopping bag; one small white piece of paper; and one 6-inch-long twig with 12 attached leaves of maximum width ½ inch. The leaves were “forest green” on the upper and “gold” colored on their undersides.  I picked up one “yellow green” colored gumball off the ground that measured 1.25-inch diameter.  The stem was 3 inches long and branched into a 5 pointed “yellow green” leaf. I saw one large heron in flight at low altitude (just above the tree level).

properties.description:
Soil moisture levels remain below normal. We have had 1.61 inches of rain since Monday but it seems to have had little impact. The small streams have all dried up and the flows in the larger streams is much reduced. A few leaves on some of the shallow-rooted trees like birches have turned  yellow and dropped off, likely as a result of water stress. The water color in the pond turned brown with sediment following a rain storm on Monday that dropped 1.01 inches of rain in less than an hour. It has since cleared up. The same storm washed the debris and gravel out of the stream beds into the streets and re-routed some streams. The surface soil appears soft in the shaded parts but has dried out in the places that get full sun. The mountain laurel are still blooming. The blackberry flowers are all gone and the green berries are beginning to grow. Some ripe wild blueberries were discovered and enjoyed today. The deer tracks are visible in the pathways. We have wild geese on the pond and frogs in the pond. We are expecting a large influx of visitors this weekend as the roads and stores are already crowded.

The Town newsletter released an article stating the  storm water division (the Town does not animal control department) is proposing a new law that penalizes dog owners for not properly disposing of pet waste with monetary fines. Earlier this month we received a 6 inch x 4.25 inch postcard bulk mail from the Town water resources department with 4 tips for summer watering including the every other day sprinkler rule and contact telephone number and website for more specific guidelines. Many local news outlets are publicizing the case of amoeba infection in North Carolina that led to early mortality of a young water sport participant.

properties.description:
Brief roadside ditch survey at 3:30 PM 6/26/2016: water is clear and 1-inch-deep at a spot in the shade. The water temperature was 82 F and any downstream flow could not be detected at that location (stagnant). An adult fly landed on my knee. It looked like a housefly but was metallic blue/green colored. Two dragonflies were in flight above the water. One was much larger than the other and both insects had metallic blue colors on their thoracic segments. A fire ant was seen crawling upon a partially submerged rock. Both ditch banks had green foliage (blooming wildflowers, grasses, shrubs, trees). Lifted a large rock (length/height/width all less than 12 inches, irregular shape) from the ditch bottom. There were no signs of plant/animal growth on or under the rock. Some dull green striations on the grey rock indicate there may have been some algal growth at one time, but the rock was not slippery in those spots today. I scooped some sand no more than an inch below the ditch bottom with a mesh strainer and did not see any signs of life. There were different colors of sand and pebbles (grey, tan, red, yellow, dull colors) but no movement or growth of any type was observed.

properties.description:
Soil moisture levels are remain below normal. We had just under 3/4 inch of rain over the past week and this is just not enough to make up for the deficits we have been seeing for the past month. Prior to the rains the soil had been extremely dry, and the trees were showing signs of water stress with more and more leaves turning yellow and dropping off. The grass has not needed mowing for more than two weeks and while some flowers are blooming, others are not flourishing. The rains did slow the water stress on the trees and other plants but have not reversed the trend. The stream flows picked up somewhat immediately after the rains but has since returned to a trickle or no flow at all. The level of the pond has fallen and it is now about 6 inches below normal. Water has stopped flowing downstream from the pond. Fish and frogs seem to be doing well and seem to be increasing in number. The great blue heron has come very close to the house in pursuit of food. Fresh deer tracks are seen again in the yard and we have many species of birds at the feeders.

The creek water is fairly clear today and some green grasses are growing on some of the sandbars that were previously submerged. I saw about 10 mallards in the water this afternoon. I saw more than 30 cattle grazing this afternoon on a hilly pasture.

Ground moisture levels are below normal. The surface of the ground is dry although digging down a few inches reveals some moisture in the soil. We are beginning to see signs of stress on the birch and sycamore trees from lack of water, some leaves are turning yellow and dropping to the ground. There are no longer any soft or muddy places in the yard. The rate of grass growth in the yard has dropped off and we have not had to mow for over two weeks now. Most flowers are continuing to grow and develop. If we don't get more rain soon we will have to resume watering. The water in the creek and pond is clear. The flow into the creek has stopped on the surface. There are numerous small fish and tadpoles visible in the creek and pond. The level of the pond has dropped about 5-6 inches below full. The great blue heron is seen daily in and around the pond. We did see fresh deer tracks by the pond this morning. Birds are continuing to frequent the feeders and nesting boxes.

Before sunrise today, I observed bats in flight around certain streetlights. I saw an unclassified wild animal that was as big as a dog but the legs were shorter and the tail was larger than most domestic canines. I observed a dead raccoon in the middle of a 4 lane road. This afternoon I observed the clear shallow creek water slowly flowing downstream. From a wooden footbridge in the park, I saw a small (<10 fish) school of small (< 3-inch-long estimated) minnows swimming upstream in the shallow creek water.  I utilized a user friendly website provided by the power company to report a streetlight problem. The power company website provides an aerial view for the customer to pinpoint the location of the outage on an electronic map.  The electronic map provides GPS coordinates in degrees carried out to several decimal places, as well as street numbers. After submitting the power outage report, the power company responds with an e-mail confirmation to the customer and provides an estimated repair time and contact number for follow up.

Conditions at White Oak Creek at Green Level just west of toll road 540 at sunrise:
Shallow water, bottom visible, slowly trickling beneath the road bridge.
Yellow underground gas markers are in the area. 
Cattail appearing slender green leaves thriving in the marshy area. 
A lone adult goose was seen dabbling, he retreated under the wooden walking bridge as I approached, he was clucking low soft sounds. The Canadian goose facial patches were a dirty grey color. His slow movements were awkward.
Localized small bubbles were observed emanating from the boggy bottom through the dingy surface biofilm.
While clearing certain roadside storm grates of assorted organic and inorganic obstructions this morning, I noticed significantly warmer air temperature beneath some, but not all grates.
The nearby Road was closed to cars, but the bike trail is not marked as closed. 
A small farm pond with at least 20 adult geese quietly concentrated close together near the center of pond was observed at dawn.

properties.description:
TWO WEEK REPORT / WET //
First week precipitation was .28 -- however, the second week we received 6.59 inches of rain.
It is difficult to keep up with fast growing grass and weeds. When downpours happen - we have standing water; amazingly ( with clay soil ) we have had fairly quick drainage though.
AGRICULTURE: CORN is loving this and the fields seem well.
BUSINESS: NA // ENERGY: has been hot and humid so air conditioners are running.  We have also had power outages - one which caused a surge that 'toasted' our electronic equipment - when no lightening strike seemed near //
FIRE: Low threat level // PLANTS: Everything has been getting enough water - now we hope that winds forecasted won't take down trees // WILDLIFE: Turkeys are sitting on their nests and foraging about three times a day // The bees are struggling to dehydrate the nectar into honey - but it is happening slowly.  Also, since it has been so rainy, the bees have been uncapping the honey and eating it in lieu of foraging when it is raining.
BIRDS are HAPPY.
RELIEF RESPONSE: NA..
SOCIETY and PUBLIC HEALTH - no warnings YET - but the mosquitos must be going to be an issue soon.
TOURISM:  Seems fine - some public events have been impacted by passing storms/
Water Supply and Quality - river levels are just SLIGHTLY above normal - as they had been low to begin with.   Drinking water is fine ( county )

Since I relocated to this area over a year ago, I have been able to find (in the phone book or internet) contact information to report power problems and dead animals on the road 24 hours a day, all year. The issue I have encountered in frequently using these numbers is jurisdictional boundaries for response between several small towns, private sector, the county, and the state. Although all reports are taken and acknowledged, they frequently are referred to another jurisdiction either by the response center or the response center provides me with the contact number of the appropriate agency. Some incidents require lengthy investigations or are not addressed as a priority (such as reporting a dead animal and the carcass decomposes to a skeleton in the same location weeks later). edit: At 1520 Morrisville Parkway community park behind the maintenance building on the creek bank I saw what appears to be a Mimosa tee (Albizia sp) in bloom with feathery purple/white semi spherical flowers. This may or may not be an invasive species. I also saw three rabbits in the park, one of which was juvenile. In  another neighborhood I saw a large shrub growing inside a curbside storm grate with more than 9 long branches protruding from inside the grate above road level 15 to 20 inches long with healthy green leaves.

properties.description:
Ground moisture levels have returned to normal due to the 1.35 inches of needed rain we've had over the past week. The lawn along with the trees and shrubbery are growing well again. Prior to the rain some of the trees had started showing water stress - the birches were losing a few yellowed leaves and the sycamore leaves were starting to curl under. These signs of stress are no longer showing up. The great blue heron has returned to the pond although we have yet to see any trace of the white tailed deer in our yard again this week. The creek is flowing with clear water. No trace of algae were seen. Small frogs and turtles are visible in the pond.

Established plants are persisting, but the seedlings are wilting and need extra water. I've carried water to the seedlings every few days. The temps in the upper 80's amplify the dry conditions. The hot, dry weather is great for boaters on the French Broad River. The river is running at 1300 cfs, which is medium low, but adequate.

properties.categories: Plants And Wildlife,Society And Public Health,Water Supply And Quality
properties.description:
During the month of May 2016 I heard two separate mourning dove calling on separate days and locations that the bird calls sounded congested with excess upper airway phlegm. 
Downstream of Grace Park ponds today I saw several large duck potatoes (>=1-foot-long green arrow shaped leaves) growing among the cattails. Neither the duck potatoes nor the cattails are flowering now. The large arrow shaped Sagittaria weeds are out of reach for closer observations without additional protective gear.  
About ten feet from the bank of a slowly westward flowing shallow ditch, I overturned one rock which left a shallow depression in the moist soil approximately 6 inches long and two inches wide. Underneath the rock were less than 30 large red ants in rapid motion. There was one aggregation of approximately 20 white rice appearing formations measuring less than ¼ inch long. The red ants scurried to carry the white eggs/pupae down a larger opening in the soil when the rock was lifted. 
The topsoil measured 81 degrees in the shade. Other life observed here today included: yellow blooming dandelions, oak trees, pine trees, vines, grass, crows, herons, frogs, chirping/clicking bugs, and filamentous green algae on creek bottom substrates.
Between 3 and 4 AM I observed a very bright yellow/orange falling star rapidly descending and then disappearing into darkness while falling toward earth in the west-southwest partly cloudy sky.

properties.description:
Along the water’s edge in several areas are growing tall (6 feet tall, +/- 1 foot) stands of slender green plants. At eye level, the blades of the green leaves measured 5/8-inches-wide and are colored the same shade of “forest green” on both sides and are equally smooth to the touch on both sides. The pointed tip of the last ½ inch of the blades is a “tumbleweed” color. These tall plants are living in similar habitats as cattails or bulrushes but do not have any fruit or flowers or any obvious identifying features above the ground except tall green slender blades today. I saw a hen and drake pair of mallards floating among these plants in an ephemeral pond yesterday after the rain. 
We are seeing a few fireflies at night now. 
I am seeing the return of what appear to be underground mole tunnels in certain moist areas but have not seen the actual animal. 
Yesterday afternoon after the rain an unusual number of small airborne dragonflies were observed less than one foot above ground for several hundred feet along a path close to the creek bank. One pair of the flying insects appeared to be copulating in flight.

properties.description:
In the community park near the athletic fields that are usually in use by humans, especially every weekend, I observed 5 adult Canada geese in the light rain at 9 AM today. I have not seen geese on the ground here in nearly a year, although they frequently fly overhead. The park this morning was completely abandoned of humans due to inclement weather and Memorial day.   I pulled another tick from the epidermis yesterday before the tick bit. The lone star tick measured slightly more than 1/8 inch long and slightly less than 1/8 inch wide.  I saw an adult drake mallard on the front porch of the public library yesterday casually walking around, not making any noise. Carpenter lake is very close tot he library and has been observed hosting numerous geese, opossum, ducks, turtles, herons, cats, one recreational SUP paddler and other indigenous species.  Not far from the library I also saw a farm supply store, several barns, several tractors, and other farm equipment (none of which were in use at the time).

The fresh grass and soil was obstructing more than 30% of available drain area. In another neighborhood, I cut a 1/16inch diameter plant stem that was protruding 8 inches above the drain grate. The cut stem segment had 8 leaves measuring ~2 inches long. (I was unable to accurately observe and examine the plant growth beneath the grate) There were many more stems growing from within that particular grate. The dorsal surface of the leaf color resembled “forest green” and the underside leaf color resembled “sea green” (Crayola) after spending two hours in a sealed airtight plastic bag. Although most of the local grates that I have observed are usually >90 unobstructed, there are a few noteworthy exceptions.

properties.description:
We had a little over a half-inch of rain (0.58) in the past week, however, the soil has dried out considerably. Soil moisture levels are now at or slightly below normal. We will need to start watering if we do not get rain in the next few days. There is a chance a tropical storm may go through but we would rather it just stay out to sea. The stream has stopped flowing into the pond and the water level in the pond is down about an inch from its normal state when full. Water is not flowing out of the pond. The water is slightly murky but there is no evidence of algae buildup. There are some fresh racoon footprints in the mud by the pond but no deer foot prints were noticed this week. We did not see the wood ducks nor the blue heron that had frequented the pond in previous weeks. The grass is continuing to grow and the plants and trees seem to be doing OK but with less vigorous growth than previously noted. No evidence of stress was noticed.

At 4:30 PM today, I made the following creek side observations near the baseball park. The air was 86 in the shade, relative humidity 40%, topsoil 70 on the creek bank. I tossed several different objects (leaf, pine cone, stick, twig)in the water at the same time and at different times and used a stopwatch to count how many seconds the objects took to float down the 20 foot length of a yellow floating nylon line that I tossed in the creek. Different size items took different trajectories and slightly different velocities, but all floated on the surface less than 1 knot downstream toward the east in very laminar motion without turbulence. The creek was approximately 15 feet wide here. The shallow water appeared a dull red/brick hue in the shade and an olive green color slightly downstream in the sunlight with greenery on both sides of the creek. I encountered some  green poisonous tri-foilate plants/vines and a few small biting insects.

properties.description:
In an area shaded by sweetgum trees (Liquidambar sp.) nearby an ephemeral ditch and a paved asphalt road, I performed 25 over -the-shoulder to the rear (blinded) tosses of a 50 square inch hollow ring. The average number of gumballs within the ring per toss was 1.75. Other plant life in this vicinity included pine cones, pine straw, vines, weeds, and grasses. I overturned a large (> 100 cubic inches) grey colored stone from the ground. The underside was moist and the topside was dry. Underneath the rock I saw: one light colored multi legged caterpillar/millipede type bug; more than 4 long earthworms in motion; more than 20 tiny white worms (larvae/pupae) in motion; a spider web; and more organic objects that were left undisturbed without closer examination. Upon returning home, I removed one adult lone star tick that was crawling along my neck/shoulder. The clear water in the ditch at that time was barely trickling towards a larger stream. edit::At 3 PM today at a small pond in an upscale residential community named “Crossings Park” N 35.799 W 078.845, the water appeared different hues of green (green yellow, granny smith green, forest green, green) with smooth distinct surface color demarcation lines and green moss/algae descending inches below the surface into the water column. The area has had a “barnyard animal” odor during night and day this week. I observed one turtle treading water at the surface here. Beaufort scale 0 at that time.

This year has started out as a very mild year and April and May seem to have had not a big gully washer like rain out here but slow moderate rain a lot of days. It has kept the pollen down a lot on the days it rains but the cloud cover seems to have slowed down agricultural type things... it makes for construction down Hwy 17 in Chesapeake (4 lane highway widening for easy access from Interstate 64 to the North Carolina Boarder). It is also making Dismal Swamp Area very much like a swamp. 

The Agriculture is slowed down because of the tractors are getting stuck in the mud. The farmers got feilds prepared, but it does not look like they got many planted. Even gardening at home for people has be hampered as the temps have stayed also between 50-60. 

Our personal garden is growing a few things. Plants are small yet but the peas have started to produce. 

Plants like Blueberries are just starting to put on leaves.

There must have been some days in Early April that the sunshine was out (but I can not recall exactly ) because our peach tree and plum tree have loads of peaches (planted 3.5 years ago so this is their forth spring and summer here at the house so the first year we have let the produce.

Weeds, that is what is growing in everyone's yard.

Have seen some wild life like deer and other critters out some. Along with all the birds at times.

Well, hopefully this jet stream change and el nina will bring something good.

properties.description:
At 4 PM in an immature pine forest running perpendicular to Morrisville Carpenter Rd and parallel to Leafy Creek Rd, I observed a stagnant ephemeral drainage ditch that is connected to a mostly dry circular ephemeral drainage pond to the north.  The ditch runs from north to south and measured 6 feet wide and 6 inches deep at one point. The ditch is surrounded by immature pine trees in various states of health and growth. Many are leaning or fallen with brown and green needles. Some maple trees were also seen. The ground is covered mostly in brown pine needles. The trees were affected by the wind (swaying/rustling) but the water at a lower elevation than the trees and ground was stagnant without any signs of recent flow or sediment disturbances. The water itself was clear enough to see the sandy bottom in most places that were devoid of growing green grass/algae/weeds. We had a brief rain shower this afternoon, which was heavy at times. There was green moss growing on the creek bank and hundreds of unclassified small waterborne and airborne insects in continuous motion and/or stirred into motion as we approached. There were isolated patches of darker green algal mats that were growing on the surface on down lower through the water column. The surface water temperature was 63°F, air temperature at eye level after 15 minutes was 69°F in the shade and relative humidity ~50%. I heard a mourning dove calling and other songbirds. Along the city block adjacent to the stagnant ditch I saw 5 or more attractive 2 story high residential homes for sale.  I sneezed about 8 consecutive times as we walked away.

properties.description:
Rain rain and more rain. The grounds squishes when I walk. But the gardens are flourishing. Farmers are having a hard time getting crops in the ground. Cool nights is not the best for tobacco. Hummingbirds have arrived and enjoying my feeders. Several interesting visitors have been at the feeders along with the usual residents. An assortment of butterflies are enjoying the beautiful spring flowers. It was exciting to see 4 baby turkeys on the roadside yesterday and today. fishing must be good on the lake as many boat trailers are at the marina. Campsites are filling up, much activity at the lake convenience store and restaurant. Lake level has been pretty consistent around 410.5' but almost reached 411' in early May. Cool weather has been great for the utility bills with highs below the average of low 80's. But according to forecasts that should change in the coming week with highs above average. Summer is just around the corner.

properties.description:
Location: N 35° 48.909’ W 078° 51.274’ at 2 PM I was near the leeward shore of a private lake with access restricted to residents. (could not make detailed water observations at the lake). After 15 minutes, the temperature measured 73° and relative humidity ~50% at eye level in the shade. The lake was at a decreased elevation relative to the highway and surrounded by residences and mature trees. Beaufort scale 1 at lake level. Plants included pines trees, maple trees and vines with hundreds of tiny spherical green berries in clusters on the distal 3 to 4 inches of the vines. I observed some cardinals in flight, but no migratory waterfowl near the lake today. Under those conditions from that distance, the water level appeared within normal limits and colored similar to Crayola “olive green”. While walking from east towards west near the woods edge at 5 PM, I performed 36 ring tosses with an 8” inner diameter ring aimed at the spherical light colored flowers of clovers and counted the flowers within the inner circle. Some of the flower stems were > 4 inches tall and some were barely off the ground. The average number of clover flowers per toss was 8, standard deviation 6, maximum 24 and minimum 0. I observed a number of honey bees, bumblebees, moth/butterfly, and gnats airborne among the clovers.

The creek measured 18 feet wide and was flowing towards the southeast with surface velocity of less than one knot. The water color appeared a "burnt sienna" color. After 15 minutes, the eye level air temperature was 61 degrees and humidity measured >50% <100%. Observed a small luminescent blue dragonfly perched on a twig. Measured a mature tree rooted on the right bank and growing toward the left bank over the creek. Eye level circumference measured 13 inches and the tree was covered with vines. THe ground was nearly 100% covered in green grasses and other plants. I saw a few (<10) small flying insects inches above the water surface.  A turkey vulture flew slowly overhead and a smaller grey/white bird was in fast antagonistic pursuit of a larger crow or blackbird.

properties.description:
This week began wet with 1.29" of rain in 2 days and ended with 3 dry days. The dry weather made it easier to work in the garden and mow the grass. Late spring wildflowers are blooming, including solomon's seal, solomon's plume, and doll's eyes. Fringe trees are still beautiful covered with white tassels. The wildlife camera showed the coyotes losing their gray, heavy winter coat for the sleek reddish coat of summer. The creek remains high, so the microhydro is on full. The drinking spring is a constant excellent quality and quantity. Thru hikers on the Appalachian Trail continue to pass through the nearby town of Hot Springs. Rafters are out, especially on the weekends.

properties.description:
TWO WEEK REPORT: May 2 thru May 15:
Normal.  We have been up and down on dry to wet.  Mostly, we have not received as much precipitation as was forecasted.  We have had to water young ornamentals and vegetables.
AGRICULTURE:  Corn is mostly being grown in this vicinity and is doing well. // Tree farming has concluded the thinning and lumbering they have been undertaking//
BUSINESS:  NA // ENGERY:  The temperatures have been in the upper 80's, and lower 90's so A/C units have been utilized ( tonight it is going down to 46 ° ) FIRE: the Forestry Service has "HIGH" risk on their roadside signage // PLANTS: most of the plants that were damaged by the freeze of late March are recovering - some are even blooming - about 4 weeks later than they should have / Vegetables are suffering from not having had a mid-70's temperatures for early growth - tomatoes are blotchy due to temperature swings and beets are suffering from being too hot//  WILDLIFE: Wild Turkeys are nesting now. Displaced forest wildlife continues to show up in our yard from the recent forestry work / RELIEF:  NA //  SOCIETY : Pollen Alerts, but fewer are suffering now it seems / TOURISM : no impact - weather has not been inclement
WATER SUPPLY:  River Levels seem normal ( and we are boaters)

properties.description:
Some agriculture observed today in walking distance included more than 6 miniature horses (possibly Shetland ponies), hundreds of acres of freshly cut grassy cover crop, a bee hive, and some farm ponds with water. I saw two Canada geese grazing on the sidewalk near the Cornerstone Shopping Center near High House Road. At 7 PM today, I measured a local creek to be 15 feet wide at the water level by tossing a nylon line to the other side. The surface water temperature was  72 F. The area was completely shaded from direct sun by decreased elevation, mature pine trees, and other plant shrubbery and trees. The creek bank was also sheltered from most of the wind by the same factors. After 15 minutes, the air temperature measured 6 feet above ground was 77 F. I submerged a kitchen strainer for 4 minutes and caught some specks and two larger aggregates measuring 1/2 inch by 1/4 inch. They were opaque brown colors but unidentifiable without magnification. A swarm of gnats was airborne several feet above the water surface. One insect briefly touched the water surface and left a circular ripple. Songbirds and Canada geese could be heard in the vicinity at that time. A very brief light rain shower started around 7:15 but did not persist for long. Some bumblebees were observed on the edge of the field flying around the manicured shrubs and honeysuckle.

Soil moisture levels are above normal now after receiving almost 3 1/2 inches of rain in the past week (3.46 to be exact) most all of it in the form of afternoon thunderstorms. The yard is very soft and muddy and it is not possible to walk in the low-lying parts without tracking mud on your shoes. The rain was good news for the grass and other plants which were suffering from a lack of water but have now resumed vigorous growth. The creek is flowing again and while the water is not clear, it has a somewhat murky appearance, it is better than in previous weeks. Unfortunately there are still some blooms of algae visible and while comparatively small, they will no doubt continue to grow in the warm weather. There are some small polliwogs in the creek and pond. The wood ducks, great blue heron and other birds continue their regular visits. The soft ground in the backyard did not show any fresh deer tracks today.

This afternoon I made a brief survey of a standing stagnant roadside puddle in the shape of longstanding tire rut. The water was 70 degrees in the shade of dusk and two inches deep in the center. The rut was ~9 feet long and 15 inches wide at the widest. I picked up a representative small 2-inch-long narrow leaf from the bottom. The leaf was green on the underside. The top side was covered in fine/fuzzy appearing rust colored silt but green underneath the thin layer that was easily rubbed off. I did not see any animal movement in the puddle but did observe a few airborne unclassified unrecognized very small flying insects less than six inches above the surface. At a nearby small water body (it ranges from dry to flooded throughout the year and is approximately the size of a Jacuzzi or small swimming pool) I observed a hen/drake pair of wild mallard ducks that flew away as I walked toward them. Yesterday in the daylight I observed ~ 8 bright white fragrant water lilies in this pond that from a distance resemble one of the Nymphaea sp. This evening in the shade of dusk the white flowers had resumed a tighter bud shape among the large green lily pads.  The stagnant water is fed, in part, by runoff from the mall parking lot. The side of the pond nearest the mall parking lot is buttressed by grey colored decorative cinderblocks measuring about 11 inches tall and stacked up to 8 blocks high (>6 feet, not including mortar, from the water surface to the curbside motor vehicle surface).

I pulled three representative clusters of pine needles from a tree near the sidewalk eye level. Cluster #1 needles were 3 @ 7 inches long. One needle was forest green all 7 inches and the other two in this cluster were tan colored the distal 2 inches. Cluster #2 were two 7 inch and one 5 inch needle. One 7 inch needle was forest green all the way, and the two others were tan colored on the distal inches. Cluster #3 were all 7.5 inches long. One was all forest green and the other two were tan the distal 3.5 inches. Following today's thunderstorm, I submerged a wire mesh kitchen strainer in the ditch for 120 seconds. The ditch was ~ 7 inches deep and the water appeared muddy. Every square inch of the mesh had some particulate matter on it after 2 minutes. Items included short grass clippings, tan pine straw fragments, small 1/2 inch green leaves and a larger 2 inch yellow leaf. The matter had a distinct earthy smell and was filled with smaller unclassified debris resembling roots or husks but nothing that was moving (insects, worms, etc.) was captured. The ditch was about 20 inches wide at that point and nothing was visible floating on the surface at that spot during that two minutes (all beneath the shallow surface). An adult red shouldered hawk perched on a low bare pine limb in the back yard and screeched loudly for a few minutes and then flew away just following the storm.

properties.categories: Plants And Wildlife,Water Supply And Quality
properties.description:
A series of thunderstorms passed through yesterday giving us some much needed rainfall although some locations suffered from wind and hail damage. We had been watering the flower gardens to keep them growing as it had been almost a week since the last rain. We received 0.83 inches of rain from the storms which served to moisten the soil and promote the growth of the flowers in addition to the yard itself. The main beneficiary of the rain was the creek in our backyard which had become stagnant and was suffering from a buildup of unsightly and toxic cyanobacteria algae. The rain apparently flushed the algae blooms away and the appearance of the creek has returned to a more normal state. The water remains somewhat murky and while a few frogs were seen, there was no evidence of the small fish that were so prevalent earlier in the year. The algae may have been too much for them. Prior to the storms the creek had ceased to bring fresh water into the pond, however, that flow has been restored. The pond remained full all week and even before the storms there was an outflow observed. The snapping turtles are taking up all the room on the logs in the water. The great blue heron is seen each day so the fishing must be good. We have Canadian geese in the mornings but they depart about mid-day. Some deer tracks were again observed in the backyard. All the vegetation is growing vigorously.

properties.categories: Plants And Wildlife,Water Supply And Quality
properties.description:
Dense green vegetative underbrush is increasing in the woods, requiring more careful observation than in cooler months when the ground is more bare and visibility is much higher. Have seen two adult snake skins that have been shed and one juvenile snake in the shade between planks in the wooden bridge. At creek-side today, in a shaded spot, the surface water was 73 degrees. There was heavy concentrations (estimated more than 10 floating particles per square foot in  midstream and much fewer or no particles closer to the creek banks)floating white colored snowflake size particles flowing downstream as well as suspended and moving in the atmosphere at visible levels. Heavy accumulation in a thick layer of this matter was observed stagnant in a sharp bend downstream in the creek. I observed a new spider web spun in circular orb fashion about 8 inches above the creek surface. The web was more on a horizontal plane than the customary vertical plane. The slender spider(thoracic segment and leg span was much greater in length than width) did not have any prey in the web. However, I counted eight pieces of the white particulate caught in the web. I observed another "water spider" skimming the water surface nearby. I submerged a clean coffee filter for 120 seconds and captured hundreds of opaque dull green irregular shaped particles that were visible with a magnifier but only cast a faint dull color on the wet filter without use of magnification. The bottom substrate of the creek was clearly visible in sunlight several inches below the surface. Velocity of water flow was obviously higher over the rocky shallow riffles than in the deeper shaded area where the observations were taken today.

properties.description:
It's been dry. We were away a couple weeks and found .91" of rain in the gauge. In the past week we've had .72" over 2 days. The dryness, combined with wind, have pushed a wildfire to over 3000 acres. A couple days ago the fire jumped the U.S. highway into Hot Springs closing the major highway for over 12 hours. The Appalachian Trail from Hot Springs to Allen Gap is closed due to the still active fire and risk of falling snags. Hikers are piling up in Hot Springs and shuttles around the fire zone are being offered for those who want to keep going. Meanwhile, spring is greening up everything with a profusion of wildflowers, returning warblers, scarlet tanagers, and "our" broad-winged hawks. The wildlife camera recorded coyotes, bear, bobcat, and raccoon wandering through. The early garden is thriving and the soil is moist about 2" under. Despite the dryness, our stream is still supplying the hydro with enough water to run on low. The spring remains at excellent quality and quantity.

properties.description:
Since Feb. 26th we have received only 2.85" of rain. that puts us at 4.50" below normal for 2016. Charlotte is at 4.32" below. this is the beginning of a moderate drought for us with March and April being two of our wettest months. Check NWS and NOAA ; They are predicting only a tenth of an inch this week the last of April. That would be over 5" below normal un less some of us get a thunderstorm in the western Piedmont of NC . Our Mt. and foothill areas are close to normal and the Coastal plain is much above. It's the western Piedmont that is really hurting. Yards are tuning brown and yellow, un irrigated fields are suffering, ponds are dropping to near 1/2 capacity and lakes, not fed by Mt. rivers are dropping also. Farmers are especially hurt. Salisbury is fed by the Yadkin/Pee Dee River and it's city water supply is good thanks to Mt. rains. Fire dangers are high and burning restrictions are in effect.

properties.description:
Observed the first small tick of the season on my skin and quickly brushed it off without inspection or measurements. Observed 20 to 50 Canada geese flying/honking at low altitude (streetlight level) this morning around sunrise (~6:30AM). On the creek bank around noon, I inspected a small clean coffee filter for cleanliness and then submerged it just below the water surface for 120 seconds. After 2 minutes, the filter did not show any particles large enough to be seen without magnification. Using a handheld magnifying glass, it was obvious that hundreds of small particles were caught by the filter. They were of an opaque green or brown color. The water temperature at that time was 64 F and the topsoil on the creek bank (21 inches vertically higher than the water) was 57 F. The area was shaded from sun at that time. The creek flow velocity was within normal limits and the bottom was visible in some locations several inches below the surface.

properties.description:
VERY DRY :  We will have to manually apply water to ornamentals, vegetables etc.  Wildlife is looking for water sources ( as our bees are as well )
** When the "storms" of Friday night / Saturday came through -we at this location - rec'd only .52 of an inch. Nearby ( we traveled ) within 6 miles, it rained for a least an hour.  All total all week was only .52 of an inch of precipitation.  That combined with HIGH WINDS and warm temperatures has caused quite a drying situation here.
AGRICULTURE:  CORN PLANTED in fields on our road, just as the Friday rains were starting ?? BUS-IND:  N/A   ENERGY:  A/C units on during the days, but no heating or a/c required in the night / FIRE - DANGER LEVEL IS HIGH // PLANTS:  Trees that lost their leaves from freeze conditions a week or so ago, have NOT recovered as of yet / BLOSSOMING NOW: Red Crimson Clover; White Clover; some dandelions; some azaleas; Poplar NOT blooming here; Other types of hollies ( other than Nellie R STevens ) have not blossomed as of yet.
OUR BEES: are suffering from the loss of forage - thankfully, the clover has begun to rebound from the freeze and is blooming.
WILDLIFE:  The tree farming operation has begun thinning in our area - that, on top of the clear-cutting done a year ago, has the TURKEYS, OPPOSUMS, and all other woodland critters scrambling for food and shelter.  Our property, and adjacent properties provide a small refuge. With Farm fields just recently tilled ( and planted ), there is virtually no forage areas readily available that are not already occupied by resident wildlife.
RELIEF RESPONSE:  N/a  // SOCIETY and PUBLIC HEALTH:  Smoke Alerts from two area wildfires has been in the news - and the pollen count ( OAK ) remained high this past week./// TOURISM:  nearby historical town is full of tourists / RECREATION:  Boating - a bit difficult with high winds
WATER SUPPLY :  Rivers are actually a bit on the low side, but with wind-driven tides, it is sometimes difficult to realize that they are, in fact, a bit low

properties.description:
Weekly Report: moderately dry ( approaching very dry )
With only 3/4 of an inch of rain over the past week; very windy conditions, cold nights, sunny days - everything that was wet, is very quickly drying out.
Conversations with other gardeners brings the topic of "could be a drought year" to the forefront quickly.  Everyone who has crops/gardens is watering already.
AGRICULTURE: field prep continues, but has slackened off.  No planting has begun. Temperatures rurally at night are dropping into the mid-30°s range. //
BUSINESS / INDUSTRY: Logging has begun again in earnest. Smaller diameter trees are being cleared as well.
ENERGY: Cold temperatures at night, and the significant winds have kept the need for a/c units to a minimum - if at all.  Overnight heating is probable for most, but for short periods.
FIRE: HIGH RISK warnings announced on local media.
PLANTS:  The plants that suffered freeze damage last week, have not begun to recover as of yet. High winds prevent planting small starter vegetable plants.
WILDLIFE: Abundance of birds ( turkeys, hawks, buzzards, doves, mockingbirds, kill-deer, hummingbirds, barn swallows, canary and house finch, wren, cardinals, blue birds. (Still no sign of the mating pair of blue jays from last year.)
RELIEF RESPONSE: N/A 
SOCIETY and PUBLIC HEALTH: pollen alerts continue
TOURISM and RECREATION: either no impact or a positive one
WATER:  River levels are high now, but from wind driven tides ./ rainfall has been minimal so without the wind, it might be lower than normal.
GROUND SURFACE is drying quickly.  Ditches that held water at the beginning of the week are just slightly damp on the bottoms, and completely dry on the sides.
The planted red & white clovers are recovering from the freezes and beginning to blossom.  Our honeybees, and other pollinators are foraging on these, and other ornamentals we have planted such as verbena and "red-tips".  Peonies are about to bloom which wasps and bumble bees will enjoy.

Ground moisture levels are normal. We have had a total of .73 inches of rain in the past week and a total of .93 inches over the past two weeks so things are drying out nicely. There are only a few soggy areas in our yard. The grass and plants are growing well. Almost all the leaf buds on the trees have broken open and we are now starting to see the summer flowers leafing out. Most of the trees are developing larger leaves. The stream is clear and flowing. The pond is also full and we have seen a re-appearance of the cyanobacteria algae blooms over the past two days. This does not seem to bother the wood ducks nor the great blue heron who are regular occupants of the pond. We have numerous deer prints in the back yard along with raccoon prints by the water's edge. We had a possum wander through the yard last evening.

properties.description:
What a spring, or whatever these past few weeks should be called. Locally we've gone from shorts and t-shirt to almost needing a winter coat. On April 9 we experienced a day of terrific winds. No damage but the wind chill was very uncomfortable. So far no damage to flowering plants during the freezing night temperatures. A fire warning was issued due to low humidity and winds. Birds are very active, butterflies abound, leaves getting larger every day. Due to recent rains the lake continues to be muddy in some areas. The level is 410.35'. It has been up and down some but is remaining fairly steady.  Fishing must be biting as there are always boats in the water, customers at the nearby convenience store and campers at the recreation area. Fields have been plowed even though there is still some standing water. We're just waiting until after the supposedly last frost date to plant. Maybe spring is truly just around the corner.

One forsythia bush has flowered but very little other colors of spring were seen in the area.

The cool weather garden plants are all up and growing. Our spring remains excellent quality and quantity.

properties.description:
The 1.19 inches of rain over the past 8 days leaves the ground with just slightly more than normal moisture levels. The soil is firm but not muddy. Grass, flowers and trees are all growing vigorously. Most of the trees have opening leaves and the pollen releases are noticed everywhere. The creek is full and while it had some algae blooms visible during the week, today they seem to have cleared up. The water color is slightly darker than usual. A steady flow of water is keeping the small fish happy. The pond is full and clear. We continue to see Canada geese on the pond along with the wood ducks. The great blue heron makes daily visits. Other small streams in the area that had noticeable algae earlier in the week are now flowing clear. Apparently recent rains and/or changes in temperature have all but eliminated what was unsightly blooms. Fresh deer tracks are still visible in our backyard.
