properties.description:
Weekly Report:
Very much "MIDDLE" of the ground soil wetness at this time. Precipitation over the past 7 days was just under 1/2 inch; and in 8 days it was just under 3/4 of an inch.
Not much considering that most of the week had a lot of sun; and a lot of wind.  A lot of drying went on. So, even the precip. that fell although beneficial, did not give plants a good drenching.
AGRICULTURE: fields have been disked and sit ready to plant.
Near to freeze temperatures are anticipated for three days out of the upcoming 8; so it is likely planting might be delayed especially for gardeners.
BUS.& INDUSTRY:  No weather related impacts known.
ENERGY: It has mostly been a period of time that neither the a/c or heating units needed to be running.
FIRE: Although the threat level might be low, the winds have been significant enough that if a fire got started, it had fuel to burn.
PLANTS:  It seems an accelerated Spring.  Most plants seem to be about 10 to 14 days 'ahead of schedule'; or quickly going through their bloom periods.
BLOOMING  NOW:  Azaleas, Forsythia, Carolina Jessamin, Crab Apple trees, Daffodils, Dandelions, Petunias, Gardenias, Clovers are starting with many blooming
LEAFING OUT:  a lot of trees and plants are beginning to leaf out  ( including vitex, crepe myrtles, sweet gum, roses )
POLLEN:  The pollen level warning remain HIGH - but the dreaded PINE POLLEN has ended this week.
Ended or Ending: dead nettle, henbit, society garlic, 
WILDLIFE:  Turkeys are foraging, squirrels are more noticeable, 
BIRDS: hummingbirds, common house finch, chickadees, wrens, cardinals, mourning doves, cow birds, hawks, mockingbirds, kill-deer, robins(not a large population)
NOT YET HERE: blue jays, barn swallows, canary finch
RELIEF:  N/A
SOCIETY: Pollen Alerts continue from last week in to this upcoming week. Near freeze temperatures are anticipated this upcoming week.
TOURISM/RECREATION: Forecasts had warned of severe weather at the end of the week.  Although there was rain and slight wind, there was no severity ( thank goodness)
WATER LEVELS in the area rivers remains on the high side, but no flooding issues are known
WATER SUPPLY & QUALITY:  no weather or climate related impacts are known

properties.description:
This afternoon I took measurements of a typical "long legged" mosquito that at the time was perched stationary on an exterior residential wall. The mosquito did not take flight during the measurements. The wingspan was slightly more than 2 inches and the distance between the most anterior leg segment and most posterior leg segment was more than 3 inches. I submerged a 4 cup sized paper coffee filter suspended with a kitchen strainer in the creek again for 120 seconds, this time I observed (without magnification)5 to 10 small dark particles resembling splinters. The most conspicuous fragment measured approximately 1/16 inch long. The vertical distance between the water and the walking surface of the bridge was 7 to 8 feet this afternoon and the bottom was visible. At this location during periods of heavy rain at 9 AM, there were several areas of standing water more than one inch deep. This afternoon, most of the puddles have evaporated.

properties.description:
This afternoon, at a location along the creek bank just downstream of a bridge that is light colored sand, I used a metallic kitchen mesh strainer (diameter ~8 inches) to collect a small sample scoop 1 to 2 inches below the surface. This area is frequently underwater, especially after a rain. Among the multi colored sand and small pebbles found in one scoop, I observed more than 8 (I stopped counting after 8)small, assumed living by the closed valves and color, bivalve mollusks (look like miniature clams). The longest lengths measured 4/16 to 5/16 inch. They had the typical concentric slightly different colored (shades of pale yellow/drab green)growth rings. Other material in the one scoop included dark colored tree/leaf fragments, and an aged acorn cup. I measured some pine seedlings on the fringe of the parking lot to be 5 to 8 inches tall with new vertical growth of 2  to 4 inches marked by a lighter green color trunk. I also observed several bumblebees in flight and a few mosquitoes.

The month of March has been a very dry month as far as precipitation goes. My total rainfall so far this month has been 2.24" Normal rainfall for the month of March for this area is 4.17"  Yesterday afternoon into yesterday evening we had a decent rainfall with the most rainfall that has fallen all month long in a day at 0.61" Yesterday's rainfall was a good steady rainfall for a few hours. I would have thought that the rain would have wet the soil around here somewhat, but I noticed in the garden dirt at work in Augusta only the top quarter of inch of soil was wet, after this quarter of an inch the dirt soil was completely dry.  Here in my backyard in North Augusta, the clay soil has large cracks in it despite the rainfall yesterday.  My husband mowed the grass tonight and again despite the heavy rain yesterday, the mowing stirred up quite the dust storm.  The drier weather has been welcomed to bring the river level down.  The current river level is at 99.13 feet.  The highest height that the river has been this month has been around 105ft.  Since the river has gone down, there are areas now with rocks exposed that have been underwater since the Flood on January 1st.  The once muddy flood waters in January, have now become much clearer, & the water color is now more of a green color which is much prettier compared to the chocolate brown color caused by the flood waters. Rain is in the forecast for Thursday, which is the last day of the month, but with current QPF forecasted, i don't see the area making normal rainfall this month. One other note for this month. The pollen started on March 13th.  The pollen was so thick on some days the week of March 14th-18th you could see a yellow smoggy haze in the afternoon sky.  Thankfully we did get some rainfall to wash the pollen away on March 19th.  0.01" of pollen collected on top of the water that was collected during the rain that night in the gage.  Since then, the pollen has not been as thick, but it is still collecting on the cars and after yesterday's rain you can see where the pollen collected in puddles and is now all dried up.  Let's hope that April showers will bring our rainfall deficit down and completely was away all of the pollen.

properties.description:
With only a trace of rain over the past two weeks, the ground has dried out considerably. The flower gardens are well munlched and are still moist below the surface. The spring grass is growing well but any bare spots show dry, dusty soil on the surface. Some grass seed that was sown three weeks ago has not yet sprouted due to the dry conditions. Trees are beginning to leaf out with most of them showing buds, seeds and/or flowering stages.
The creek is still flowing although the rate would be better described as a trickle. The big news is the flourishing of long threads of green algae in the stream and pond. The same algae are also prevalent in other small streams in the area. Every one of the small streams observed this week have displayed these same algae blooms and I have traveled as far as 25 miles away. This must be the result of well-fertilized lawns and a lack of fresh water to increase water flows. The same green algae has formed clumps on the surface of the pond which move with the winds.
We continue to see wild animals including the white tailed deer moving across our yard. The great blue heron and wood ducks are seen each day on the pond. Other birds are working their way through the food from the feeders in our yard.

properties.description:
Most of this week has been dry and warm--up to 79.7°--mostly in the mid-70's. Despite the dryness the soil is moist. I planted cool-loving lettuce, spinach, kale, & peas into the damp ground. The first spring wildflower, sharp-lobed hepatica, bloomed on Mar. 12. Buds are swelling. Other early wildflowers are in bud. Our honeybees are very active and bringing in pollen. The red maples must be in bloom. The dawn chorus of birds is getting more varied with robins, song sparrows, tufted titmice, Carolina chickadees, and cardinals. I noted the eastern phoebe's return on Mar. 6. The majority of the wood frog tadpoles emerged from their eggs this week making certain curves of the pond look like wiggling black masses. The first wave Appalachian Trail thru-hikers arrived in Hot Springs, along with spring break hikers and boaters--all enjoying the warm weather. Yesterday some widely scattered rain showers moved through giving us .25" of rain. The hydro turbine continues to run on full and the drinking spring remain excellent in quality & quantity.

This is for one week ( sorry - had to take down the rain gauge so it would not freeze and crack )
The conditions remain abnormally wet for this time of year; regardless of winds, which do dry things.  There is standing water in the roadside ditches and the topsoil remains soft.
Over the past couple of weeks - nothing really has been getting done agriculturally on a local level
Tornadoes in the area mid week last week caused schools and businesses to close early.  Immediate area had little impact from the high winds ( some branches down, little else) nearby tornadoes did do damage
Plants are beginning to bloom - some a little prematurely - but near to being on schedule ( blueberries / dandelions / candy tuft / popcorn spirea / a little showing on vibernum/ daffodils and hyacinths - bloom one day / frost the next so they keep coming and going 
Water levels in area rivers remain high, although locally being wind driven - there are times when the 'mud flats' show up.
Overall, life and business proceed without the impact of weather, with the exception of the "tornado threat day" last week.

Hang around a few minutes and the weather will change. One weekend it's snow, then next break out the shorts. Once constant is moisture. Hyco Lake reached a peak for 410.9' and now has slightly settled down to 410.48' but the cove in front of the house is still very clay-colored. But fishing activity on the lake is very high and lots of business at the marina and restaurant. On cold days bird activity is high but on other days not so much. Daffodils are in bloom, other plants are budding but the garden and fields cannot be worked. There is standing water everywhere with more rain predicted this week. Moderate temperatures mean less heat needed but not quite warm enough for open windows. Snow moon is tonight but spring will be here soon.142

Drought Impact Data: 
StartDate: 2016-02-22
EndDate: NA
Is Condition Monitoring Report
Categories:

Wildlife observed in the last 24 hours include: 8 floating/walking geese, 2 floating ducks (buffleheads or hooded mergansers), 2 gulls in flight, one turkey vulture in flight, one large great blue heron in flight, and a dove at ground level. Observed the skeletal remains of an animal approximately 6 feet from the creek bank earlier in 2016. Closer skeletal measurements today include: 9" long spinal column; 5" long and 3" wide head (skull); longest leg 10" long separated about halfway with a (knee like) flexible joint; a paw with knuckle joints. Brief examination of the skull showed 3 small posterior molar teeth, 2 longer anterior (fang like) teeth, and numerous missing sockets where the anterior most incisor teeth should be. There was no flesh, insects, odors, or unusual observations near the site. A local gallon of gas was recently observed at $1.79 9/10. A campfire site was observed on the shore of a pond today with recent burning debris including a partially burnt (edit 2/20: partially charred with some green needles and some burnt portions on the tree) Christmas tree and more than 20 empty beverage containers. Some large stones that encircled the campfire fire site in the wooded area were overturned and numerous living crawling insects were observed in the damp soil beneath the rocks. (crickets?)

properties.description:
The ground is slightly wetter than normal. We had 1.19 inches of rain four days ago and there are still some muddy areas in the low-lying parts of the yard. Even where the ground is relatively solid, it is still moist and there are no dry spots. The stream is flowing with very clear water and the pond is full. Vegetation appears to be dealing with February weather quite well. Some early flowers are sending up leaf shoots and the grass in the yard is green. No leaf buds have been observed yet. We have white tailed deer going through the yard several times each day. A fox wandered through the yard at mid-day a few days ago. The great blue heron, kingfishers, and ducks are frequently seen on the pond.

properties.description:
This week could summed up in a word: snow! Although we've only had .86" of water equivalent--it's been dry, fluffy snow--we've had 19.6" of snow. The snowstorm that blew through here on Feb. 9 dumped 16" of snow on us. That was a county high (probably a state high) for amount of snow! Meanwhile the temps have only been slightly above freezing on two days. The lowest temp of the week was last night at 9.6°. When the snow arrived, so did the purple finches and the pine siskins. The hungry birds have been eating a lot of sunflower seeds and suet. Our hydro continues to generate on full. Our drinking spring remains excellent quality and quantity.

properties.description:
Ground moisture levels have returned to normal. The rain events we experienced a week ago left the ground very wet but the effects of it have largely disappeared by today. The ground is no longer soggy and difficult to walk on. It has firmed up and while still moist, it will not stick to shoes. The grass is growing (slowly) and we have clumps of early spring flowers shooting up. Despite the cold weather, the daffodils are about 4 inches high. The deer continue to find enough to eat and walk through the yard on a regular basis. A kingfisher has joined the great blue heron and both seem to find food in the pond. The stream is flowing clear and strong. Small fish and tadpoles are visible in the stream. Both the pond and stream are full and while water is flowing from the spillway on the pond, it is a measured flow rate, much reduced from last week.

properties.description:
We've had a lot of rain in the past week (4.78 inches total) which ensures the ground has more moisture than normal. It is much wetter than normal with some areas of the yard so soft we cannot walk through them. Even higher areas are very soft and muddy. Daffodils have sprouted in the garden in anticipation of the coming spring. The deer tracks in the back yard are very deep because the ground is so soft. The creek is flowing clear and has a steady flow of water through it. Numerous small fish are visible in the stream along with quite a few fat tadpoles in the water. The pond is also full and it is slightly muddy colored from the water flowing in. The ducks and great blue heron are regular visitors. We are also seeing an abundance of birds of all types at our feeders in the backyard. A downy woodpecker has been hanging on the suet feeder each morning. Squirrels continue to find ways to defeat the guards intended to keep them out of the feeders.

properties.description:
weekly report:  WET
Factually, we have not had much precipitation in the past 7 days; however, the last day of the prior report had over 2.5 inches, so the conditions remain wet.
There was a front that moved through on Thursday, and was anticipated to bring significant accumulation - however, it turned out to be a drizzly sort of event, cold and damp.
Temperatures remained JUST above freezing, which was good in that black ice was not an issue in the area ( which it can be at this time of year )
Agriculture: infrequently, some farmers are clearing brush around their fields
Bus & Ind.  nothing impacted or unusual
Energy: temperatures are down more than they were, so heating systems are being used more 
Fire: threat remains low; although the winds have been quite high so if something got going - it could present a hazard
Plants & Wildlife:  Blooming: red maple, leather-leaf mahonnia, dandelions
Birds: cardinals, finches, mockingbirds, doves are the most frequently seen, ( along with buzzards of course)
Relief Response: none necc.
Society and Public Health: no concerns ( upper respiratory infections seem prevalent in the public at this time)
Tourism: nothing impacted THIS week
Water Supply and Quality: two local rivers remain high - but not causing flooding issues / roadside ditches and creeks all have water - either standing or moving slowly

properties.description:
Life came to a screeching halt on 1/22 when the snow began. As southerns we don't drive in the snow. Most stores closed and the few open had very little business, damage to their bottom lines. However on 1/21 the stores were full of shoppers, no bread or milk was left in town so hopefully that offset any losses. 5'75" snow with a little sleet fell. Fortunately during the height of the storm there were no accidents in the county. The lake level has slightly dropped to 410.41'. Birds have been extremely active with numbers too high to count at times. Outside of what I can see from the safe confines of my house,what I hear on the news or email exchanges I have no idea what is going on in the rest of the area. But my world is beautiful. But needless to say no outside gardening is being accomplished, only skimming through "dream books" aka seed catalogs.

A sleet and ice storm delivered just over an inch of precipitation two days ago. Below freezing temperatures have kept the ice on the ground and all trees and plants. Branches of the trees and bushes are bending under the weight of the ice. Many in the area are still without electricity. Very little traffic is moving but the main roads are now passable.
The pond is covered with ice. The creek is still open and water is flowing in it. There are small fish in the creek. Ducks and a lone great blue heron were seen where the creek enters the pond. Deer tracks are visible in the ice in the back yard. Many birds have been frequenting our bird feeders.

properties.description:
weekly report:  Remains exceptionally wet
Friday night saw the most precipitation all week; got near to 3 inches overnight, as the blizzard formed up and rolled on up the east coast;  we were fortunate as it never froze until late on Saturday, by then, the wind had dried most of the roadways and walkways.
Agriculture: nothing happening
Business & Industry: I'm sure it must have been impacted towards the latter part of the week; as everyone prepared for the blizzard ( Jonas ) that slipped by our west and went north.  We did see heavy rains.
Energy:  It got cold and windy, so I'm sure that heating systems were being used heavily.
Fire:  With the winds, anything that caught on fire would have been difficult to put out; however, surface is wet.
Plants and Wildlife:  Clover got frosted, so deer are foraging on other things; birds are at the feeders much more than previously - and the "cow birds" showed up on Saturday morning following the storm
Relief Response:  None was necessary here
Society & Public Health:  Schools were closed, and many businesses delayed openings on Friday as the storm ( and freezing rains - black ice possibilities ) approached
Tourism and Recreation :  A planned parade in our city was impacted on Saturday morning
Water supply and Quality: normal
Rivers are high due to rains and run-off

properties.description:
weekly report: WET.
We had two days over the last seven that had rain.  One day (Friday )  it started to rain about 2:15 till about 5:15.  In those three hours it poured at times - with an accumulation over the 3 hours of .79 inch.
The surface of our soil just doesn't get dried out in between the rains. Just when you think it might -- we get another front.
The temperatures have been moderate, but that is about to change.
That I have seen, nothing has been done agriculturally at this time.
Energy: moderate temperatures, have meant normal heating and/or air conditioning usage. 
Fire: it's wet. Fire hazard level must be low
Plants: Nothing extraordinary at the moment.  Last week's freezes stunted any premature blooming. Blooming ( normally ) plants include: leather-leaf mahonnia; red maple; dandelions.  There is evidence of hollies having made an attempt ( premature).
Bees are bringing in pollen - we are certain our queens are laying ( brood build up - dangerous time - more population eating reserve honey - we will feed )
Wildlife: It's rabbit hunting season, so we still have wildlife being run around by hunters and their dogs.
Relief: none necc.
Society & Public Health: Nothing extraordinary. Some talk of upper respiratory infections going around - primarily in school age children
Tourism & Recreation: Nothing should have been impacted by weather events EXCEPT If it happened to have been last Friday late afternoon / early evening.  In fact, we personally saw several vehicles that had hydroplaned off the highways.  It was raining - ponding water - and high winds.
Water Supply and Quality: no issues. Rivers ( two here ) remain high.  All ditches have standing water.  Beavers with their many dams are causing threatening issues with low lying roads and culverts.

At 9:30 AM at a point in Indian Creek near the roads named "Singer" and "Rope Walk", the surface water temperature was 46 degrees F. The creek flow was laminar and the water was two feet deep at the most. Sand and stones were readily visible on the bottom. It was about six feet across at that point. The month of December started out very dry and we ended up with flooding rains at the end of the month.  Total rainfall measured was 6.57" here in North Augusta where I live in the River North development.  Normal rainfall for the CSRA is 3.39"  The excess rainfall and runoff from rains elsewhere upstream flooded the Savannah river.  The river stayed around 112 ft throughout the month on December.  Heavy rains here and across the region upstream caused Lake Thurmond to reach a record level full pool of 336 ft.  On Thursday December 31st the flood gates were opened at the Thurmond Dam.  Water slowly creeped into the neighborhood all day and water started rising rapidly on December 31st.  We could see the 1st signs of the neighborhood flooding later New Years eve before midnight.  On New Years morning, we woke up to flooded roads in the neighborhood and some neighbors reported flooding in their basements anywhere from 2-4 ft. Water continued to rise during the day on New Years Day at a rate of one inch per hour.  We started measuring the water rise at 11:30pm and by 6pm almost one foot of water had risen throughout the neighborhood.  Roads flooded even more with this rapid water rise during the day.  Water flooded our backyard and slowly creeped it's way across the side of our yard and filled our driveway across the low spot.  Thankfully the water stopped just before reaching our basement garage. The river crest was 118.3ft.  Thankfully water went down on Saturday January 2nd. Roads in the neighborhood were now passable once the water went down on Jan 2nd.  Most houses that flooded are now drying out. There are only 2 houses that still have about 2 feet of water in their basement. The flood gates have been open at Thurmond Dam for over a week with the dam gates now coming to a close. Last I heard the flood gates will be completely shut on Monday 1/11/16.  The river has been running at flood stage all week long at 117.5 ft. This level should come down once the Dam flood gates have been shut.  Other areas that have been effected by the high river water here in the area are in North Augusta, river docks behind houses in the River club neighborhood collapsed, the Augusta riverfront marina has been closed due to being underwater, & the Augusta riverwalk has been closed as well due to being underwater.  We had our 1st rainfall of January today. 0.19" fell. This should not effect the river level too much.  One other note.....The Thurmond dam became a hot tourist spot to watch the flood waters go.  Many people went to the Dam and had their pictures taken with the rushing water coming out of the Dam in the background

Anoles have been running around.  Within the past couple of days, temperatures have cooled off and by week's end will be back to near normal and all of the flowers will freeze.  Fall crops have been amazing this year .  . . lettuce, kale, broccoli, and cauliflower.  The onions have not liked the wet weather.

properties.description:
We are well above normal levels of precipitation for this time of year. The many small streams coursing down the mountainsides are all full and are overflowing their banks at some points. Even the small gullies that are normally dry have water flowing down them. The larger streams and rivers in the area are responding to these increased inputs by increasing the speed of the water flowing down and are filling their banks. The result is a pleasant sound of gurgling water audible across the valley. The increased water flows has created some new channels as the water seeks to speed it's way down the mountain. The water has made local hiking trails somewhat treacherous with boots required for dry feet. Muddy places abound. The soft ground is good for finding animal footpirnts. Fresh deer tracks are found all across our property. The inputs of fresh water have apparently engaged the fish in the pond, several good sized ones were caught (and released) over the past few days.

People are staying in, and I have seen more then average ambulances out with full lights and sirens. I wonder if this weather and change in the barometric pressure is altering the pain from arthritis... in those moments of stiffness people fall and break hips and many other things. There is an interplay with bacteria, fungus, pain from arthritis, breathing, exercise and other things with health. The buildings we live in and their decay if not properly maintained or built to start with.

Glad this weather is not as cold as last year. But really nothing more to report.

properties.description:
Wildlife observed in the past few days include: over 100 geese, over 100 seagulls, 3 deer, 2 rabbits, a hawk, hundreds of earthworms, and one slug. While many trees have lost their leaves this fall, a number of local oak trees are still retaining many of their brown leaves intact on the trees. In observing the storm drain systems on the city streets, have noticed three styles of grates. Some have 20 diagonally situated openings, some have 32 vertical openings stacked in two rows perpendicular to the curb, and some are completely open with no hindrance to the water flow from the street. During the recent rain events, a number of street side grates have been noted to be slightly or completely obstructed with pine straw and/or leaves. When time permits, these obstructions are easily cleared with a stick or boot and immediate increase and redirection of curbside flow is observed. Other debris such as clothing items, plastic bottles and miscellaneous trash have been observed slightly obstructing the flow as well. In a small creek in wooded area this week observed hundreds of green weeds on the bottom of the water. At this location the water was 6 inch deep and 36 inch across. One weed measured 11 inch long stem with no leaves on the bottom 4.5 inch root and 14 small (1/4 to 1 inch) green leaves on the distal 2 inches of weed. The green leaves grew progressively smaller toward the tip of the plant. Implication for drought is that the creek/ditch located in this wooded area of lean and immature pines is sometimes dry, even in the absence of drought, so these aquatic weeds would not exist.

On Dec. 2 the French Broad River rose to 21,000 cfs! It's back down to 2900 cfs today. (Normal is about 2,000 cfs.) Then Dec. 4, 5, and 6 the temperatures dropped to the 20's°. Now the last three days have been extraordinarily warm in the upper 60s°. A black swallowtail chrysalis that is supposed to overwinter, instead emerged last week as a butterfly. But there is nothing to eat now. Sulfur butterflies have also been seen, maybe migrating through, but way too late. I have seen a few flowers, such as violets and phlox. Our honeybees are active, but I've not seen them on any flowers. Our wildlife cam revealed coyotes and a black bear on a cold night. Although it's been dry for the last nine days, the soil is moist. Foggy, dewy mornings help. Our drinking spring remains high quality and quantity.

properties.categories: Agriculture,Energy,Fire,Plants And Wildlife,Society And Public Health,Tourism And Recreation
properties.description:
weekly report:  The overall condition remains " moderately wet".  Even though we have not had that much precipitation, the ground surface is not drying out. Many areas remain "squishy" when walked upon; ditches retain water in the basins.
AGRICULUTRE: So, this week, much to this rural  neighborhood's surprise, a local farmer had contacted the correct folks and blew up a beaver dam.  It was quite an explosion; and the water running in and through the ditches towards the creek ( and ultimately the river ) was deep and swift flowing.
BEAVERS are beginning to be quite a problem in the immediate area. Their ponds, a result of their dams; are beginning to encroach upon more major roadways.  We suspect that more dam removal by explosion will be in the future.
These beaver dams also cause the water to stand in ditches; which over the course of the last summer, caused the mosquito population to be serious.
Other than that - agriculture in the immediate vicinity has not done anything over the past week.
LOGGING:  It seems that this is their season.  A LOT of logging is going on locally.  We have not seen any evidence of replanting the previous year's logging.  This is a concern for wind block / soil erosion and more. ( and of course, wildlife refuge )
ENERGY:  the temperatures swung widely this week - going from quite warm ( approaching hot.. upper 70's ) to quite cool ( highs not making it in to the 50'); so a/c and heaters were run, probably not in earnest, but still had to be run daily.
PLANTS: As of last week, some plants were blooming that otherwise would not have: Shasta daisy / daffodils are starting to show through the ground / roses are blooming / dandelions and a smattering of others.
WILDLIFE:  It is bear hunting season, so animals are sometimes seen moving around that might otherwise remain undetected.  ( the use dogs to hunt which scatters all critters)
The rain of this past week mostly was on one day, which if you had to be out would have been uncomfortable, but in no way would have impacted business.  It was mid-week, so outdoor events, normally scheduled on weekends, were not adversely impacted.
WATER LEVELS RIVERS: remain on the high side of normal
TOURISM:  We live near a tourist destination, and with the holidays, it is busier locally - but no weather event has impacted tourism.
Winds have been higher - which normally impacts Fire Danger- but the ground surface remains wet, so the fire danger level has remained low.

The beaver who recently moved into the neighborhood continues his night time construction. A small flock of mallard ducks has appeared on the pond and appears to be checking out the neighborhood. Falling leaves are posing a problem for the street drains, effectively clogging the drains and preventing rain from draining the streets leading to some minor flooding.

Still, our drain at the foot of the driveway remains active and has been for well over two months.  We don't remember a time in our 20 years here where that's happened.

properties.description:
Over three inches of rain in two days has had a real impact. All the streams are flowing vigorously and what are normally just ditches all have rivulets of water coursing down them. The water is clear. Small streams that have previously been dry are now flowing freely. The upper reaches of the  Watauga River are full to the upper limits of the banks on either side. Some minor flooding was observed today on the flat lands. The ground is very soft and any hike along a trail will result in picking up a lot of mud on ones shoes. A small herd of seven deer are patrolling our neighborhood and eating whatever vegetation remains down to ground level. Their feet leave indentations wherever they walk. Their coats are noticeably darker compared to what we saw only a few weeks ago. A flock of geese are gathering on the pond and today we heard the distinctive call of (but did not see) a pileated woodpecker in the woods. We did not see the ground hog today, perhaps he has already begun hibernation for the coming winter.

A dense fog is in the air now, and has been all day, thereby reducing visibility. The fog is denser now than it was in the daylight. Since fog is composed of moisture, in a drought, this phenomenon may be less likely to occur here. Over the weekend, in the dark, before dawn hours on two consecutive days, I observed groups of at least three adult deer in close proximity to the low metallic fence separating a golf course and the public road. The deer were apparently startled by my approaching flashlight and quickly ran. On one occasion the deer ran in circles and startled the great blue heron into screeching/grunting flight from the shallow waters where he/she has been seen standing in the morning.

properties.description:
Today we recorded 1.65" of rain and it's still raining. This rain followed 6 dry days. The French Broad River has climbed from about 2300 cfs to 7100 cfs. All creeks and rivers are roaring, including our little creek. The microhydro is on full (6 kwh per day). The wildlife camera shows coyotes and deer in their winter gray coats. They appear filled out and healthy. Our flower garden has tiny bulb leaf shoots coming out of the ground and a handful of phlox flowers--perhaps triggered by mild temperatures. It's interesting that animals don winter coats according to the season, while plants respond to temperature (that can get plants into trouble). Our drinking spring remains excellent quality and quantity.

properties.description:
We continue in the all or nothing weather pattern. 6" rain, a week of unseasonably warm and dry, 2" 15 days warm and dry and a quick 2 day cool down, and now 2+ precip again. In between the rain it has been alarming how quickly the streams and creeks go back to below normal levels. Birds are emptying the feeders quickly, and I am still seeing snakes, groundhogs and one bear sighting. We ate our thanksgiving dinner on the porch. sunsets and sunrises have been spectacular. Tourists are enjoying the warm dry spells for hiking and shopping. Farmers are shaking their heads! Most everyone has a sniffle- seasonal whiplash!

properties.description:
Moderately Wet:  Ground is still "squishy" from last week's precipitations.
Even with warmer than usual temps, and breezy days, the ground surface is not drying out quickly.  We suspect that is because since we have had our first frosts and freeze, the groundcover is no longer in a growing mode, so it is not absorbing the fluid.
AGRICULTURE:  last week, one of our two local farmers harvested his crop of soy JUST in time, before last week's rain.  The second farmer did the same this week -harvesting throughout the night over the weekend trying to beat the Monday morning rain - and did.
It is my understanding that some of the soy was already starting to develop some mold, and if it rained again - the crop would have been totally lost.
ENERGY:  Air Conditioners got put on during the middle of the day a couple of times over the past week - only to have all the heat or air conditioning systems off in the overnights.  
FIRE:  Breezy conditions would normally signal fire hazard, but as  previously stated, the ground surface is wet.   There is standing water in all roadside ditches.
The river levels remain on the high side - but not flooding.
PLANTS: Blooming.  The frost knocked down the marigolds, and some other late blooming flowers. Eleagnus, mahonnia, some camellias and dandelions are blooming sporadically.
The pepper plants got done in during the week with our first 29 degree night.
BIRDS:  The usual suspects still come to the feeders ( morning doves, cardinals, wrens, mockingbirds, common house finches ).  Crows, Hawks, Buzzards seem active lately.
It is hunting season ( rut ) so most other critters are laying low - and no evidence even of foxes is apparent.
The weekend weather was wonderful - so outdoor public events went off well.  No effect on tourism.

Total rainfall for the month of November was 3.55" here in North Augusta.  Normal rainfall total for the month of November is 2.83" The month started out rather wet, but then we had some nice dry fall like weather in the middle of the month. The dry weather was welcomed after we had drenching flooding rainfall at the start of October. Temperatures we comfortable & above normal most of the time throughout the month, with the exception of two nights after we had cold fronts pass with clear & frosty conditions.  We had our official first killing frost to end the growing season on Tuesday November 24th when the temperature here on the river dropped to 32 degrees. As far as the river, upstream lakes were at full pool from October flooding rains.  All that rain water finally drained downstream and the highest river level that I saw was just above 115ft here on the Savannah River. This did cause some flooding down by the marina in downtown by the boat ramp where the level is below 114 ft.

I am sorry, but have been ill for a few months. I have noticed that some of the crops have not come in very good like the soybean and cotton crop has been scrawny, but I am not a farmer so really don't have any idea of the direct impact for the year.  The weather being what seems over all to be dry on more days, (we have had some heavy rain fall (>2-3 inch) making our rain fall totals look good, but they are over fewer days... we had gone several long stretches. This is what I think has impacted crop yeilds here. But having more dry days, I think has helped the construction industry get some of the road projects cleared up and they had many damaged roads from rain/ice from the last 2 winters in this area. We are going into the winter with many of the roads finally repaired. Hope it helps with accident prevention, but that is yet to be seen.
We have lots of moss growing in shaded areas, even more then before.
People who have been doing DIY projects to their homes like in siding and stuff have really been able to move along here.
It appears that too, the new addition of a mall in Elizabeth City really got completed fast and is open in many places.
I am sure the construction has helped people remain employed this year... thanks to dry weather. This is however a very economically depressed area and don't know if employment rates have gone up on long term work projects.

properties.categories: Society And Public Health,Water Supply And Quality
properties.description:
The national weather service all hazards radio announced a "code yellow" air quality forecast for today with the primary pollutant of uncategorized "small particulate". Air quality is forecast in this metropolitan area, but not in all areas. If the pollutant is smoke from combustion, then it follows carbon monoxide will be produced as well. Smoke rises or is suspended or transported by wind. Carbon monoxide is odorless and heavier than air so it seeks lowest ground. If particulate is dust, then the properties of the dust will affect certain populations (trees, pollens, ashes, asbestos, molds, etc.) These microscopic pollutants cause: mucosal irritation; vascular dilation or constriction; central nervous system issues; and others. Affects may be acute, chronic and cumulative. Carbon monoxide may seek path of least resistance and flow downhill/downstream within river banks all the way to the lowest elevation sea level at the coast. One implication for drought is that, after a rain, some of these pollutants may be transported from the atmosphere to the water. Many times I see "code green" better air quality following a rain. Therefore, in a drought, the air pollution irritants may be more problematic. For me this includes mucosal moisturizers, rinses, over the counter pain remedies and avoidance.

properties.description:
weekly report: WET - really wet !  We had two different systems move through that each put down between 1.5 and over 2 inches of rain within just a few days of one another.
The winds have gotten higher over the past four days as well. There was localized street flooding. In some areas, just about 20 miles away, the flooding was bad enough that it impacted schools and businesses. ( not RIGHT here - closer to the coast )
AGRICULTURE:  Whew- the local farmer harvested the soy THE DAY prior to the rains.  Now those same fields have standing water.
Because it has gotten much cooler ( cold ), the mosquitos are not the problem they were, even at the beginning of the week.
Fire Level should be low.
River Levels are HIGH - we were out boating so this is a fact.
WILDLIFE:  critters are scrounging for food - deer are eating our clover ( planted for our bees )
BEES: are kicking out their drones, and have just within the past day, stopped bringing in very much pollen. At the beginning of the week they were bringing in pollen.
Night time temps will have them in a much tighter cluster in the hives.
BLOOMING: Eleagnus,Marigolds, some hollies, some magnolias, camellias, pansies, mums, and even a few green peppers.
Public Events would have been curtailed if they fell on Thursday or Sunday - "ugly damp wet weather both days "
Air Conditioners run slightly - then back to heating systems as the overnights were dipping near to freezing.
Frost was very very light ( so far )

At a local creek approximately N 35-49 and W 078-51 at 10:00 AM the creek bank was three feet wide and water was 4 inches deep. Surface floating leaves were stationary, but undercurrents and slow flow over nearby ripples revealed some downstream movement. The topsoil was 52 F. Air temp was 51 F with humidity of 55%. The sandy bottom beneath one inch of water was 54 F. Large tree roots were spanning the creek and extending from trees toward the water. One such root measured 7 inch circumference and was more than 30 inches long. Raccoon tracks were seen along the creek bank in the sand. I pulled out a small rusty toddler sized chair from the creek bank that was first spotted nearly 10 months ago and placed it by the roadside to dry for later pickup. In another area, spotted a large hawk perched on a streetlight at an intersection that was not busy with traffic at that time. The hawk remained  unmoved as me and the dog slowly walked directly underneath the light.

At this location, we're not affected by tides but elsewhere in the Charleston area King tides caused shallow coastal flooding at midweek.  Sampling for Charleston Waterkeeper at high tide Wednesday morning, I had to wear my muck boots to even attempt to reach some of the docks that we routinely sample from. At many locations, the floating docks were as high or higher than the stationary dock.

properties.description:
One fast moving front gave us 1.49" of rain & wind. The rain raised the French Broad River to 12,000 cfs and brought out the kayakers. Today the river is running 6,000 cfs. Last night we got our first SNOW of the season, although only a little on surfaces above the ground. A little less than 1/4" of snow perched on top of grass, leaves, kale, flower stalks, and porches. The snow melted where it hit the ground. Feeder birds--mostly chickadees, titmice, and goldfinches--are very active. Before the rain last week, the creek had slowed down and we turned off the small jet in the microhydro. After the rain, we put the microhydro on full making 6 kilowatts per day. Our drinking water remains excellent quality & quantity.

Nov 4, 2015 at 19:36:43 UTC: location N 35-49.490 W 078-50.519 on the concrete curb of a street. Most curbs were dry. At this location, shallow water was trickling slowly. A small particle was measured moving ten inches in 48 seconds. Using a circular magnifier with a field of vision circumference of 2.3 inches, I counted small bubbles on the surface of dark green slippery algae. The larger spherical bubbles measured ~ 1/16 inch diameter. 8 large bubbles and 10 large bubbles per circle measured at this curb site. The bubbles looked similar to carbonation bubbles of a soda. NOV 5 at 13:08:10 UTC in the turbulent stream at this location ( N 35-49.004 W 078-50.679 )was a long stick stuck in an eddy on the right shore bank with a large conglomeration of foam. The foam was darker than shaving cream but colored more like the foam of a latte or cappuccino. The foam conglomeration appeared longer than 36 inches and was irregular like a mountain range but as tall as 8 inches in some areas. NOV 5 at 13:44:14 UTC a freshly horizontally fallen  tree on the ground. The tree had hundreds of fresh green leaves. One leaf measured 4 inches long and 1/2 inch wide. Unable to accurately measure the trunk under the conditions, but estimated more than 20 feet tall. edit 11/20/2015: this tree was reported freshly fallen after a storm. On closer inspection, the tree is nearly horizontal to the ground near a parking lot, but the leaves are still very green except for one small fractured limb with brown leaves distal to the fracture. The tree is apparently rooted even though it looks nearly horizontally fallen. It is not prudent to venture to inspect the root/low trunk structure due to the location and steep incline.

At N 35-48.948 W 078-50.718 today in a stagnant shallow water area between the paved road and a stream restoration area, I noticed quite a few (~10) small "snails". The dark colored snails were on large rocks (>6 inch x 6 inch rocks) near the water surface one to two inches below water. So, although we have abundant moisture, I'm afraid we are stunting the growth of the grass seed recently spread on the lawn to thicken it up for next years lawn. A beaver has begun to build a home in the bank and we are seeing signs where he has been collecting sticks and mud around the spillway as well as some small saplings that have been cut with the characteristic angle cut and taken away. No new deer footprints were observed this week.

The sandy bottom with small pebbles was visible through the clear water. Leaves on the water surface moved 12 inches in less than 3 seconds. An adult, lean appearing, great blue heron was spotted perched on a low concrete water manhole structure near this site. On NOV 6 at 14:59:05 UTC at N 35-49.548 W 078-50.209 some culverts under the 3 lane road were observed to be very obstructed with trees, branches and pine straw/leaves. Three large culvert openings are located (out of reach) 16 feet below the bridge rail. The obstructed water flow led to a back up accumulation of isolated foamy discolored (tan/yellow) matter floating on the surface for several square yards behind the blockage. Nearby this site, a freshly horizontally fallen pine near the sidewalk was observed/measured. The trunk measured 15 inches diameter at one point. Three representative limbs: limb 1) 14 inch long limb with brown pine needles on the first nine inches and green needles on inches 9 to 14: limb 2) 15 inch long limb with brown pine needles on inches 0 to 7 and green needles on distal inches 7 to 15: limb 3) A 12 inch long pine limb had brown pine needles on proximal 0 to 10 inches and green needles on the remaining distal 2 inches (10-12). Many needles were in clusters of 3-4 and measured about 5 to 6 inches long. The pattern of mixed brown and green pine needles is very noticeable along this area of the creek. No pine cones were observed on this fallen tree.  Edit 11/19--earlier this week on returning to this site it is apparent that the pine needles were changed from brown to green in many of these trees.

From the Perquimans Weekly newspaper dated 11-18-15 by reporter Peter Williams. Two weeks of wet, cloudy weather caused by two long term low pressure systems that have kept farmers out of the fields. Paul Smith an agricultural agent for the past 17 years. October had heavy rains and the sun didn't come out for 15 days so crops never dried out. Cotton and soybeans were hit especially hard. This has been one of the largest monetary losses we've had including natural disaster. Cotton and soybeans remain in the field because the ground is too wet for growers to pick and are not able to plant a wheat crop.

properties.description:
At the beginning of this week we received .85" of rain, then it became clear and cold--down to 24.8°. The forest is quiet with deep green pines & rhododendrons standing in contrast to the naked, gray hardwoods. I watched a downy woodpecker silently fly from tree to tree. And yet, animals haven't entered hibernation. I saw a groundhog eating on the side of the road and we found a garter snake last week. So it's not quite winter. The rain raised river levels and kayakers and rafters came to enjoy the water. We cut back to just the large jet on the microhydro producing 3 kwh/day. (That may not seem like much, but with our conservative lifestyle, 3 kw is often our average use of electricity.) The drinking spring remains excellent quality and quantity.

Nov 15 at 14:18:52 UTC at N 35-48.947 W 078-50.421 the creek was flowing and leaves on the water surface travelled downstream 6 feet in 10 to 20 seconds. Water surface temperature 51 F, air temperature 48 F, topsoil temperature 49 F relative humidity 44%. (measured air temp/humid at 42 inches above ground level in shade out of wind). Could not see below surface of water in shade, but could see few inches below surface in sunlight. Weather damage at park N 35-48.917 W 078-50.769 a large fallen tree spans the creek and is within 10 feet of the road. The tree measured 35 inch circumference near base and 16.5 inch circumference near the broken piece. A possum nest was displaced by the broken tree. The 5 pointed green leaves and green spherical prickly sweet gum balls were amply intact yesterday distal to the fracture. An adult deer in this area was seen running away down the paved road from the dog barking around 8 AM today. In a nearby parking lot, while seated in the same parking space, I picked up 20 freshly fallen acorns that measured diameters ranging from 5/16 inch to 7/16 inch (without the bottom cups.)  November 14 I saw from 30 to 50 migratory waterfowl in flight (geese and ducks flying in formation around sunrise/sunset). edit November 16: the broken tree limb is now horizontal and upon closer viewing, the green sweet gum balls and 5 point leaves were not actually on the broken tree but on a tree that the broken tree segment was leaning on. The fallen tree actually looks unhealthy from trunk to the top without any leaves or gumballs. Work crews removed the branch from the precarious leaning position near the road and laid it horizontal today.

RIVER LEVELS: remain more on the high side, early in the week heavy rains caused flood alerts.
No public events were impacted negatively by any weather event.

The creek is full and clear with many small fish still swimming around in it. Leaves continue turning yellow, brown and red and falling to the ground. Its' impossible to get ahead of them. The grass seed planted a few weeks ago is growing well. The white pines are dropping a lot of brown needles.

properties.description:
Nov 11 at 13:53:08 UTC location N 35-48.914 W 078-50.353 the creek was 65 inches wide and 6 inches deep. The smooth contours of the light colored sandy bottom were clear in the morning sunlight. Timed one floating leaf moving 6 feet downstream in 90 seconds. Other leaves floated at different velocities relative to water depth, fluctuations near banks, leaf size and other variables. The banks had scattered green moss and the ground surface in the woods was covered with damp pine straw, grasses, and fallen leaves. On Nov 11 at 15:36:00 UTC at N 35-48.999 W 078-50.420 a number of large pine trees were noted to be cut down. One pine stump measured circumference of 5 foot ten inches sawed of at 16 inches above ground. The flatly sawed surface had green growth (moss) and some small oblong shallow burrows. Inserted thermometer into some of the burrows on the trunk and measured 54 degrees. The surrounding topsoil, in contrast, measured 58 degrees at the same time. Overturned a stone near the woods edge and found dozens of large yellow/red colored ants underneath in the damp dirt. The ants had three distinct segments (thorax, head, etc.), six jointed legs and long antennae. Among the larger ants were some very small white insects that were not measured but noted to be in rapid motion under the overturned rock. Implications for drought include moisture required and lack of moisture would change the rate and location of decomposition and increase risk of combustion of the leaf covered ground in the woods.

University of Oregon Research Team for Earth Scope came to set up equipment on Pauline Davis Properties to collect data on Wednesday, November 4, 2015.
A 3 foot hole had to be dug to position some of the equipment. The bottom of the hole was muddy with water accumulating in the bottom. This is on the ridge between the North and South Forks of the Edisto River. There is a pond on this site. This is on the hill above the pond.
We have water standing in ditches and any low areas in yards. The ground is saturated with water.
Questions - How is this affecting the aquifers? What is the affect on the estuaries and salt water encroachments?
Ponds are now full and close to flowing over emergency spillways. We are soggy wet.

properties.description:
In the last 9 days we've had 2 fronts pass through with a total of 1.79" of rain and 3 days of dry, warm weather in between. It's turned to an early winter look with few leaves on the trees. The distant hills look rusty with the persistent oak & beech leaves. Juncos have returned from the high country. They migrate up to the mountain tops in the summer and down to 2,000' in the winter. Goldfinches have returned wearing their winter drab--the summer yellow of the males looking much like females. White-throated sparrows and winter wrens add song to the quiet days. Katydids are around, but quiet. No more evening insect chorus. Frogs are still active at the pond and an occasional dragonfly is around. The rain has raised the river level and brought out kayakers and rafters--important to the tourist economy of Madison County. We have our microhydro on the large jet producing 3 kwh. Our drinking spring remains at high quality and quantity.

properties.description:
weekly report: rainfall total for the past week was: 2.85 inches.  
On the days that it did not rain, it was hot, and mostly sunny. 
AGRICULTURE: Nothing very active it seems this past week.  The soy bean fields surrounding our property have not been harvested as of yet - but they are very brown.  Some morning glories ran along the sides.
Bus/Ind. : 
Energy:  This week the air conditioners were run. We are inland from the ocean abt. 35 miles. Temperatures were easily into the 80's on many days.  All night time temperatures were low enough to be able to turn the a/c off entirely.  This is a huge energy saving time of year.
FIRE: threat remains in the low category due to the rains; underbrush is damp
PLANTS: Many plants that normally bloom in the spring are showing a minimal few blooms ( hollies; verbena; osmanthus; even a few azalea )  Dandelions and society garlic are back; along with clover leaves ( no blossoms ); eleagnus is blooming; the mahonnia is beginning to show promise for a December bloom as it has buds forming - as does the one variety of camellia ( blooms in December usually )/
Wildlife: A small bear was killed on a nearby highway after it was found wandering in circles, injured.  Apparently, it had been brushed by a passing freight train.  Coyotes are heard and seen.  
BIRDS:  Plenty of cardinals in the woods, and only sometimes at the feeders.  Chickadees and common house finch, accompanied on the ground by mourning doves are the feeders most frequent visitors.
Hawks, crows, and buzzards.
SNAKES:  snakes are being seen in the woods, and are slightly aggressive, in a defensive manner.  It is extremely difficult to be able to identify the type of snakes being seen.  Locals have so many names; and it is sensed that they are not all correct.  Website visits for photos don't help.  
MOTHS are very prevalent in the grasses and around the marigolds.  Flies have been biting. MOSQUITOS continue to be a huge problem here. 
Tourism: all public events have gone on without impact from weather
Water Supply: we are fine.  River levels remain slightly on the high side.
OVERALL:  MODERATELY WET

properties.description:
weekly report:  we had just under 1/2 inch of precipitation for this past week.  It seems 'normal'. However, some planting and weeding found the top 4-6 inches of soil quite dry, nearly 'dusty' in spots. 
AGRICULTURE: Soy beans are amber brown - seem ready to harvest / Cotton is being harvested in the area / Very small patches of corn are still standing - most were harvested quite a while ago / Farmers are being advised by cooperative extension to get their winter wheat planted BY mid November.
ENERGY:  It has been another week of mostly no use of heating or cooling systems. One day saw temperatures temporarily high enough to warrant some A/C for a few hours, but once the sun had set, the night temps were cool enough to either forget about it, or just open a window.
FIRE:  Danger seems low, but is likely increasing since winds and little precipitation is beginning to dry out the brush.
PLANTS: BLOOMING small blooms on such normally spring blooming plants such as hollies / osmanthus / even a few azaleas.  Magnolias / eleagnus / dandelions are blooming.  Clover leaves are resfurfacing
LEAVES - most deciduous trees are now losing their leaves fairly consistently, and those that haven't lost leaves are turning colors ( such as Bradford pears, and some ornamentals)  
WILDLIFE: It is hunting season.  Deer have been killed by vehicles twice on our street in one week ( early morning or early evening ).  Fox scat is evident / Opossums have been seen a lot this year, more than in the past. / Bears are known and have been seen or pictured in the immediate area.
BIRDS:  Cardinals are not feeding on the feeders at this time, but are frequently seen in the brush and woods. ( seems they do this every year ).  Common house finch are still feeding.  Doves are prevalent - but quail and turkeys have not been seen much if at all. 
SOCIETY - PUBLIC HEALTH:  MOSQUITOS.  I have mentioned this for several reports.  They are truly the worst we've seen them in perhaps a decade.  A trip to WalMart found the shelves absolutely empty of mosquito repellent.  It is a common topic of discussion locally.
Fire ants are slowing down - but are still evident, and they too seem to be having a 'banner' year.
TOURISM:  No public events have been impacted, although there were events that had been cancelled previously and were held locally this past week.
WATER:  The river levels remain normal.

At 11:40 AM local time the distance between the water surface at  the footbridge in the park was 6 feet nine inches. At Nov 7 14:50:31 UTC the water was measured at the ditch location N 35-48.884 W 078-50.776 during a light rain. The ditch here was 32 inches wide and 8 inches deep in the middle. Surface leaves floating were moving 4 feet in less than 3 seconds. The water temperature was 68 degrees. Using a 1/2 cup plastic cup and a household electric meter, I measured the DC voltage and resistance of water here. As a control, I measured 1/2 cup bottled water, diet soda, rain water, (with baking soda or table salt added) indoors. Resistance of the water samples were different and usually in the 2,000 Ohm range. Voltage among samples varied, mostly in the 200 millivolt DC range (+,-). The properties of the creek water steadily varied as soon as the water was removed from the creek, unlike the other samples, which were fairly stable. The method should be refined before numbers reported. The hypothesis is that the electrolyte properties of water will vary with the solution, temperature, mixing, 1/2 life, and other variables. The ingredients of creek water are largely unknown, unlike the other samples. The implication for drought is that the cations/ions transported in the creek are located/concentrated elsewhere when the creek is not flowing. The creek in this location is usually dry.

The cooler weather has allowed us to work outside a bit these last several weeks, (mostly trying to get this old house readied for winter.) While you can not help but notice the moss on the ground is still growing in spots all over the yard (since spring) the grass has slowed its growing (not needing mowed as often) and the crops of cotton and soybeans are being harvested. To me, the cotton crop does not look right. It is not as tall, nor as thick with cotton balls. Soybeen corp did not grow as tall either. 

Interesting that many of these old houses have the appearences of being in better shape then they are because they used vinyl siding with aluminum trim. How ever the caulking over the years is not kept up, and that wind damage occurs as the siding becomes brittle from being baked in the sun since some where in the 90s. You can not get the right pieces either to just go fix it. So, we noticed a small maybe the size of a silver dollar hole between the storm window and regular window. (That was the only visable symptom) however we got the trim molding cover off (this is a bay window that is 12x7 feet behind a exterior wall.) Well it was rotted all the way down to the foundation of the ground. Mind you, it was not infested with vectors like carpenter ants, or termites. This is just moisture trapped causing wood rooting along edges of wood severly. They would have been better off, neve having put that stuff on. It would have been noticed faster. Needless the hugh air leak for HVAC/heat or cooling.It has taken 3 weeks to rebuild the wall with 2 carpenters working at it. We only have the bay window roof to replace now.

2 coats of gripper prime coat, and two coats of color trim... with lots of caulk inbetwen the seal plates, window casements and alike. It will not be recovered with aluminum either. Talked to some local carpenter in this are, many homes are having these issues and they are not being readily discovered.This is where housing construction and weather meet, and the people who are having these issues are not even able to see the damage before buying and lots of these old homes are very old. We are have discovered a different problem under the vinyl siding itself in a nother area, will get tell you once we have a way to tear it apart. I do not even know how to assess the impact of this. Some people -not so many- are actually taking this vinyl siding off and dealing with structural issues.

properties.description:
At a creek at 8 AM today, air temperature 47.4 and 47.6. Water temperature measured 57.7, 58.8, and 58.3. Water is turbid so bottom is not visible. Velocity of water flow is enough to create "V" ripples behind the thermometer inserted at the surface extending more than 20 inches. pH 6.8; bromine 0; alkalinity 40. At 8:40 a few hundred feet downstream, water temp was 58.0, 57.6, and 58.1. pH 6.2, bromine 0, alkalinity 40. At 7:30AM, I purchased 5 gallons of filtered water that was filtered on site at a department store for 37 cents/gallon. Bromine 0, pH 6.2, alkalinity 40. At 9:20AM, in a wooded area, for the first time, I saw a stagnant pool of water estimated less than 20 yards by 20 yards. The water was dark appearing and had an irregular thin biofilm on the surface. Medium small bubbles were actively surfacing below the biofilm. Pine straw was seen floating in the water. A living box turtle was near the shore, measuring approximately 6 inches long and 4 inches wide (not still enough for accurate measurement). Surface water temperature of this pool measured 53.6 and 54.0 near the shore. I saw the same adult squirrel that does not have a tail and has a distinct abdominal scar climbing a pine tree near where he was first seen almost a year ago. Activities directly observed while taking these measurements included: baseball; golfing with carts; air traffic of large and small planes; swing set; porch sitting; dog walking; and walking. (discussion of hydrogen ion concentration in water and the influence of drought on acid base homeostasis is beyond the scope of these limited observations)

Our station had 19.38" in October, almost 16" of which fell in the first six days.  We've had 1.55" during the last five days of the month.  Our neighborhood has plenty of springs, but they only appear when it's really wet.  The neighborhood has "bled" all month, although only the most persistent springs are still active.  We have one French drain that runs when it's really wet and it's still going strong, but it's drawing water from a foot or more under the surface.  As you might imagine, nothing is suffering from a shortage of water.

properties.description:
Surface water temperature measured at a nearby creek at 8:30AM today was 59.2, 59.9 and 59.1 degrees F. The creek was in shade and flowing generously at that time. For whatever reason the water was 9 degrees warmer than the air at that time, the drought implication would be the thermal energy that raised the water temperature while it was flowing would be much more concentrated if it were released in less water. Water temperature in turn affects biologic cycles (spawning, circadian, migrating, reproducing, etc.)and therefore has impact on local and downstream organisms. The distance between the water surface and the footbridge measured 8 feet yesterday afternoon and was estimated the same today. During low water, the creek at this site has been dry or stagnant. Observed 5 snails on the sidewalk. Three living snails left visibly narrow slimy trails, two dead snails were dry on the surface. The shells spiraled from large to small counterclockwise from head to tail end. A number of people have been observed in the occupation of leaf blowing recently using electric and fossil fuel powered blowers. The implication for drought is that the release of leaves and pine straw from trees is affected by water and therefore affects seasonal employment in a minor way.

It's been two days since we had over 3 inches of rain and the ground is very soft and muddy. The streams are flowing more vigorously than they have at any time this year. There are streams flowing down the mountainside where we have not previously seen water flowing. The happy gurgling gives a new sound to the trails but this is at the cost of very muddy conditions. The water is all flowing clear. It seems almost impossible to keep one's shoes dry and I can verify the water feels very cold when seeping into my shoes. No flooding or damage has been observed but all the waterways seen are at their full levels. Several species of squirrels were noted while on a walk today along with some chipmunks, all putting away stores for the coming winter. Some deer were seen at a distance. Most of the trees at this altitude are now bare of leaves and only a few still display their bright fall colors. The roads and pathways are covered with fallen leaves.

Danet Road is holding up very well. The biggest problem is standing water covering the entrance to Hwy. 4 from Danet Road. "Pine Hill" creek was flowing again this AM. 
"Pine Hill creek" is what I call the water that flows down the ditch from Todd Creek Road down to and crosses Danet Road. When we have constant rain there is a puddle about 4 to 6' minimum that accumulates. 
Those of us that live on Danet Road have to cross this water to get access onto Hwy. 4 and from Hwy. 4 to Danet Rd.]It is standing, not flowing. But it is bad on the brakes of the cars. Also it is a hazard when we enter from Hwy. 4. 
I know to slow or stop before entering Danet Rd. I enter at an angle and cross at the low point of the puddle.
We have asked both the state and county for assistance and have received help from the county by keeping the ditches on both sides as open as possible. Still the hazard remains.

properties.description:
weekly report:  No rain at all this week - which is fine. The soil is still quite damp - although towards the end of this past week, it was starting to dry in the upper 4-6 inches. ( we were planting - so we got a good idea of this )
Temperatures have been moderate, and the winds as well - with occasional 15 kts or so.  
AGRICULTURE:  Federal funds relief has been made available to any farmers who suffered impacts from the rains of about a month ago.  Soy beans are now a pretty amber - likely near ready to harvest.
VEGETATION:  Falling leaves: oak, crepe myrtle, sweet gum, poplar, ornamental fruits.  Red Maples are stunning right now - Bradford pear has not turned as of yet ( late ).
Blooming still: very small amounts ( locally ) of ragweed, eleagnus, aster, mums. ( honey bees have been foraging on these ).
Clover leaves are showing back up, as is "society garlic" ( aka field onions in the yards.
Centipede grass has stopped growing and is turning brown.
BIRDS:  cardinals are sometimes on the feeders, but not so much.  Now it is small finches and wrens.  Kill Deer and Mockingbirds, Crows, and Hawks are often seen.
WILDLIFE:  It is hunting season.  Bears are being seen in the very near vicinity ( mostly on wildlife cameras).  Deer population seems 'normal'.  Fox scat is often seen.  Haven't seen any signs of rabbits.  Opposum are seen, as are raccoons.  Turkeys are not seen as often right now.

River water levels remain on the high side of normal; due no doubt to the past rains, and wind driven 'tides'.
There have been many public events ( fall ) and none have been impacted adversely by bad weather - in fact, quite the opposite - it has been " Chamber of Commerce" weather for these gatherings.
Neither A/C or heating systems were necessary what-so-ever this past week - a relief from energy bills for a small amount of time.

We have pulled the honey off our bees for the winter, and prepped them.  They are all strong at this time.  We got a lot more honey off our fall harvest than we did off the spring honey flow ( which WAS weather impacted )

properties.description:
It's been another streak of dry (beautiful) fall weather. We received our first frost on the 17th and the first hard freeze on the following three days with the lowest low at 28.9°. The afternoon usually warmed up into the 60's with lots of clear, sunny skies. The cold triggered some gorgeous fall color. I now think this week is the peak of color. Although tulip poplars and walnuts are bare, the maples, oaks, hickories, and beeches present a lovely palette of gold, scarlet, lemon yellow, russet, and orange. Few wildflowers remain, but bees are enjoying our late chrysanthemums. Coyotes have been common on the wildlife camera, along with opossums, raccoons, and wild turkeys. Family groups of turkeys are common in the fields. I heard a goldfinch this afternoon, maybe part of the gang that will hang around all winter. Also hearing winter wrens regularly and saw one around the eaves looking for bugs. With the lack of rain, we had to turn off the microhydro. Our drinking spring remains at excellent quality and quantity.

We've received NO rain all week. Still the grass is growing and the garden is producing lots of veggies including peppers, tomatoes, okra, and  beans. I am watering seeds and seedlings to get them established. There's early fall color with burgundy red sumacs and sourwood and splashes of bright orange-red of Virginia creeper climbing tree trunks. Squirrels are busy gathering chinese chestnuts, walnuts, and hickory nuts. Bird migration continues with thrushes coming through. Summer hummingbirds and broad-winged hawks are still here in small numbers. There are still a handful of fireflies; katydids still sing in the evening, while cone-headed grasshoppers serenade by day. The dryness has affected one friend's spring that is reduced to a trickle. We are grateful that our spring continues at its high quality and quantity.

Late September and early October brought us a record-setting 12 consecutive days of precipitation. The impact of that is now history as we have just seen 12 consecutive days with no precipitation. This is not close to the record but the effects are becoming more apparent each day. The usual soft spots in the yard are now firmed up and quite solid. Digging down through the mulch in the flower gardens shows there is still some moisture below the top inch which has completely dried out. Areas of the yard that have recently been seeded require watering every few days. The creek and pond levels are down about 4 inches from full. The water is slightly hazy but it is easy to see the bottom. Small fish are swimming in the creek. The flow of water has diminished but it is still flowing in the creek and from the pond outfall. The great blue heron has been successfully fishing for his lunch each day. The deer are making their presence known by eating the hostas and other flowers but they are not able to leave their usual foot prints in the hard soil. We have seen the last of the humming birds for the year but other birds are plentiful around the feeders. Leaves are starting to change colors in the maples but not yet for the sycamores. The needles on the white pines are turning brown and falling off.

(All the last tomatoes are now spread out on the table and peppers fill a bushel basket.) The fall color has peaked. Now the cold will turn the oaks and beeches, always the last to change color.

The French Broad is falling back to a more normal level at 1420 cfs. Rafters and kayakers enjoyed the water last weekend. Our microhydro small jet is still producing 2.4 kwh per day (but we may need to turn it off soon.)

Crickets are still singing. Butterflies are few--mostly sulfurs. Asters and gentians are still blooming. Winter wrens have been singing every morning. I heard a broadwing hawk today...maybe a passing migrant? I'd expect the hawks that nested here have already flown south.

The spring water continues at high quality and quantity.

properties.description:
Sidewalk sightings today: in a tree protection zone, saw a department of agriculture bug trap on a tree to assess for boring ash tree bugs. On the concrete sidewalks, several damp or shallow stagnant areas have thin slippery algal growth of different species. One green algae covered area had numerous tiny air bubbles on the surface of the algae. Another sidewalk area had slippery olive green thin hair like slippery algae this morning. In another area, on a sidewalk bridge, at a 4 lane bridge crossing a creek, I saw life including: a large snake at lest 4 feet long motionless on a branch with no leaves. The snake was about 6 to 10 feet above the shallow slow moving clear creek water. The long snake was copper/orange/gold colored and had repetitive finger like blotches that grew progressively smaller and closer together from the head to tail. At least 25 of the blotches were counted. In the area was also hanging vines including Virginia creeper with green and red leaves, a bumblebee near a honeysuckle bloom, pokeweed, and a red cardinal bird. In another area, I saw unusually large paw prints with a pad and four toes and four large claws. The prints were 3/4 inch deep into the moist soil where newly sown grass seeds were 3 to 4 inches high on the roadside sidewalk. I also saw an adult squirrel struggling to carry a fairly green pine cone up a large pine tree from the ground level. The pine cone was at least 3 times as big as the squirrels head. I have seen three adult squirrels and one domestic dog over the last few months that appear to have very limited mobility below the pelvis, almost to the point of paralysis, but still able to ambulate or climb trees to a limited extent.
