properties.description:
weekly report:  Just at one more inch of rainfall over the past week.  Still, it is drizzly, chilly, and breezy.  Being in southeastern NC, we did not receive what SC did over the past 10 days - but we are on the periphery of these systems, so we have been kept wet.  More northeastern counties, and the rest of NC has not rec'd this rainfall.
For two days, following the rain event of last weekend, we had nice sunny weather.  But lawn mowing has been near to impossible with standing water in lawns.   Most everyone who COULD mow, did during those two days of drying out.  The grasses has grown tremendously during the rains, with near perfect temperatures as well.
We have high water in rivers.  The ferry system has had to cancel one of its runs on two separate occasions because the water level is too high to be able to load vehicles.
An annual HUGE outdoor local event is suffering.  Normally over 100,000 people attend this event each year - but the entire weekend event is being impacted by chilly, wet and breezy weather.
AGRICULTURE:  Local news is reporting crop damages.  Fall vegetable crops were very severely effected by the rains of the last weekend.  Losses for one farmer is estimated at about $7500.  Additionally, one local sod farmer is worried that the centipede did not go dormant prior to being sogged down by the rains; and he is estimating his losses in the tens of thousands.
Personally, we haven't had losses - all peppers still blooming and producing - lettuce, beats, celery, onions and garlic all doing well.  The asparagus ferns are full but starting to dry out.  Strawberry plants looking healthy right now.
Soy crop is 'yellowing' and seems to have not been much effected; corn not harvested may dry out?; tobacco standing is probably lost -but a recent trip this week up thru NE NC and into SE VA shows crops being harvested normally - as they did not receive the rainfall we did.
Honey bees no doubt have been eating what should have been their winter stores; they are foraging ( visibly confirmed ) up on groundsel; eleagnus; and golden rod.  
Most of the red maples are starting to turn red; crepe myrtles in this area have sparse leaves; oaks are3 dropping their leaves; figs are not and still are trying to ripen ( brown turkey figs .  Also blooming is vitex, some magnolia and a bloom or two on Nellie R Stevens hollies.
BIRDS:  Blue jay still around - of course the lone female humming bird left the day before the rains came last week; cardinals and finches are feeding at the seed feeders -canary finches have not been seen; doves are prevalent; hawks and crows seem to be making a lot of noise of late; 
Prevalent are wrens, mockingbirds, and kill deer.
FIRE ANTS -the population locally has exploded !
Spiders are spinning webs at this time of year.
A gojillion plus two little white MOTHS seem to be in the grasses as we mow. Yellow moths are prevalent as well. Mosquitos get nasty at the evening and when the temps are just warm enough for them.
No need for air conditioning, or heating quite yet.
Fire threat is extremely low ( though winds are constant ).
No drought here.  Starting to feel as if it will be a chilly damp winter !

Heartfelt condolences to our neighbors in SC !   We are a mere 5 hour drive straight up  the coast from Myrtle Beach.  Locally here,  folks are rallying relief efforts headed down to SC.  Sincerest hope that y'all recover as quickly as can be expected.

We have fresh raccoon tracks by the pond. Squirrels have been very active gathering up acorns for the coming winter. The great blue heron has been fishing successfully in the pond this past week. Trees are dropping some leaves and pine needles and some yellow leaves are seen on the tulip trees but most of the leaves are still green. Last week was the big rain, especially south and east of us. Still we got 4.12" of rain 9/30-10/04. (That's just a little less precip than the whole month of September!) The French Broad River rose was big--running 10,000 cfs! Fortunately the predicted flooding did not happen. We put out microhydro on full for several days. We just turned off the large jet today. Our drinking water continues to be high quality and quantity. Our friend's spring that had gone dry is back.

Fall color is at about 50% with some leaves knocked down by the rain. Since there's been no significant rain for the last 4 days, I'm back to watering the winter seedlings. Summer crops of tomatoes & peppers continue to produce. Hummingbirds have left, as have the indigo buntings, broad-winged hawks, and warblers. We're still enjoying goldenrods, gentians, and fall asters. Witch hazel trees are blooming.

This is a tough report to prepare!  While most of South Carolina suffered some degree of drought during the past water year, we ended the 2014-15 water year with a 16.16" surplus.  September was only one of four months that we did not meet our monthly average of rain.  Having said that, much of South Carolina is now suffering from extreme and unusual flooding.  We are on the short side of that here in the lowcountry near Savannah, GA.  It has rained every day in October because of the low sitting off southern Florida drawing in moisture.  We have recorded 2.71" in the past 5 days which is already the monthly average.  The calendar year is also running quite ahead.  We are sick of rain and humidity but are counting our blessings that we are not in upstate South Carolina where there has been death and destruction as well as major interstates closed.

Consequently it has soaked in very well, providing good short and long term moisture that will be available to all plants.

properties.description:
Yes, we have rain - 10 straight days with measurable rain totaling 7.37". With a normal level for Hyco Lake is 410.5', ithas steadily risen to 411.42'. A notice has been sent to residents to remove items from docks that could be damaged by water or float away. I've seen several docks that are almost level with the water. Overall the lake is muddy due to runoff as are local streams. Almost all ditches have standing water. I've seen some very shallow standing water but no reports of road closings. Fortunately not too many reports of falling trees but we did loose power on Saturday (10/4) for about an hour and lights have blinked several times since. Fortunately we have not been effected like South Carolina. Even though the entire state of North Carolina is under a state of emergency no local shelters have been opened. Still a few campers but they are mostly temporary workers on local projects. Farmers are concerned as they have not been able to harvest crops. There could be considerable damage / loss of what's left in the fields. Birds have not been very active but saw one hummingbird at our feeder. He has fresh food to store up energy for his long winter home flight. Temperatures are cooler, fortunately the humidity has gone. Think fall is officially here.

properties.description:
We had three consecutive weeks in which we got a total of 1/4 inch of rain and things were looking very dire. Leaves of the trees were curling under and/or dropping to the ground, the grass was struggling and the ground had turned rock solid. The pond was at the lowest level it has been in over a year and there was no flow into or out of it. That all came to an end eight days ago and we have had rain every day since then. Eight consecutive days of rain have now saturated the ground. The pond level is back to full and there is a vigorous flow down the stream in our yard to the pond as well as from the pond exit over the dam on the other side. The water is clear and fish and turtles can be seen in the stream. The ground is now more than just soggy, it is very soft and muddy everywhere. Wildlife do not seem to have changed their patterns. A doe and two young deer crossed our yard this afternoon. We are still seeing the heron and footprints from the raccoon(s) by the pond. The river birches in our yard have lost about 80% of their leaves compared to the river birch at our cabin in the NC mountains which has not lost any leaves yet. The effects of the past dry spell linger.

properties.description:
Only .54" of rain fell this week after 11 days of no measurable rain. There must have been a lot of rain upstream on French Broad River since it rose from about 400 cfs to 3,000 cfs! Rafters were enjoying the high water over the weekend. the Feels like fall which arrived on Sept. 23. (We even had our first fire in the wood stove--our primary source to heat.) 

Bird migration may be slowing, but it is still going on with warblers, rose-breasted grosbeaks, and others passing through. It seems that goldfinches are moving through and I think our summer hummingbirds have left. We did have one hummer at the feeder this evening--perhaps passing by.

Leaves are slowly changing color. Sourwoods are still red. Many poplar leaves are turning brown and falling off. Maples are beginning to turn. We searched out our ginseng plants with lemon yellow leaves and removed the leaves so they won't attract would-be root hunters. Goldenrods and asters decorate the fields. Around the house zinnias, marigolds, dahlias, and roses provide a lot of color and nectar for butterflies. 

Our spring is still good quality and quantity. But one friend's spring is still dry.

properties.description:
weekly report:  1.22 inches of rain accumulated. We are on the very southern portion of the system that has held in place just off the coast of NC for days.  It has been very windy / appears foggy - very overcast / "spitting" rain at times - with no significant downpours IN THIS AREA.
We have not had any flooding HERE.   The accumulation has come over a period of 4 days, so no downpour events have caused any flooding.//
AGRICULTURE:  Soy bean leaves continue to yellow / Dried on the stalk corn is.. well.. getting wet these days // most tobacco seems to have been harvested already // TREES: crepe myrtles are no longer blooming - leaves turning brown and falling.  Oak leaves browning and falling.  BLOOMING: osmanthus / eleagnus / golden rod / groundsel.  Society garlic is starting to show back up in lawns.  Hollies, gardenias, vibernum often throw a flower or two at this time of year, and are doing so.
There is new growth on some shrubbery - evergreens such as ligustrum, hollies, pines.  
No public event has been cancelled locally ( to my knowledge ) although - just to our north ( about 40 miles ) the college football game was no doubt impacted somewhat by the weather system on Saturday.  
Rivers are running just slightly higher, but since the rain is more 'down east' flooding from upriver is not an issue at this time. 
BIRDS:  blue jay still feeding at feeder / cardinals increasing feeding at feeders / flocks of "cow birds" showing up again / Hummingbirds - still have two females as if Sunday morning.
Honey bees are no doubt eating their stores since the weather has made it more than difficult for them to forage for days //  Temperatures have been cooler - upper 70's days / 60's at night as the system remains somewhat "stalled" just off coast. Air conditioners are getting a slight break and heating systems are not necessary at this time.

The last of the crops are varied. The fig trees are putting out puny figs, the crops all are small including the cotton fields, so there should be an over all low yield this year. The road damage from weather of last winter... is still not completed. Much regrading and pot holes everywhere. This will impact the health of cars and vechiles as people can not have thier front ends aligned all the time, thus will speed the distruction of tires and vibaration will loosen nuts and bolts holding them together. We are having to do some of that personally. Just something from this years weather that people dont think about. The run off of over fertilaztion of yards and fields is producing over growth of alge in the rivers, ditches and sounds. It seems the really hard rains of August are causing more sea vegitation to grow as the standing water was so high. Noted, buildings with vinyl siding that does not have the preventive caulking are distroying building but it is not visable as the vinyl looks good until you take it off. Bad news for all these new homes as water is leaking in... Same problem with water washing away morter from brick. They could have coated it with sealant but had not, thus the brick work is failing.

On a stone wall that encloses a private chlorinated pool ~ 5 feet from the sidewalk, observed two separate colonies of white colored rod shaped cottony fibrous filamentous growths about 8 inches above the grass attached in the crevices of the stones in the wall. Two of the pampass grass sites are known to also have underground water/utility issues needing repair.

properties.description:
Largest mushroom near park measured 7.5 inch diameter of a flat rounded circular top 5 inches above ground surface. Mushroom appeared mostly yellow/tan spongy material. One red ladybug seen in motion on a surface a few inches above ground. Last night around 7:20 PM seen ~ 20 adult geese in flight between treetops and low clouds flying away from sun. At 7:10 AM today, saw two smaller flocks of geese flying away from the sun at low altitude. Saw one hawk and one turkey vulture in flight today. In a residential pine area, measured 4 circular areas of 8 inch diameter selected for visually high number of pine cone fragments. Segment 1) one pine cone core measuring 2.5 inches long. 20 fragments or barbs of cones about 1 inch long. Segment 2) 2 cone cores and 22 fragments or barbs Segment 3) 1 cone core and 100 fragments Segment 4) 4 cone cores (2.5 inch, 3 inch, 3 inch 2.75 inch long) and 36 barbs. The measurements were taken less than 5 feet from the pine trunk of 45 inch circumference. The cores and fragments/barbs appear to be very fresh with sharp points and light colored material. Assumed to be work of squirrels, but have not visually seen in progress. Not uncommon in other areas around here. Similarly measured 8 inch diameter ground portions beneath an oak of 48 inch circumference. Nine acorn shell fragments per measurement with smaller acorns of 3/16 inch to 7/16 inch diameters and 4 acorns joined as pairs in this group. These acorns/shell fragments did not appear very fresh. Other recent findings in include a long slender bleached appearing vertebral column, scat/droppings of wild berry and meat eaters. Several areas of ground appear to have burrowing moles. Human litter includes shoestring french fries and other decaying and/or non biodegradable food products/packages in the wild. In one wooded area (shady, little wind) of the municipal drainage system of ditches, ponds and culverts, discovered a long shallow water puddle that had hundreds of small mosquitoes on the surface. Four large frogs left the water for shore when I approached on foot. Dark green filamentous algal mats with a bad smell appeared on/beneath the surface of less than half of the shallow water surface.

There has been no rain (other than an occasional "trace") at all since our last report - now rainless in past 13 days.  While hiking mountains of northern Pickens & Oconee Counties it appears that the northern parts of these counties are "abnormally" dry and this is reflected by the reduced flows we see in mountain springs and small creeks.  In our area the lack of rain is definitely showing but soil digs show the column is still reasonably moist in most places, i.e. I would say more/less "normal" for this time of year. However, dry (but not burnt) lawns are becoming more common now (and thus incipient drought conditions) in the southern two thirds of Pickens (and probably Oconee) County.

The lack of any significant recent rain has dried out the soil and lawns (except for those that are vigorously watered) are turning brown throughout the neighborhood. Healthy trees are showing some signs of stress with leaves curling around the edges. Some trees have lost most of their leaves (birches) and some are showing more than half yellow leaves. Flowers in the garden continue to develop more dried leaves although some like milkweeds are blooming. The pond is at the lowest it has been for several years and more shore becomes visible each day. There is no water flowing out of the pond and none appearing in the streams that feed it. Surface water flows appear to be nil. The stream in the backyard has some water backed up into it from the pond but no new water is flowing in. Small fish and frogs are still abundant. Deer continue to wander through our yard and keep taking their toll from the flower gardens. The hostas are now all gone. Raccoon footprints are visible in the shoreline of the pond. Hummingbirds frequent the feeder and other birds are abundant around the other feeders.

Today: Two large, slender, (~>24 inches long) slowly swimming fish near the surface of the still murky water in a pool size municipal retention pond. Right now three vultures representing two species (wing patterns of black and white diagonal patterns and black wing tips on white wings) circling at high altitude outside the window. Abundant bright yellow wild flowers are in bloom in/near the woods. Stems are about waist high, flowers have 7 to 8 bright yellow petals and are attracting a few bumblebees today.

Trees:near some mature pines with over 60 inch trunk circumferences on the edge of a parking lot, a 30 inch x 30 inch square area had over 25 small pine seedlings 2 to 3 inches tall. In the same 30 inch area, 10 open older pine cones, 3 to 4 inches long, were on the ground. In another area, 3 taller pines spaced about ten feet apart measured trunk circumferences of 32 inches, 27 inches, and 37 inches. Nearby pine straw strands on the ground had three strands and were about 5.75 to 7.5 inches long. Flowers:bright Jimsonweeds are in different stages of opening/blooming. Another widespread flowering vine has trumpet shaped orange colored blooms 3 to 4 inches long which are beginning to morph into slender green pods 6 to 8 inches long (like miniature banana shapes). Two white tail deer seen in the riparian zone near the 4 lane bridge just after sunset yesterday. Their upright white hair lined ears were the most distinguishing feature in dark. The deer snorted and ran away after exchanging glances. A small rabbit was seen near a waterhole near the same time. In efforts to conserve water by reducing toilet flushing, it has become apparent that patches of thin gelatinous appearing yellow colored bio film appear above the waterline in the toilet overnight when not flushed.

Ditch is dry. Creek is slowly flowing, water clear enough to see sandy bottom. In the wooded footpath, on a typical one foot long segment of ~ 7 feet wide walkway, it is not unusual to see more than 15 brown or yellow dry leaves on the paved footpath. Leaves range in size 1", 2", 3" and larger. Leaves crunch when stepped upon. Twigs on ground snap. A turtle was seen near the path. Turtle shell was dark with some orange patches patterned. Turtle measured ~5" long and 3" wide. Hawks screeching overhead in flight when disturbed and not alone. Singular hawks are not screeching, only when two or more are seen, or when other large birds are around.

properties.description:
The lack of precipitation is really being noticed now. The pond is at the lowest level we have seen this year. There are no creeks flowing into the pond at this time and there is no water at all in the outflow channel. The white pine trees on our property have lost a lot of brown needles. Leaves in the poplar trees are turning yellow and falling to the ground. The grass in the lawn has ceased growing in any meaningful way. The ground has hardened and is no longer soft in the the lower parts of the backyard. Flowers are continuing to bloom and we see many moths and butterflies. The milkweeds, planted to attract monarchs, have about reached their maximum height.
We have abundant evidence of wildlife in our yard - the white tailed deer continue to devastate the hostas and some other plants that suit their fancy. A great blue herron is seen regularly in the pond but where he was standing in the water earlier in the year, he is now standing on an island that has appeared in the pond. Birds of many varieties are frequenting the feeders in the yard.

This area I have been meaning to let you know, the conditions here wax and wane. The vegitation in the area is suffering as the rain comes, then doesn't for 20 or 25 days, then we get dumped on by a rain storm. The roads I mentioned in earlier winter reports, are still undegoing restoration. The car bottoms out and then its the asphalt depending on the kind of car you drive. The biggest suggestions I can make here, is they need to dig out and put a better bed of sand/clay something and pour 6-8 inches of asphault rather then the 1-2 inches they are pouring. The rain leaps the ground under the asphault shifting, and without the thicker coating the roads will never have a chance. Neither do the cars. Much of my area  looks ok... but it is not, with the spotty rainfall the crops are growing funny or dying before getting mature.

Construction is good for a change, but the heat index needs to be better looked at for some of these areas that have high humidity. There are people sick with heat exhaustion, heat stroke. Maybe if they broke the work day like they do in the south of Texas into two parts. The Early Morning, then take off in the hoter part of the day, then return to work to finish later when it is cooler for outside jobs. Just a thought,

We're a week before the equinox, but it feels like fall--low of 44° this morning! Ushering in this lovely coolness was 2 fronts that brought a total of 1.74" of rain over 3 days. The front probably also brought migrating birds and perhaps more of our hummingbirds lit out before the front. Fall wildflowers are still beautiful with many nectaring butterflies-- friteries, skippers, swallowtails, sulphurs, and a few Dianas. Despite a rainy, cool weekend, we still saw folks with tubes and rafts on the French Broad River. Our spring remains a constant quality and quantity. Black walnuts and Chinese chestnut litter the ground. A few tree leaves are falling.

Precipitation for the week totaled 1.15 //
AGRICULTURE:  corn is being harvested / soy continues to be green / cotton - most have been defoliated and the white buds are beginning to look like snowy covered fields//
BIRDS:  no noticeable behavior differences at this time - of course, no brood this late in most species / 
PLANTS: The pollen count would be up, except for the afternoon showers ( grasses mostly ) //  Ragweed seems to have finished its cycle, but the other fall flowering plants are beginning to 'head up ' / our fall blooming "New Bern Lillies" are blooming with their wispy red flowers /  Crepe Myrtles are done with the exception of an odd bloom here or there // same with Magnolias /  Abellia is blooming / Roses continue to bloom / VEGETABLES: Peppers are still producing / tomatoes are done / pole beans are just about over / carrots not quite ready to harvest / Asparagus ferns are seeding / fall gardens are being planted locally / LAWN MOWING continues - grasses are doing so well this year / Lower temperatures at night but continue to have upper 80s with high humidity and afternoon showers makes everything feel sticky / No public events have been impacted by weather events to my knowledge / River water levels remain normal / Roadside ditches are either wet, or if typical, have some small amount of standing water - meaning the ground is damp.

Birds are migrating with warblers, vireos, and others feeding especially actively in the early morning. Some hummingbirds have left; others are still here. The French Broad River is low--about 500 cfs, well below the median of 1100 cfs. Rafting companies are still taking guests down the river. Our drinking spring remains excellent quality and quantity, but we have friends whose spring has sadly dried up.

Maples and other hardwoods are showing signs of increased stress by dropping additional leaves.  Islands continue to expand in the main channel of the Catawba River in and around Belmont.  With no precip forecasted in the next week, conditions will continue to deteriorate.  Additional homeowners have surrendered to the conditions by electing to discontinue irrigating lawns ahead of the potential implementation of voluntary and/or mandatory water restrictions and upon receipt of their last water bill.

Posted 9/5/15.  Observed drought impact start date - May 1. 5.15 inches of rain since May 1 in southeast Gastonia.  Neighborhood creek again completely dry after some temporary flow resulting from brief downpour recently.  Assuming there will be no impact from tropical systems or other organized precip, as we approach the window for lawn renovation, thorough irrigation will most likely be required to prepare for aeration and seeding assuming there will be no impact from land falling tropical systems.  If drought conditions persist into October/November, homeowners with newly seeded lawns who do not have irrigation systems will once again be dragging hoses in an effort to keep the germination viable into late fall.  Water levels are now falling again in the Catawba River around Belmont after some recent rains helped somewhat.  Temps in the low to mid 90's in the past week have added "fuel" to the fire.

There is no drought in the very southern part of the lowcountry in South Carolina.  We saw our entire August average rainfall during the last week alone - 6.67", 4.33" falling yesterday.  The middle of the month was a little dry, but the beginning and end of the month was extremely wet.  This station recorded 15.09" of rain for the month.  We've had a bumper crop of mushrooms growing all over.  Gardens are watered, lagoons are high, and lawns are lush.  This station has recorded more than a 15" surplus for the calendar year so far and more than 19" for the water year with only one month remaining in he water year. The moles and rabbits are loving our yard!

About a city block away and visibly lower elevation was a chlorinated swimming pool, about the same size as the pond, with less than 5 human swimmers.

The ground is continuing to dry out. The creek and pond are both back to below normal levels. The grass in the yard is growing slowly if at all. Areas of the yard are turning brown for lack of water. We are also seeing increased numbers of leaves turning brown and dropping off the trees. The deer continue to eat whatever is left of the hostas and other plants they fancy. We have seen more humming birds in the past week than previously sighted. Perhaps they are beginning to gather for the flight south. The butterflies are gathering in a few bushes in large numbers. The milkweed which was supposed to attract Monarch butterflies has yet to do so. Most of the plants have not yet flowered so perhaps there is hope for later in the season.

The rain gods were upon us this week.  It was getting dry . . . until now.  We received 5.57" of rain this past week, of which 4.72 fell in the past two days.  We are already well over our monthly average rainfall.  We are very fortunate to have the precipitation we have had.  Rainfall has consisted of mostly late afternoon thunderstorms, consistent with a lot of moisture in the air and high afternoon temps.  Grass and lagoons are doing well, local farmers are happy, and we can still enjoy the dog days of summer!

In our case (SC-PC-1) 4.89" fell which brought total August rainfall to 5.58" which is some half inch over "nominal normal" with nearly a week still left in the month. That said, incipient drought conditions have now clearly ended here, for western Pickens County and probably the rest of the county as well.

properties.description:
We had two inches of rain this past week but it all occurred in two successive days. While the ground remains moist and soft at the surface, there are signs that plants are continuing to dry out. The lower branches of many of the plantings in the flower gardens have turned brown. We are experiencing leaf color changes and brown leaves are falling in the yard. The grass is growing slowly. The pond is full but the upper parts of the creek are dry so new water is not flowing into the pond. The water is fairly clear and frogs and small fish are visible in the water. Several turtles continue to bask on the logs by the shore. We have fresh deer tracks in our backyard every day and the hostas have been decimated by the deer. A variety of birds including humming birds continue to frequent the feeders.

Activity on the lake is winding down, fewer campers and less boat activity. Hyco Lake level is steadily slipping, now at 409.60'. Birds are much less active, except for the two hummingbirds. Not much is blooming and the vegetable garden looks pitiful - time for the fall garden. Although no fire warnings have been issued the woods are getting very dry. Temperatures are getting cooler, nice to be able to open windows and doors to let in fresh air.

properties.description:
Our moderate drought in western Piedmont N.C., which is backed by the NWS reports, began in late April and has continued until now : August 19, 2015. May @ 1.43", June @ 2.66" and July @ 3.19" were near 1" to over 2 and 1/2 " below normal. August until last night 8/19 was over 3" below normal leaving us at over 8" below for the spring and Summer of 2015. After the 1.26 " of the last 24 hrs. we are now @ close to 7 inches below normal for 2015. Strawberry, tomato, corn and soy bean crops all had devastating losses this year according to our state agriculture and local official reports. Hundreds of thousands lost in each area with millions totaled. Thanks to irrigation we had some good strawberries and blueberries but at a big cost to the farmers. Our corn crop was all but destroyed with exceptions of some small irrigated plots. Wildlife has been seen coming out into more dangerous areas for them to get water, especially deer, raccoons, rabbits, opossoms and snakes. Our main water source in Rowan County is the Yadkin/PeeDee River and has been effected but not significantly due to the Mountain areas getting good rainfall during this time which feeds the Yadkin. Yards are brown to yellow unless watered every 2 days. Fields are the same. Trees are loosing nuts at a rapid pace especially pecan and walnut. Larger heat resistant , deep rooted bushes are fairing better than small bushes. Scattered wild fires are common. Lake levels are down some  and that effects tourism for fishing and other water sports but again thanks to the Yadkin that has not been too bad.

lty
ure

properties.description:
This week has had one day with 1.42" of rain that fell in three good thunderstorms over a period of hours. Besides a tiny bit of rain 2 days ago (.02"), we've been dry. However, all conditions appear normal. The garden is thriving (trying to stay ahead of abundant tomatoes, beans, and zucchini). I am watering seeds and baby lettuce & kale plants planted for the fall/winter.

Late summer flowers are blooming: goldenrod, ironweed, and joe-pye weed, plus all the zinnias at the house. Butterflies are enjoying all the new flowers: sulfurs, fritillaries, swallowtails, skippers. Despite low conditions on the French Broad River, raft guides say it's still fun and customers are enjoying the ride. It's great weather for hiking and backpacking, as well as river fun. The temps have been in the mid 80's with lows in the 60° range (one night down to 58.6° when the humidity went down briefly). Our spring water remains a constant excellent quality and quantity, although the creek is too low to generate electricity right now.

This past week we received 0.36 inches of rain.  Grass continues to have a yellow-green color and we needed to mow this week.  We did not water our orchard this week, though we will need to within a day or so.  I did make an observation today that is outside of the norm.  About 140 feet of our wood fencing, which consists of of treated wood, made of 4-by-4 inch posts with three horizontally parallel straight-cut wood planks between every two sets of posts (the total height of the fence above ground is between four to five feet), has enough moisture removed from the soil and fence posts that there is a gap all around the 4-by-4 posts, allowing the fence face as a whole to wobble back and forth.  The gaps around the posts are perhaps a quarter of an inch or so all the way around, and I haven't yet looked at all of our fencing, which totals about just under one half of a mile.  Some poles have been wobbly before at various times of the year, but not this many all at once, all in a row at the same time.  This is an old fence, at least a dozen years old.  Many of the planks are easily broken by horses rubbing against them, and some of the poles have been weakened by ants and termites.

properties.description:
weekly report: August 9th till August 16th am:
Rainfall over the past week was 1.47 inches - all within a couple of hours at one time mid-week.// Temperatures were down about 10 degrees from what they had been - making the period more pleasant.  Winds were slightly above 10 mph most of the afternoons.  By the end of the week; watering of vegetables and ornamentals was necessary again.   AGRICULTURE:  The two farmers who have planted soy nearby both had to spray pesticide to thwart "worms" on their soy beans. ( apparently - they were done flowering - which we missed - and are now forming beans )//PLANTS: The leaf changes are noticeable, if one is looking.  That "bellweather tree" that I spoke of a while back - river birch - is turning it's leaves slightly and they are olive in color, rather than bright green.  Tulip Poplar leaves are browning and continuing to drop.  BLOOMING  - slight crepe myrtle blooms; some magnolia bloom; grasses seeding; vitex; roses; Mexican pansies. LAWNS continue being cut and are very thick in our neighborhood; WATER - we had a pressure issue this week, but that was resolved with a phone call - cause was not determined // BIRDS: barn swallows are around - seen only in the mornings and late evenings on wires / hummers are feeding a lot - ( ours are consuming a quart a day ) // The "usual suspects" are here : cardinals, blue jays; chickadees / finches ( canary and common house ); wrens; doves; we hear the quail and whippoorwills; turkeys can be seen in the early mornings/ hawks / and evidence of fox (scat); another nearby community had another alligator siting (they seem to be more prevalent this year than in the past years ); RIVER LEVELS - seem normal - wind driven as usual // No public activity has been impacted by weather related issues in any way that we are aware of // Cooler mornings ( in the upper 60's ) but rises to just around 90 degrees now during the days -forecast has a couple more days like that, then forecasting upper 80's - big difference from a month ago when it was nearer 100 than 90 most days. ROADSIDE DITCHES - mostly dry - no standing water.  MOSQUITOS - not bad yet, but their time is coming - usually September is the worse for us here - and by then, the barn swallows are gone.
Pollen levels are low right now - although are bees are foraging and bringing in a dark orange pollen at this time- our bees still have brood - which is great for this time of year - however, they still have not capped off the nectar/honey.. we are hoping for a fall harvest as we get them ready for winter ( reduce equipment on each colony ).
Worth mentioning is that we monitor for varroa mites on our colonies - while all have SOME - 25% are high enough to warrant action on our part.
We have replanted some vegetables.
Overall... to the person who is out every day, and looking -one can sense the change of the season beginning.  Seems a bit early, but the signs are there.

properties.description:
Around 2/3 of an inch of rain over tha past two weeks seems to have turned the tide from very dry conditions to normal. Prior to the storm, it was very clear we were seeing adverse impacts from lack of rain. Leaves were falling from some trees (maples), others developed yellow leaves (birches and poplars). Grass was stunted and turning brown and flowers were wilting. Since the rain, the leaves have stopped turning color and falling and the grass has resumed growing. Flowers are again appearing healthy and we are seeing quite a few butterflies and other insects. It is really quite remarkable to see the turn-around all from less than an inch of rain. We observed a doe and her fawn grazing in our backyard. There are numerous birds at the bird feeders and several humming birds continue to fight over access to the feeder.

properties.description:
In the last 11 day there have been only three days with rain yielding 1.75". Tonight it's raining. Many parts of the county have reported that the creeks have been very low. The French Broad River at Marshall is low with only 400-500 cfs. The dry weather has been good for hikers, fishers, campers, even rafters who continue to use the French Broad. Hot Springs, our closest town, is bustling with recreationists and tourists. Today's thunderstorms will bring up the creeks for a short time. Despite the dryness, all plant growth is lush, grass is growing, garden is thriving. Our spring remains unchanged at excellent quality and quantity, although our creek is too low to generate electricity through our turbine. All stations is Madison County have been getting some rain, but we seem to be recording more than the others. Our location tends to be a wet spot.

After ample rains in June and July, during the last 11 days we have received only ineffective fractional amounts of rain totaling .25" while average afternoon temperature during this time of 92.3°along with very high insolation due to lack of clud cover.  This has combine to create incipient drought conditions in western Pickens County at this time.Although pasture land still appears to be ok, tuliptrees (Tulip-popular, Liriodendron tulipifera)have developed pre-autumnal yellowing of leaves along with leaf drop.  This is an excellent indicator of drying of the soil column.  Thus, we have now entered an "abnormally dry" condition here in western Pickens, County.

Drought conditions rapidly being established at this station due to diminishing rainfall and ongoing high temperatures. At Greenville-Spartanburg Airport, yesterday was a record high 99°F. The past month only two days did not reach 90°, ranking the 6th warmest same-period since 1962.

Vegetation in exposed locations wilts daily, growing season appears to be stalled. Savannah River reservoirs are drawing down (although Jocassee appears near full pool); tributary rivers and streams are generally running at only 10% of normal flow.

Precipitation at this station recorded to date of this submission over last:
15 days - 0.28" (5% of normal);
30 days - 0.96" (17% of normal);
60 days - 7.49" (68% of normal)

We are in a drought this late spring through present.  We received no precipitation this past week.  On average we receive about four inches each month, with variability.  From May through July we received a total of 6.47 inches of rain, so we are five and a half inches our normal amount for these past three months.  (In April we received 6.50 inches, so for the calendar year we are only 4.72 inches under our normal amount.)  Grass is yellow and tan, with some light green colors.  The topsoil is dry and cracking in many places.  Vegetable garden plants that do not get watered show stress with low turgor pressure.  We watered our nut orchard twice this past week and our fruit trees once.  Several tree transplants from the spring were watered too to help reduce their stress.  With the high heat and humidity, we have been careful to ensure our outdoor animals (chickens, horses, and alpacas) have had water and shade.

The last 10 days have been DRY. We had one significant thunderstorm July 24 giving us .78". The total for the past 10 days is 1.02". Besides watering the seedlings I recently planted for fall, there is no significant effects of the dryness. The garden is thriving (beans, tomatoes, cukes, squash, beets, & okra all demanding to be picked.) We harvested the rest of our onions and it's good that they were dry at the picking. The French Broad River is low, running at about 700 cfs. All the river rafting companies are still doing well. They just try to talk up the duckies, instead of putting several people in rafts that can get them hung up on the rocks. We turned off our microhydro today since the creek is low. But our drinking spring is unchanged in quality or quantity. Life in the woods seems normal. This year's turkey chicks are growing up. The wildlife camera shows the movements of a yearling bear and young coyotes. Feeder birds are actively devouring sunflower seeds and hummingbirds are draining the quart feeder daily.

properties.description:
weekly report//  The week was hot and muggy.  On Thursday, rain was predicted for 3 pm.  It started raining by 7:30 in the morning. SEVERE storms from 10:30 till noon. ( area tornado warnings).  We happened to have to drive during this, and witnessed street flooding.  I would estimate that in 1-1/2 hr. period, that 2.42 inches of rain fell.  More later throughout the day.  Now, three days later, while there is still some water in roadside ditches, all other areas have been absorbed.
It was certainly a day that any tourism would have been curtailed.  However, public events ( normally scheduled for weekends) have not been impacted.  All here is lush and green.  BLOOMING PLANTS: crepe myrtles, some magnolias, vine plants ( cukes, squash, pumpkins); abellia beginning to bloom, as are some mums, zinnias and sunflowers, black-eyed-susan and day lilies are pretty much done for now; BIRDS: hummers still feeding in droves / barn swallow babies - last of the hatchlings are about to fly - suspect that will be the last of the brood for this year, as they normally depart by early September // Soy beans are doing well, some spraying of cotton is being done now // Local river water levels are normal//

properties.description:
The county continues to be classified in moderate drought (D1).  We've had only 2 inches of rain in the last 90 days at this location.  Leaves on some trees have begun to look wilted.  Being dependent on well water has made us cautious in water usage.  Rather than running water down the drain waiting to get hot water, we run it into plastic gallon jugs, which we use later for watering plants and refilling the birdbath.  I've watered our rhododendron bush one time with 5 gallons of water.  Otherwise, we've had no outdoor watering.  In late June, the well ran low enough (while doing laundry in the front-loading washer) to trip the low water switch on the pump; it was sufficiently recharged in about 20 minutes to reset the switch and it's been fine since then.  Small nearby creek (tributary to Duhart Creek) ran dry a week ago.  Wonder whether the nearby golf course has run the water table down.  Forecasts for scattered thunderstorms ultimately prove elusive--always seem to be pushed back till "tomorrow"--which never comes.

properties.description:
Continued hazy, hot, humid, windy and dry conditions with only brief widely scattered showers. Literally block to block. Lawn are brown, construction sites are dust storms. Humans and animals alike are suffering with dust and pollen allergies, including a bad outbreak of kennel cough among dogs. Creeks are low, it's a slow float on the French Broad! All season crops require supplemental watering, and house and potted plants need watering twice a day. Black Mountain, usually bustling at mid day is much quieter on the street as tourists take refuge from the sun and heat. The splash pad is the place to be! Several smile wild fires were burning this month, some started by dry conditions and lightening.

properties.categories: Energy,Plants And Wildlife,Tourism And Recreation,Water Supply And Quality
properties.description:
The last week started with thunderstorms. In 3 days (July 13,14, & 15) we received 2.85". The bullseye of the storms must have been north of here at NC-MS-19 where 4.65" dropped on the 13th for a total of 9.13" over the 3 days! The next 5 days saw next to no rain. The creeks were all running full and the kayakers were out, but there was no flooding.

Our creek surged on the 14th, so we turned our microhydro on full (a good thing since the grid power went down for several hours in the storm.) But we turned off a jet on the 17th when the creek went back down. On the dry days the temps have climbed to the upper 80's, but clouds are providing moving shade. Our drinking spring remains constant good quality and quantity.

The rain caused some of our shiitake logs to burst forth with mushrooms. The garden soil is dry on top, but moist less than an inch under the surface. All veggies are thriving. Grass is growing. Honey bee colonies are expanding. The sourwood is blooming and attracting bees. We even picked peaches last week. 

The French Broad River spiked above 3000 cubic feet per second (cfs) on July 14, then went down to less than 800 cfs. Rafting companies all appear to have plenty of customers. When the water is low, guides put fewer people in rafts and encourage those who will to use duckies or other single person boats.

Although we received 0.25 in. of rain a couple of days ago, most forecasts for rain (in the form of scattered thunderstorms) have failed to materialize at this location for the past two months.  After ample rain during April, we had only 0.48 in. in May, 1.05 in. in June, and 0.37 in. so far in July.  The NC Drought Monitor Advisory changed the classification of this county from abnormally dry to moderate drought about a month ago.  Trees are still green for the most part, but tulip poplars have individual leaves (about 1%) turning yellow and dropping.  The ornamental cherry trees (now more than 15 years old) are looking very scraggly after the extreme cold of the winter and this very hot summer.  Lawn has not needed mowing for about a month.  We're allowing some composites to head out to give pollinators some food.  Lantana plant (which overwintered and came back from roots) is also blooming and doing all right with no supplemental watering.  The soil (mostly clay) has started to crack in some places--up to 1/4 inch wide and 4 inches deep in one location.

With evaporation the humidity is very high. Found out that if people are using R-410 Regrerant in AC units, and the CF/m on AC is not ballanced right, humidity is NOT condensed and removed as it should hand houses build up humidity inside. With all the other problems of humidity, the HVAC people in Eastern NC are really not wekk edycated in this and the damage from high mosture content supports biologics so carpenter ants and termite damage is more likely. My husband just took a class on it and I had been complaining on the humidity levels (he had been down playing me until the class he took on Friday.) OUr inside house humidity has been running 65-70 % thus you have to run your AC unit into lower tempuratures to achieve reduction in the cooling of AC. (This is weather interplaying in lots of old houses here in this area) JUst FYI. The conclusion is that R 410 refrigerant is much more touchy comared to AC that uses other refrigerants. Would affect heating and cooling costs.

The very large tulip popular tree shed a lot of leaves during the last week of June; they had to be raked up.  The tree is now showing a lot of bright yellow leaves which I am sure will fall off soon.  The dogwood trees are suffering showing wilted leaves and some even became crispy.  A young dogwood tree that is 6 ft tall wilted real bad and has a lot of crisp leaves--I need to get some water to it real soon.  The in ground swimming pool had to have water added to it on Monday, as the skimmer was beginning to suck air.  Loss was due to evaporation as well as being full of kids playing that day.  The garden looks great only because it is under drip irrigation, being applied every other day.  Some cucumbers that are not being irrigated are wilted, not growing very well, and are producing only small misshapen pickles that had to be discarded.  We sure can use some rain and a significant amount of it.

The past 9 days (where does the time go?) has seen 6 days of nearly no rain and 3 days with thunderstorms that gave us 1.8". It's good for the garden, especially the tomatoes, to get dry days after a period of rain. It helps keep the early blight under control and gives me a chance to spray the organic preventive, Serenade. All I have to do is give a little water to seedlings. We did have to turn off the microhydro turbine since there wasn't enough water in the creek. However the spring maintains its good quality and quantity. Fawns are moving about with their moms. Summer flowers blooming now include turk's cap lilies, red-flowering raspberries, and monarda (red bee balm). The hummingbirds are coming back to the feeder. The French Broad River is running low, below 1000' cubic feet per second, but the rafting companies remain busy. It's a great flow for funyaks and other small boats.

properties.description:
The heat has been quite high this last 2 weeks with many days having 82-98 degrees with 87-94% humidity which affects heat index. My personal observations are that many of the crops are burning at the edges of their leafs, even with twice a day irrigation in private setings. Not so in public farms. I know of one actual case of a HVAC refrigeration technician fainting during the heat while repairing a AC unit on a Doller General. The roof was flat and tar... 6/16. His employer chose to fire him as he was in the probation period of his employment. He got off the roof safely (as he had no partner to check on him) but it took a lot of rehydration of Pedilyte about 1.5 gal over the course of 18 hours (without regard to all the water he had drank before he fainted. He was a very seasoned commercial and industral HVAC installer/repair technician. However he did not go to the hospital (as many men do not) so it will not show up as a reported incident except here. The poverty here, is such... other construction workers are subject to the same. It is a shame they do not implement what in many south Texas areas on the Gulf Coast do during heat conditions like this - which is to stop work when the temp reaches so high, and they return to work maybe 5-6 pm as the sun is much higher on their horizon... a second suggestion is to start construction on road work and other asphault/ or construction when possible at 10 pm and work until 6-8 am and this provides a much cooler environment using work construction grade lighting sources... this would not work for all trades but much of the road work could be done that way. 

No real working knowledge on what to do for HVAC Refrigeration techs on hot roofs... we have so many commercial and industral buildings that can not shut down when the AC goes out... it has to be fixed, but I wonder if the industry could barrow some ideas from the fire fighters gear for such work?

The rain and cool weather this AM is a great blessing... the plants that were showing heat damage to thier leave edges... perked up with this burst of rain and cooler weather this am. I am too new to this to make any assumptions on why this weather has been progressively too hot in the summer and very unusually cold in the winter for this area... but it is making an impact... The farmers have to be feeling it, but I am too new to the area to know any farmers yet to get to know.

The boat landing area parking lot has almost reached capacity. This year there was less concerned about fires from fireworks since we have been receiving rain. Total rainfall here in North Augusta for the month of June was only 3.11" Normal rainfall is 4.29"  You can tell that it is very dry because there are cracks in the clay soil at my new house under construction by the river that are anywhere from 1/4" to 1/2" big.  Also, pine tree needles are turning brown up in the trees and falling like crazy around the current neighborhood.  Savannah River was a muddy mess earlier in the month after almost 2.0" fell in a night of thunderstorms.  I remember that there were numerous flood warnings upstream around Clarks Hill that night.  Water in the Savannah River is flowing very clear now that it has been so dry.  The temperature reached 100 degrees last week 3 days in a row June 24th-26th.  The highest temperature reading that I saw was 102 and that was on June 15th.  There were many other days that the airport reported 100 degrees or more, but my thermometer read anywhere from 97-99 degrees.  Heat Wave finally broke on June 27th with a cold front.  Humidity was reduced with this cold front, but then it returned on June 30th along with a good soaking rain 0.58". Deer, wild boar, white cranes, & gray cranes were spotted on the pond at the new house construction.

properties.description:
This has been the driest week yet--only .48" in 8 days. I did some watering of vegetables yesterday and drained our reservoir lower than it could recharge overnight from the ram pump. The spring remains strong, but it would be best to use creek water for watering. I've replaced early spring veggies (peas and kale) with several kinds of beans. I need to water for germination. Hoping for rain tonight and tomorrow. Meanwhile the blueberries are very productive this year and tomatoes are healthier without lots of rain.

The dry, sunny weather is great for water sports. Rafting companies are busy on the French Broad River and boating enthusiasts are enjoying the river. Anglers and waders are common along the Laurel River. 

Baby birds are fledging. Fawns are emerging from thickets. Hummingbirds are still more active at honeysuckle than at the feeder, but often come to the feeder in the evening. Japanese beetles emerged last week, but are in small numbers thankfully. We switched the microhydro to the small jet to maintain a good flow in the creek, so we're generating 2.4 kw/day of hydro power and lots of solar.

The area still gets plenty of rain though spiratic and thunderstorms. Really a lot of nice weather too. The Humidity levels are quite high and the 16th of June, the temps hit over 100 in our area. My husband (Refrigeration HVAC Tech) was on a flat tar roof of Dollar General and got over heated to the point he collapsed but conscience on the roof for 15 minutes before being able to get down. 32 ft in the air. This caused shaky and dehydration symptoms we were able to treat here with Pedilyte, cool environment and rest. Took two days. The folks out here (his employer) did not even have someone check on him, make a way for him to get from the job site to a hospital. He got home by himself. This is a problem that people do not know FSLA requirements (Fair Standard Labor Act of 1938) that the department of labor is regulated by.

And the employers lack of knowledge of heat on tar roofs placed and employee in danger. 

I went to look up information on the heat index of roofing material as ACs and other things are on roofs of commercial buildings... YOu know I could not find anything. 

A roofer gets up there and puts on a roof, but is exposed to something far less hot... wood. However once tivack, tar paper, singles, tar, rock and other elements are applied these surfaces are reflecting far more heat. 

Employeers such as HVAC, Roofer Repair People need this information and instructions to do a buddy check when they have people in the field and recommendations on when not to work on things during noon day but work at night under work lights.

My suggestion.

Other then that, weather is great and balmy. Vegitation is growing great. Some areas they are deforesting around here. Don't know what that is going to do to some of the weather.

We have had only 0.37 " of rain since 4/27/15. During this 31 day period we have had less than 10% of our normal rainfall. Strawberry farms are watering their fields daily. Tomato, corn, wheat, soy bean and other important food product farmers are also spending money and time to care for their crops. If rain doesn't come very soon it will be devastating to our local farmers, dairy producers and beef cattle ranchers. Our local ponds, lakes and the Yadkin River are going down each day. The Yadkin is the only reason we aren't on water rationing yet because it is partly feed by mountain rains and the Mountains have received much more rain than we of the western Piedmont of NC. Rowan is the hardest hit of all counties, I have followed the data of our CoCoRaHS reporters. Fields and yards that are not watered have been turning brown and/or yellow. Burning permits are not being issued without severe restrictions. I personally have had to carry water to my blueberry bushes to keep them alive and they are very drought resistant and loaded with berries that I hopefully will harvest in July and August but at much higher cost. Food prices will be up in all categories due to the dry conditions. Birds are coming for water at feeders much more than normal and other animals, such as rabbits, coons and deer, are more visible coming for food and water bear yards and gardens. We in Rowan were about 2 inches ahead in precipitation going into April. We are now more than 3 inches behind during 2 of our normally wettest months.

After what seemed like months or years of ample, even excessive rain, we are now doing without.  While we are by no means in a drought, lawns are needed watering, plants are beginning to wilt / leaves droop, and the ground is hard packed again.  Rain is supposedly coming, but after weeks without any substantial rain, thunderstorms would only erode and not infiltrate.

During the Thunderstorms of Thursday... we had 0.98 in less then 80 minutes.

You know I called Wakefield Meterologist Yesterday... I have 5 tempurature devices and the local forcast for South Mills is at an AirPort in Chesapeake, VA or Coast Guard Base in Elizabeth City, NC located on the sound. Both areas get a significant cooling effect from the water and breeze coming off... but in this area of NC, much of this area is trees (the lumber industry is here for over 200+ years) and the trees are 80 ft tall. Much of the area is forested or spotty farms as they have to clear dense tree stumps for farm land here.... thus we do not get the breeze... Point: OUR Tempurature here is at least 10 degrees hotter in the summer and yesterday it was 18 degrees hotter. The meteorologist all but called me a lier. He said my instruments were not accurate, but 5 seperate devices... one NOAA authorized, 2 manual tempurature gauges, and 2 different vehicles parked with readings all reading the same are not wrong. In the sun, it was registering on the patio at 126 f, but the shade was 100 f on the manual therm was 98 f. I drive my Mercades to the sound and it is 71 degrees...

People out here have just as many heat problems as those in the city. However, since there is not as many resources and it is 15 miles in 2 directions to a commercial grocery store... in a village of 464Pop and a county of less then 10K... I don't think this is something to be ignored. They need to have temp readings away from the water with a cool breeze... it does not reflect what inland is like surrounded by 80 ft trees and no breeze... with your little village cleared and open to the elements. We don't even get the benefit of shade. Too dangerous this close to the coast with hurricanes. The roots on the trees are shallow.

So, Please... Could someone check out what I am saying. I am a Scientist by trade too! and I am not making this up and it is not one device reading this way. Some little old person or baby is going to get killed by the heat, and they are not going to know it cause the AQK will not check it out.

This is not JUST a weather issue but a Public Health Issue and I am in Public Health!

Thank You for listening.

Thanks

properties.description:
Since Nov 2014, our station has recorded below-normal precipitation for each month except April 2015, which was just at normal level. From Jan-May 2015, we have received only 12.93" of precip. which is 5.33" below average for our site. The slow, cumulative effect has been a gradual but recognizable reduction in vegetative growth and surface water flow. The effect on groundwater is largely unknown.  The trees were slow to emerge from dormancy this Spring as was the grass cover. Our meadow grass is much sparser. Some small trees simply did not survive through the winter, even though the winter cold was not exceptional. The soil is hard and cracked in places, difficult to dig. The woods are very dry; a lot of dry leaf litter which means we have a high wild fire risk.  Our springs are barely flowing. Usually they flow at several gallons per minute. The meadow creek is almost dry; it should be flowing strongly. We have noticed that deer & other wildlife are watering at the few pools that still have enough water to drink.  We are having to hand-water our garden just to keep the young plants alive. If this dryness does not end, we face a greatly reduced garden crop this year and a big risk of wild fires should we get lightning strikes or fires from careless trash & brush burning.

Summer flowers are opening pretty much on schedule, such as mountain laurel, mock orange, and Carolina allspice shrubs. Shiitake mushrooms are finally producing in a normal way (soak the oak log and pop out mushrooms in a few days). Our drinking spring remains at high quality and quantity.

Rowan open land is over 50% forests and agriculture, Strawberry farmers are now irrigating daily and have been for nearly a month. Local cattle operations have used much of their ponds for getting water to cattle and spending money on running their pumps from wells and ponds to get this to the animals. Many smaller ponds are near drying up. More birds are appearing at my watering areas out back. Lawns that are not watered regularly are turning brown and  yellow. My water bill will be at least 3 times what it normally is this month. I get water from the city of Salisbury. If we don't get a good amount of rain soon the city will have to begin water rationing. Our main water source is The Yadkin River and it is down 2.73 feet. it would be lower but some of its water comes from NC Mts. and foots hills that have had some rain. Our family pond of about 5 acres is down over 1 foot. The shallow areas will soon be exposed if conditions continue. Fire danger is at dangerous levels due to so many fields with dry grass and forests.

How dry I am. After a very nice April, May have proven to be lacking. While plants are not suffering yet, I am having to give supplemental water since there are new plants in the garden and flower beds. While no fire warning ha been issued, I am beginning to be concerned. With above average temperatures, containers need attention about every day. With crops in the fields I have already seen irrigation systems set up but none in operation. Activity on the lake has increased, both number of fishing boats and number of weekend campers. Lake level has been in a slow but steady decline, now 410.23'. Birds, butterflies and bees are plentiful.

It has been very dry these past few weeks.  We received 0.09 inches of rain this week, with a total of 0.10 inches for the past three weeks.  The topsoil is dry.  Some areas of fields that have bare soil exposed have small cracks in the ground.  Grass is not growing much and has an overall light green to slight yellow color.  We have not needed to mow this past week, which usually needs to be done at least once a week to keep up with the growth.  We have irrigated our nut orchard this past week, and watered our fruit trees.  We have needed to water plants in the garden and crops in fields.  Plants having received watering have responeded favorably with growth.  Deer have been in the fields eating some crops, which is normal.  We caught our first Japanese beetle of the season in a trap; they normally start to appear at this time of the year.  We have not had problems with our well this past week.

In the last eight days, there were three days with rain giving a little over an inch. It has felt dry since the rain came in brief thunderstorms. Although garden soil is dry on the surface, the organic matter retains moisture just a couple inches below. The forest is fully clothed with leaves. Tulip poplars & locust trees are blooming providing nectar to the honeybees. Our wildlife camera showed the typical wildlife, including black bears. The whitetail deer look a little scruffy as they lose their winter gray coats. Birds are nesting. May flowers include three orchids: pink lady's slippers, puttyroot and lily-leafed twayblade. The creek is slower. We're now using only the large jet producing 3 kw per day. Our spring remains high quality and quantity. We went rafting on the French Broad River last week. The river was moderately low, but a lot of fun.

The yard is drying up nicely and there are no muddy spots left to dirty shoes. The stream flow has reduced this week but it is still flowing clearly. There are still many small fish seen in the creek, darting back and forth. A bit of patience is rewarded by frogs moving about along the creek banks. The pond is full and the turtles are still sunning themselves on the fallen logs in the pond. A very large (>25 pounds) snapping turtle died of unknown causes this week and floated to the shore in our backyard where his corpse drew the attention of bugs, flies, and dogs. The body has been disposed of. Birds are continuing to flock around the feeders. Some Northern Flickers and a Red-bellied woodpecker are fond of the remains of the winter suet cakes while smaller finches are more attracted to the thistle seed feeder and sunflower seeds. The yard is growing well and many flowers are blooming in the gardens which makes for a pretty sight. Leaves on the trees are all fully developed.

After two consecutive months of cloudy rainy weather for the months of March and April, there finally was a two week period starting the beginning of the month of May with bright sunny days consecutively.  Total rainfall in March was 3.12" and total rainfall in April was 3.60"  March rainfall was actually below average, normal rainfall is 4.17" and April rainfall was above average, normal is 2.83"  Today was the 1st day with measured precipitation for the month of May.  Today a thundershower developed and dropped 0.10"  I was happy to get a break from watering my tomato plants.  Other plants that are blooming flowers now are magnolia's, jasmine, amarillo's, & gardenia's.  Tomato plants were one inch tall when I planted them 3 weeks ago.  This week they are about a foot tall and my cherry tomato plant has yellow flowers on it, and my better boy tomato has flowers on it as well.  Despite the lack of rainfall for the past two weeks, leaves still look bright and green in all of the trees.

The freshly tilled fields with the transplants standing at attention in neat rows with no weeds. Beautiful. There has been  much activity on the lake. Since my last report Hyco Lake reached a peak of 410.49 on April 20 but has dropped to 410.29 today. We have not received much rain lately. The garden was not dry as it is heavily mulched but some is needed soon. So far no effects from Tropical Storm Ana this far inland. All the standing water in the ditches has disappeared. Butterflies have arrived in profusion and enjoying the flowering plants in the yard. This has been an extremely beautiful spring. Strawberries are abundant and delicious. The farmers market is very busy. Hoping for a good growing season for field crops and home gardens.

With only 0.01 inches of liquid precipitation we received these past two weeks, twice this past week we irrigated our orchards and watered the crops in our fields.  We harvested our hay crop on Monday; we are not able to compare this year's harvest of square-bales to last year's harvest as we round-baled last year.  Grass is less green and lush as it was several weeks ago.  Fireflies were spotted for the first time this season on May 6th, in the late evening. properties.description:
May began with .22" of rain from off and on showers. Then we became mostly dry for 6 days with temps in the 80°s. Yesterday a thunderstorm dropped a quick quarter inch of rain. 

All of our typical summer birds have returned and most are nesting. Gray tree frogs and spring peepers serenade through the evening. Our trees have mostly leafed out and the spring wildflowers are fading. Yesterday I went to Mt. Mitchell, at 6683 ft, where no leaves were yet on the hardwood trees. I estimate the the leaf line is about 3500 feet. Above 3500 feet there are no leaves; below 3500 feet the leaves are coming out. At about 2000 feet, the leaves are fully out.

Our creek is flowing less with the lack of rain, but we still have both jets on the microhydro for 6 kw of power. The spring is unchanged in quality or quantity. I rafted the French Broad a few days ago and the river was a little low, but very runnable. The rafting season has started.

properties.description:
weekly report: Rainfall over the week was only .52 of an inch, although four days were impacted by weather events.
High winds added to ground surface drying.
Immediately located agriculture - fields are still not being planted at this time.
We have a ditch that is over 4 feet deep - there is still water standing at the bottom of this ditch, however, even rain events have not hampered planting of garden or flowers.
All trees are now leafed out.  Sadly, the Nellie R Steven flowers were impacted by a freeze last month, so there are only a few flowers - the Savannah and Foster hollies are starting to show signs of flowers to come.
Birds not previously noticed but now identified on our property include Thrasher, and Blue Grosbeak.  The Blue Jays are flying in pairs; and the cowbirds are still making pests of themselves.
Red Crimson clover is nearly finished blooming - although all types of bees are still foraging on it.  White clover is now abundant.  It appears that the privet is about to bloom; the "red-tips" are in the last week of their bloom.
Last week was very cool, and wet, and chilly with the wind. This week the temps are warming into the 80's daytime, and low 50's at night.  Grasses are growing well.
Spring festivals and public events were slightly impacted by heavy rainfall on Friday, but the weekend was perfect for all of them ( BBQ, Strawberry  Festivals )
Pollen levels are being reported as still on the higher end of the spectrum, but it is not as noticeable as it was just 2 weeks ago.
Low energy usage on a/c or heat ( needed to use heat last week).

Weather has been moderate and providing frequent enough rain without it being too much for trees, grasses, and the beginning of crops to grow. Have noticed for some reason, many farmers still have not tilled thier fields. Not sure why. Started to see pollenators out, but not many blooms yet, still a bit early. 

Roads are still being repaired from freezes, and many piles of asphalt have had to be pulled up to just flat replace the roads. I don't think they put enough ground crush stuff and thick enough asphalt to really prevent cracking and needs for repair compared to other places on major roads. But I am not a civil engineer. (I will ask my son who is asphalt certified and a soil engineer elsewhere to see if he can help me) Groceries are very high and are having to be imported from many other places just for vegetables and fruit such as Indonesia and Vietnam, that is pretty far for North Carolina to get fruit and veggies.

We are continuing to have plenty of precipitation and are above average for the year. This leads to vigorous new growth of grass in the lawn, flowers in the flower beds and the leaves of trees are developing. This growth, in turn, has served to prevent the lawn from becoming a muddy quagmire as it was earlier in the year. The creek is full and flowing clear. The pond if full and we see daily visits from ducks, geese, and a great blue heron off our back deck. Deer are crossing our back yard in the morning and late afternoon. The milkweed that was transplanted to the back yard last week is adapting to its new surroundings. We hope that it attracts the monarch butterflies on their migration and through the summer.

properties.description:
This week's total precipitation came to .69 / and that was spread over there days of the seven.
Suddenly, EVERYTHING is growing rapidly; as day time temps remained moderate and night temps were warm.  Overcast days made for great growing conditions, although the winds have been a bit on the high side.
Agriculture:  seems as if nothing new happened this week.
Birds: a female hummer showed up at the feeder - joining the two males that arrived nearly two weeks ago; cowbirds dominate; chick-a-dees are still gathering nesting materials; barn swallow population is higher, and most have a hen sitting on her nest ( although no eggs YET );the yellow canary finches are abundant now too; turkeys have gotten spooked as it is hunting season, so we don't see them as frequently as we had been.//  
Flora and Fauna: Crepe Myrtles are leafed out now, and most oaks are on their way too; fig is just starting to leaf out; cedars have little blue pods on them; the "red tips" are about to bloom; dandelions are done, as are the society garlic; now it is time for the clovers - red crimson and white dutch in abundance; ( this makes our honeybees very happy with plenty to forage on ); the wild wisteria in THIS area has not been abundant thus far; 
Because of overcast days, we are still able to grow lettuce etc., however, the summer crops are starting to break the ground now too. ( cucumbers, squash, beans )
Centipede grass is nearly 100% green now - that means mowing has returned to neighborhood activities.  
We still had the opportunity to be digging some holes, so we could see the water levels ~ and it varied across our 10 acres ~ from as high as 6 inches to 18 inches. Roadside ditches have a prevalent small amount of standing water in them.   
It is an active season for community events, and it we have participated in some.  Soft rains have not hampered attendance.
The fire ban at our area was lifted this week, and it was a perfect time to remove debris ( ice storm of Feb 17th).
We are expecting rain in higher amounts over the next 24 hours, but as it is now, the local river levels are not excessive - creeks are flowing still.
Pollen levels are decreasing from some ( pine primarily is the visible one), but oaks, and late blooming maples still are productive)  Choke Cherries are blooming this week.
There has been no stress on heating or a/c systems this past week.

properties.description:
It's been a two week period for this report:  This covers from March 22nd through April 1st 2015
Ups and downs in temperatures were an issue; as were high winds ( steady at 20 or more mph on some three or four days during the two weeks).  Surfaces dry out quickly, but ground water remains high.
The farmers in the last two weeks have applied herbicides, and then at the end of the period, some have started to apply what appears to be lime. No tilling or planting as of yet.  The Weyerhauser forest that was cut down throughout the end of last year, has not been replanted as of yet, although the equipment to do so is standing at the ready - apparently waiting till the troughs dry out enough for them to work.
Blooming around here now is popcorn spirea, phlox, dandelions, crab apples
The strawberries are just now starting to blossom.  The hollies are NEARLY there - but not yet
The pears and plums are done - forsythia still showing but dwindling. Some daffodils still in bloom, but most are done.
Carolina Jessamine is starting to bloom.
As of April 4th, the pine pollen is JUST starting - oh yeah - we can now look forward to two weeks at least of yellow green dust on EVERYTHING.
Centipede grass is just starting to green up, and will continue as the night time temperatures are expected to be around 60 degrees over the next week.  That means mowing is coming soon to our list of activities.

This week, on April 2nd,  the Barn swallows showed back up.
There is an abundance of doves, mockingbirds, chickadees, cardinals, finches of numerous varieties, and some blue birds, as well as kill deers.
Wind action has caused some creeks and river edges to go dry ( as is the situation when it blows for a long time out of the SW here ) Effects some areas with dry beds - and of course others get high water.  All wind related.  In fact, a small inflatable capsized on our bigger river and one person is still missing over 24 hours later.
Outdoor fire bans continue for our county due to winds and surface low humidity.

Predicted rain in the area did not materialize, at least not to the extent first thought - so many outdoor activities of the Easter weekend have been reported to have been well attended.

properties.description:
We've had a total of 1.94" of rain over the last 9 days (oops, the time got away from me). The rain mostly came in scattered showers with time to garden in between showers, until today with all day rain. Tonight the rivers are very full. The French Broad is rushing through the trees. All the moisture makes plants grow quickly--lots of new wildflowers, including three species of trilliums, bellworts, and several species of violets. Golden ragworts fill the open areas; dogwoods and redbuds fill the mid-canopy. Summer birds continue to return including broad-winged hawks and ovenbirds. (Hummingbirds should be here soon. They're a little late.) The microhydro is running full at 6 kwh/ day. The spring's excellent quality and quantity is unchanged.
