The conditions around here are still quite wet from last week. Puddles in yards, fields and all the ditches are full. A real sticky mud making large equipment like cranes tractors, and other machinery that would normally do contracting, is still shot dead. Some people are using kinda like those pallets that they lay out in squares. (I am sure for construction) but they are cumbersome and had to work with.Some of the cone, and barrel pylons in the streets that are damage or they were working on is very confusing. Have seen a couple of accidents like that, and almost in one myself. This was the first warm weekend to work in the yard, building a coupe and cleaning up weeks. In putting the fence together, we went to Home Deport 22 miles away, and noticed, they have all their bare root roses (unsold) and they are trying to grow. (This is not good as they are packed in would shavings and have no nutrition for the plant grown support - these roses should be gotten rid of. They did have a smattering of some winter plants but non of the spring ones really. There were cashiers and employees standing around as no one was there and on 5 O'clock on Sunday on a pretty day, the place should have been busseling. The tree limbs that had fallen all around the road ways 5-7 in limbs, for the most part have gotten picked up. However there is thick sticky mud everywhere. I have know idea of the cost, but just the plants at Home Depot that can not be sold are a small fortune.

The last several weeks, the warmer weather has brought lots of mud and stuff. Road crews are all over trying to get huge pot holes repaired caouse of the ice/then melt/then ice weather of Jan, Feb and Mar... it is creating road hazzards and probably dangerouse for crews, as even the detours have detours.

People on Creigs list in this area a giving away trees that have fallen to any one who will just come and cut them down and get them out of there yard.

Construction is behind so now all of a sudden with the weather better, everyone is working who was previously just waiting for return to work calls. Those going back to work are being asked to do tons of overtime because commercial jobs are behind schedule. But am thankful for all the work my friends and all are getting cause 2-4 months of unemployment has affected not only the jobs, but when your laid off, you have no medical benefits. With the IRS imposeing the Health Care Mandates, these kinds of workers have not only have been without employment, but health insurance too, now a fine... That is triple jeopardy, just cause of the weather this year.

Well, the usual.. plants are growing, have not lost much it seems from the weather... 

I am not sure about farmers cause I have only seen one farmer getting out to plow the fields which I think is strange cause most would be chomping at the bit to get things started.

The spring parade continues  with new wildflowers blooming and returning birds, like black-throated green warblers. The microhydro is running full at 3 kw/day. The drinking spring remains constant high quality and quantity.

Fishing equipment rentals, fishing lessons, refreshments, hiking, nature walks and boating lessons are also seasonally available at these two lakes if the weather permits. In the "energy" category, this provides diversity in terms of alternative sources, costs, efficiencies, back up, availabilities, etc. For potential drought relief response efforts, it complicates matters due to unknown or undiscovered side effects on health and the ecosystem from the use, transportation, storage and byproducts of newer alternative energy sources. Newer untested fuel usage creates labeling, storage, transportation and hazard notification issues. Yesterday, for the first time, I saw an estimated >100 small minnows swimming in a shallow slow moving/stationary ditch. (did not disturb or touch minnows for classification). I spotted the first butterflies of the year--2 anglewings, probably question mark butterflies. Periwinkles are blooming and bloodroot flowers are on the verge of opening. The wood frog tadpoles are beginning to emerge from the eggs. The garden is wet, but workable. Peas, beets, spinach, kale, and other greens have been planted. Our first shiitake mushrooms have emerged, although they're slow in opening. The microhydro continues to produce 6 kw/day. The drinking spring remains high quality and steady quantity. There's nothing like delicious mountain spring water!

properties.description:
I sit possible for March to come in and go out like a lion?  Beginning to think this is happening. So many plants are in bloom - forsythia, camellias, quince. Then there are Bradford pears plus others showing signs of color or tassels hanging down like drop earrings. Tulips, hyacinths, jonquils along with crocus popping up in beautiful spring colors. In traveling around my home county plus several neighboring counties ponds and streams are very full plus water standing in some roadside ditches. Very little plowing has been done in the fields around home and this includes my home garden. However every time I have been in a garden center recently business seems to be booming. But a local greenhouse says their crops are late maturing due to the cold weather earlier in the month. Hyco Lake has been up and down, depending on the amount of rain west of here but steadily rising the past few days to the present 410.65'. Fishing must be good judging by the number of boat trailers at the lake dock. Quite a few vehicles have been at the lake convenience store and the restaurant should be re-opening soon. Still a few campers at the lake campground.  Birds are nesting but with the last cold snap they have flocked back to the feeders. Prior to that they must have been enjoying what nature was providing. I was not seeing many but thoroughly enjoying the songs. Spring should be here soon, I hope!

I am continuing to hear as of this weekend at church the impact of the ice and rain on the trees and forests around here. (more then just my driving observation from the roads). Some of these people own acres of land and are very surprised as in the last weeks they have found branches broken from very large trees (50-80 ft) that the branch is 7 or 8 inches in diameter. There is much wood and logging going on here. I do not know how it affects the industry, if at all cause some things precieved by an observer such as a forest fire in the pined areas... may SEEM bad, but is what actually releases the seeds from the cones for new forest growth. So... I am just reporting the things I am continuing to hear. Additionally, we had nearly an inch of rain here the other day, but there are large poddles spaning 20-30 feet only an inch or two deep where the ground can not absorb the water. This land is flat and Dismal Swamp is here... but this is supposed to be by FEMA Charts a 500 year flood zone. The pot holes in the roads are horrible and have just showed up since the snow and frost. The cracks of things expanded quite a bit and the cracking and erosion on the highways is very apparent and they are worsting. You can hardly drive any road without major pot holes and potential damage to the suspension of the vehicle.

Over the past week the topsoil dried enough to be able to shallow till in the vegetable garden.
Water table remains high - ANY precipitation is a cause for puddles to form and stand for approx. 24 hours - the ground surface for days after a rain is squishy to walk on.
Birds continue to increase and nest; 
blooming plants : forsythia / pears / plums / dandelions (camellias where they didn't freeze in Feb - which they did here = no blooms this year ) Some trees are beginning to leaf out. 
As for our honey bees - they are producing a lot of brood (and bringing in a lot of pollen ); we have had to add more space to all our colonies this past week - honey flow is right around the corner. { which also means it is a time to protect against black bears - who are very interested in the protein provided by honeybee brood larvae)
On the agricultural topic - the farmers are applying pre-emergent herbicides at this time.
Logging has stopped - no replanting has occurred as of this time in this area.

This week I have been running around the area of Elizabeth City, Kitty Hawk, Hatterus, in North Carolina.. and Norfolk, Virginia Beach and Hamton in Va. The biggest things I see are abnormally large distruction of roads, minor and major roads with serious potholes. And there is so much alge, moss, fungus and other stuff. People are having during the last 2-3 months coughs that hang on and does not seem to resolve even though they go to the doctor. The warmer weather are lifting spirits as well as seeing some blue this week, but then everyone got sad again that we were getting a cold snap and wet weather. During these times, it seems people are at the end of their rope as the indoor and gray days. People here are not used to two really cold long winters here in this area and it is affecting moods, jobs and all. Several stores in Elizabeth City are closing... one is an anchor store at the small strip mall, JC Pennies closes the first week of April. It could pull down lots of other stores but the real reason is the weather and lack of employablity is creating market shortfalls.

The economy has gone on too long in this area this way. Other things that is interesting, and i don't know how much weather has to play, but some wood beams in this area got tagged with the "ISIS" We reported this to the FBI of course, but you wonder with the weather unemployment and all how much the enviromental, computer technology and poor economics are synergistically playing on each other.

properties.description:
This has been a rainy week with at least a little rain every day totalling 1.67". The temps have been mild--mostly in the 60's. Every morning sounds like spring with flocks of twittering goldfinches & pine siskins, and lots of singing birds. New spring birds include Eastern phoebes, white throated sparrows, and robins. The wood frogs called for five days, laid a few more egg clusters, and have moved back into the woods. Spring peepers are now singing. And the first wildflower of the season, sharp-lobed hepatica, bloomed on March 14. Our wildlife camera recorded a rabbit, raccoons, and a bobcat moving around last week. So good to see the sunshine today. I planted peas in the garden and I'm counting on the ground to warm up & dry off in the next few days. The microhydro is producing 6 kw per day. The spring remains its wonderful quality and quantity.

properties.description:
The past week has witnessed more seasonable weather - in fact, setting some high temperatures in the region.
Activities that should have been started weeks ago got underway ( pruning of woody shrubs; planting of peas and early vegetable crops )
Chickadees are now frequenting the feeders and searching for nest building materials.
The recent rain of March 14th has swollen the rivers - the water table is very high at the moment.
Fruit trees ( pears, plums ) are beginning to bloom  - maples are beginning to leaf out.
We noticed that our honeybees are again foraging on the teeny flowers of the arborvitae shrubs - this is about 2 weeks behind when they were doing the same last year.
The camellias will not bloom this year in our yard as the buds were frozen during the ice storm of Feb. 17th - they are now falling unopened to the ground.
Henbit and dead nettle, along with dandelions are decorating our yards and fields ( all of which the bees will forage upon )
One of our local farmers has plowed his field - don't know for certain what will be planted - likely it will be corn.

Another week that saw weather extremes. Temperatures rose to above 80 degrees, and within 24 hours were down to the upper twenties.  Precipitation was ( thankfully ) a bit lighter than anticipated with another winter storm; and the temperatures in our area stayed just above freezing.  Made for an uncomfortable period of time, but the black ice that was feared did not materialize.  However, schools and some businesses were put on yet another 2 to 3 hour delay for yet one more day.  
The water table remains high.  Rivers and streams are not yet at flood stage; a significant rain event over the next 7 days could put them there however.
All planting and normal spring maintenance has been delayed approximately two weeks due to cold and wet weather this season.
Birds continue to utilize the feeders heavily relying on human intervention; with the exception of the robins.  I should have mentioned that a couple weeks ago several of us noticed that we have an abundance of robins this year.

These roads are in Great Repair and I travel them all the time. So this observation was unusual. On my drive too, there is damage to the trees in that the branches up to 6-7 inches in diameter were broken off and some trees actually fell. These observations where on Benefit Road, Douglas Rd and Hwy 17 near the VA/NC Boarder. (all in Chesapeake area) These roads run parallel to the boarder of the two states… and is the second to the last road available to transverse Highways 168 to 17.

properties.description:
Snow this week was three times the anticipated (forecasted) depth. Instead of a dusting to 1 inch, we received over three inches at this location. 
We have had to pull the cocorahs water gauge in at times to keep it from freezing and cracking.  Temperatures most every night have caused serious concerns about black ice on the roads; schools and businesses have either been closed or several hour delays were scheduled openings.
Plows ( and logging ) have damaged the tertiary roads, so some small patching is being done by DOT.
Although it is "time" to plant some things ( like potatoes, leeks, onions, peas and set out asparagus crowns ) it is impossible to work the soil.  It is much too wet.   Lettuce and spinach in our cold frame is failing due to much colder than average temperatures.
Propane usage, which was not so high until January, certainly has increased in February. ( as the cost of fossil fuels starts to increase again after a period of low rates )
Birds are greatly using the feeders.
The red wing black birds have shown up ( in hoards as usual ); cardinals are beginning to be evident more often; pine siskin vie for time at the feeders; ( have found some of the dead on the property - perhaps from freezing or wind fatality )Grackles compete with the black birds; no sign of any blue jays ( although they are supposed to be here year round - they are not )
We are feeding our bees - and they are bringing in pollen.  We suspect that the pollen is from occasional dandy-lion, and from the evergreens.
Water levels must certainly be rising on our local rivers, although no flood warnings had been issued up to this point. The recent precip. locally, and the abundance of snow inland ( up river ) must certainly be making an effect.
We are seeing opossum out during the day foraging.
4 days after the snowfall, patches of snow remain in shaded areas despite temps. being above freezing most days - they are below freezing all nights.
We've noticed that the ornamental fruit trees are beginning to show the very first signs of buds forming.
Overall, it is very wet - and very cold. Outdoor activities are quite limited.

properties.description:
What a week!  Snow, ice and COLD. Hard to remember what "average" temperatures are like. The snow was beautiful and is good for the soil and crops. But with the cold temperatures my driveway has become a skating rink. But a benefit is the influx of birds. Quickly the seed disappears from the feeders as the hoards descend. By scattering seeds on the ground the fluttering makes the ground appear to be moving. All of us, especially the cats looking through the windows, have enjoyed the show they have produced for us. In talking with some businesses customers and hence revenues have fallen. Those who ship items via truck have had orders held up in distribution centers. A few hardy souls are still at the campground. Hyco Lake has a layer of ice, especially in the shallow areas near the shoreline. Haven't seen any ice fishermen. Power has been lost twice within the last week. That is really a safety concern in cold weather, not only for those without power but also for the dedicated utility crews working to restore it. Hats off to them. But today the sun is trying to shine and the ice is beginning to melt. Heading outside to clear a path. Gardening is definitely on hold!

properties.description:
Winter is arriving on gusty winds. Birds are very active, feeders are already empty. Our chipmunk families are also stocking up in anticipation of the pending snow. With these high winds comes the danger of fires spreading. Warnings had been issued. Earlier rains raised the Hyco Lake level to 410.62' and the cove was quite muddy. This happens when there is much rain in a short period of time. It quickly cleared and the level is now 410.47'. In observing farm ponds all seem to be quite full. With a  few warm days bulbs began popping their heads out of the soil and a few plants have begun budding out. Every day I see a few hardy fishermen at the marina. There are still some hardy souls at the campground. Fields have been plowed in anticipation of spring. Seeds have been ordered in preparation for a vegetable garden. Aged firewood is ready to be brought closer to the house to supplement the stack already here.  Thanks to the power crews who restored our electricity so quickly. We are fortunate to have a generator and fireplace so all is well. Right now we are all in a holding pattern, just waiting to see what Mother Nature brings next.

The first signs of spring were evident this week. Several clusters of daffodils/jonquils have sprung up in the gardens and although none of ours have opened flowers yet, some of our neighbors have daffodils with open flowers. Very small buds are visible on the cloned lilacs and on the maple trees. The sycamores are shedding the fruits which had remained through the winter. Deer continue to roam through the yard daily, nibbling at vegetation. We have some clusters of wild onions appearing in the yard. The creek is full and clear and the pond is also full. The low parts of the yard are still very muddy but the higher parts have dried out somewhat from the previous week. Birds are more frequent at the feeders with up to 8 Carolina chickadees being observed at one time along with the usual mix of cardinals, wrens and blue birds.

Last week, I reported that wet fuel was a factor in delaying seasonal prescribed fires.  I conducted two prescribed fires this week, both burned for wildlife and other ecological reasons. Both tracts had saturated soils and standing water.  On one tract, the fuel was primarily tall grass and fire carried very well, burning over the standing water.  The other tract had mixed fuels and mixed results.  Grass in the middle areas burned reasonably well, carrying over the standing water.  The margins had hardwood leaf litter on two sides and mixed pine and hardwood litter on another.  In those areas, wet fuel prevented the fire from carrying very well at all.

properties.description:
We have an abundance of ground moisture at this time.  Recent rains ( of 2" or less ) have produced some local river and creek minor flooding.  Basically there has not been property damage, although the waterways have been up and down within 3 feet of their flood stages
Logging continues !  
Our honeybees are bringing in pollen.  The red maples are blooming as is mahonnia, some dandelions, and apparently some other 'weed' things.  That means the queens should be laying eggs... a precarious time of year when the bees might eat up all the stores ( if they haven't done so already ) and bees could starve.  Most all beekeepers we know are now feeding their bees ( sugar syrup ).
The next months will bring swings in temperature that will effect all blossoms.  It can be brutal around here as the late winter allows blossoming, only to have winds and freezing temps take them away overnight.
Temperatures remain in the freezing level each night; home heating has been less expensive and less usage this year over last year

properties.description:
Another opportunity to observe conditions in parts of Virginia, West Virginia, Kentucky and Indiana. One word sums it up - wet. According to locals each state has been receiving ample rain. In West Virginia there was still evidence of a recent snow. Freezing rain had coated the trees in higher elevations but the roads were fine. Beautiful frozen liquid was seen in the rocks along the interstate. Streams were full and at times water in highway ditches was frozen. We even saw a few frozen ponds. After all it is winter!  At and around home, it is quite wet. I was working in the yard, took a step and started sinking. Great for the water table. Streams, rivers and ponds are at or above normal levels. Since my last report, Hyco Lake rose briefly but has settled back to 410.39'. Some days the lake is so still it looks like a mirror, so beautiful. There are still quite a few fishermen on the lake and campers are returning to the recreation area. Birds are still around, quantities not as large as in past years, but a good variety. As I write this there are 11 different ones at our feeders plus the usual squirrels and chipmunks. Everything appears to have gone dormant, about time for winter pruning. Hellebores are beginning to bloom, providing a little winter color. Still waiting for a big snow!

properties.description:
Over the past week there has been sufficient precipitation, in addition to the relatively high ground water level to produce warnings of area creek and river flood levels.  Property damage is not truly a concern, as the waterways crest and abate from 1 to 3 feet above flood stages.
Black ice once again has become a concern for the region.
Frequently, forecasters do not warn for this possibility unless freezing rain is present; while truly, water that has not evaporated due to low temperatures, refreezes causing black ice in sporadic areas.
Temperature forecasting - we live 8.8 miles from the town - where they will forecast the lows for the rural areas to be about 36 - we actually got down to 30. This is a big difference when it comes to predicting of the possibility of dangers caused by black ice ( not to mention impact on plants if a consideration - such as lettuce )

Logging continues - amazingly - one wonders if there are any trees left on the Weyerhauser property nearby.  The logging trucks roll by on about a six minute interval continuously.

properties.description:
The old year ended with plenty of rain. With many days of measurable precipitation, the ground is quite saturated. In places we've had to add extra pavers or gravel. Still some standing water in ditches. This greatly reduces the fire chances as some people are burning leaves instead of composting them - horrors!  During this time the Hyco Lake level went from 410.3' to a high of 410.71' on December 25 Slowly it has been dropping and today is 410.35'. Great for the water table and must be good for fishing. Every time I drive by the recreation area there are boat trailers. One morning this week I drove over the lake bridges quite early and the water was so still it looked like a mirror - beautiful. Birds are very appreciative of the seed we've been scattering on the ground in addition to keeping the seed and suet feeders full. Fresh water is always available but having unfrozen water has been a challenge the past few days. Finally some real winter weather has put our plants to a dormant state. The lake campground does not have as many campers as before Christmas but more than usual are still there. Seed catalogs are magically filling my mailbox and filling my head with dreams of a bountiful garden. Just waiting for a good snow - several times we have seen flurries but no accumulation. Winter is here!

Primarily temperatures have effected the area more than rainfall.  However, some area creeks and rivers did rise to flood stage; warnings were issued - but no damage or significant danger arose.
Logging continues despite slight rain or low temperatures.
Schools were opened late one day due to low temperatures ( mid - teens); the eleagnus continues to bloom on interior buds that were not frozen or frosted ( less so now than earlier in this period ).  Flu season - many warnings - many cases reported locally
Local power company  has asked customers to reduce usage to avoid power interruptions.
The past two weeks following Christmas especially is a low quantity of public events - that is scheduled to start picking up a bit over the next weeks; so impact on tourism and recreation will be impacted by whatever will come
No agriculture activities to report for weeks now.

properties.description:
This will be a snowless December with only 2.54" of rain. Other stations in the county, except one, had even less rain. (NC-MS-12 had 2.55".) Looking over our last 5 years, December has seen from 1.2" to 25" of snow and an average of 5.45" of rain. We're seen no adverse affects of the dryness. Our drinking spring remains at the same quality and quantity. We have the large jet on the microhydro creating 3 kw per day. Wildlife activity is normal: scratching wild turkeys, singing coyotes, and waddling opossums seen this week. Winter birds are on the feeder. The mild temps have encouraged winter greens to actually grow--enoying fresh salads, chard, and kale.

properties.description:
Overall, very little rain since Thanksgiving, but when it arrives, it arrives big time. Two episodes over several days each have provided nearly 10 inches of rain. Ironically, both times we have been away. So, the hypothesis continues to be supported that when I am gone, it rains. A lot. The question is how long do I have to live somewhere for the effect to take place?
In any case, minimal apparent impact in the area regarding precipitation issues. Cooler, but very pleasant, temperatures are certainly helping that issue. Many plants are dormant, others getting by on available precipitation. Very little irrigation being provided.
Have a Happy New Year.

weekly report:  With the exception of Christmas Eve, the rain received throughout the week came in small amounts that were easily absorbed.  Christmas Eve had standing water everywhere; ditches over flowing; and some inland creeks and rivers remain with flood warnings and watches as the water begins to move down towards the coast.
Temperatures have also been relatively mild.   With the holidays, we did not see any agricultural activities; even the loggers seem to have taken the holidays off.  They have some logs still to be hauled out that they cut, and the 'debris fields' left are truly unsightly.
The deer have moved some miles away towards the safety of a creek and surrounding vegetation.  Many small animals were killed during the logging ( we find them, or see the buzzards )
Outdoor holiday events seem to have lucked out in between the rain storms; and were reportedly well attended.

properties.description:
With two consecutive days of over an inch of rain each and over four inches of total rainfall this past week, it is not surprising we had some minor flooding in our yard and in the surrounding area. Some streets had up to several inches of water in them and while there were no threats to housing or vehicles, some drivers encountered hydroplaning. Water levels in the pond were up about a foot at the maximum of the flooding. The water in the stream turned to a khaki color obliterating the sight of any fish. A great blue heron spent much of the time sitting hunched over on the bank during the heaviest rains looking at the rising water levels. Aside from feeling sorry for the magnificent bird, there was little else we could do. The yard is very soft and muddy. The dog requires a good wiping down when he comes indoors to remove the dirt on his paws.

Normally when the trees become dormant we can have the turbine fully on. Although it's dry, the veggies in the cold frame need no extra water. Despite the winter solstice, the month has been very unwintery. It's a good time to finish the tasks put off by snow in Nov. & gather firewood for next year. Movements of wildlife & birds at the feeders are normal for this time of year. Our spring remains high quality and quantity.

properties.description:
What season is this? One day it's warm and sunny, then cold and rainy or some combination thereof. With over an inch and a half of rain in the last ten days, Hyco reached a peak of 410.59' but has now dropped down to 410.36'. On early mornings the water is so still is looks like a mirror. At night it beautifully reflects the Christmas decorations set on docks. There are still plenty of campers at the recreation area. They have even decorated with stringing lights on the fence. Some die-hard fishermen have been dropping lines into the lake from the shore and boats - hope they are having good luck. The major influx of winter birds has not occurred yet but the seed in our feeders and the suet is disappearing on a steady basis. Sasanguas are steadily blooming, providing some color. Nandinas, pyracanthas and hollies are producing plenty of berries - ample for decorations and food for the birds. There are still plenty of leaves and acorns are on the ground, slowly but surely getting leaves into flower beds or compost bins. Worm bins are in their winter locations and their activity is slowing down. fields are barren but are still beautiful, just waiting for snow! The sunny days are helping the tomatoes int he greenhouse grow and the strawberries have begun to bloom. Occasionally see a few good bugs in the greenhouse.  Hope everyone has a wonderful Christmas.

It's been 9 days since I've reported (Christmas busyness!), but we've had only .16", with .11" last night when a front rolled by. Despite the lack of rain, we've had heavy frosts and the soil is moist. The first 5 days of this period were cloudy with little evaporation. We had heavy fog this morning. We did turn off one of the jets in the microhydro, so generating 3 kwh per day. The quality & quantity of our drinking spring is unchanged.

wkly rpt:
Rainfall has been "just enough" to keep trees growing well.
Cover crops of clover remain green.
Soy beans not harvested remain in the fields - some was harvested though this year.  Farmers are brush hogging and disc work is being done to prep the fields for the next crops.
Logging continues in our area - very heavily.  Trucks start into the area at 4:30 in the morning, and by 6:30 they are coming out loaded... about one every 4 to 5 minutes headed for the processing plants.  It is likely much of this harvest will be put into wood chips which are being shipped to Italy as an alternative fuel source, as they have recently banned coal from use there.  Ultimately, that will have an effect on the cost of paper products in the US. These "loblolly" pines are generally use for paper products.  
Each morning here is a heavy frost  on the lawn grass and horizontal surfaces. During the day, the temperatures are up in the 50's at least.  Lettuce and leeks are growing well this year, as it has not been as cold as previously.
Honeybees continue to forage on warmer days.. eleagnus and mahonnia continue to bloom with the occasional dandelion.
Water levels in the rivers are constant and no issue.

With .60" of rain yesterday, the first week of Dec. had 1.06" of rain.  The opening of Dec. with 63° warmth was a far cry from Nov. 1 with 10 " of snow and temps in the 30s°! This last week has been a good time to gather firewood for next year's fires. This is important to us since the wood stove is our source of heat. An interesting wildlife note from late Nov: we helped a neighbor catch a bat that had come into her home and it turned out to be a silver-haired bat. The silver-haired bat normally lives in trees, is not seen often, and had not been recorded for Madison County. Our drinking spring remains constant in quality and quantity.

weekly report:  Very little accumulation of precipitation; Temperatures were moderate, and winds were not extremely high.  This is all about to change - temperatures are dropping; some fronts moving through are anticipated to bring precipitation; and at the moment, the winds are quite high out of the NE ( always makes it chilly )
Soy beans that were not harvested remain decaying in the fields ( most were harvested, but some were not ); no further agriculture activity has been observed locally recently.
There is a considerable amount of logging going on in the immediate area; always disturbing to wild life & makes a mess of mud of the roadways; causes asphalt damage too.
( 3 separate logging companies are working within 5 miles of our house at this time )
Our honeybees seem to be doing all right - they are being fed, and on those days when the weather is not prohibitive, they are out foraging on eleagnus and mahonnia - we always anticipate that the red maple will bloom early next month and that actually encourages them to start laying brood for the spring -a dangerous time as an early increase of brood can have them eating up all their stored honey.  Without our feeding them additional sugar syrup - they could starve.
Rain showers impeded several holiday parades and flotillas over this past weekend.  River levels remain normal ( for now) although wind driven surf can cause localized flooding.
The weather had been pleasant enough that many holiday decorations were put outside over the past week ( following Thanksgiving ).
Ground moisture remains constant.  Digging down a foot had us hitting water.

With almost three inches of rainfall in the past week we even experienced some minor flooding in the low areas of the yard. One area was too muddy to rake the leaves today. Banner rainfall this weekend for much needed rain!  Saturday the lawn was so dry, the lawnmower kicked up dust, the lagoon levels were way down, and everything was beginning to go dormant.  In about a 36-hr. period we received 2.07" of nice soaking rain, exceeding the entire month of November rainfall.  It was the first meaningful rain since October 21.  This morning, it is very mild, the lawns are greener and the lagoons are up.  A near 3 acre lagoon next to our house has risen to the top of the drain grate and is trickling slightly over the top.  A great time to be thankful.  Happy Thanksgiving everyone.  Next report in 2 weeks.

weekly report:
There hasn't been much precipitation; although the next four days predict soaking heavy rains.
Agriculture:  Freezes have curtailed the NWS from issuing any further warnings as the growing season is officially ended.  Soy beans are being harvested ( yesterday ) in a rush to beat several sequential days of rain.
Temperatures have been much cooler; with some overnight lows in the upper teens and lower twenties - which is unseasonally low for this time of year.
As for our honeybees - they are now being fed sugar syrup - although they may not quite need that yet. However, several very cold nights, followed by multiple days of rain will keep them inside and unable to forage ( or defecate for that matter )
Blooms remain for them to forage upon when temperatures exceed freezing: camellias; eleagnus; some dandelions; mahonia.
Area river levels are being effected more from winds than accumulated rainfall at this point ( subject to change starting today)
Air and road travel will be effected by heavy downpours, but thankfully no freezing ( ice or snow ) is predicted for this upcoming holiday week.
Happy Thanksgiving everyone !

properties.description:
What season is it?  One day we're in the 60's or 70's, next day we hardly rise above 40. Chilly days mean warm fires, thanks to my wonderful husband. Leaves were about a month late in giving us a good color show. Lots of leaves are still on the trees. But more leaves and acorns have already fallen than usual. We were quite dry - bad for fall plantings. But then almost an inch of rain fell. HURRAY! On another day we saw about a dozen flurries, extremely early. What a November! Hyco Lake level had been steadily dropping but that trend was reversed with the large rain. Current level is 410.02' While there are still a large number of campers at the recreation area this is due to work in the area. But not unusual to see a fisherman or two about every day. Bird feeders are ready but the usual winter birds have not arrived yet. Maybe the weather fluctuations are confusing them also. Except for winter cover crops, large fields are barren. Several have recently been plowed which creates a wonderful fall picture. Hope everyone has a wonderful Thanksgiving.

Things were drying out considerably since mid-October, only 0.20" in the month before the system that hit this past weekend delivered 1.84". The dry-out fit nicely with our stream and river work, allowing our DNR crew to collect fish and habitat data at baseflows. It also seemed to make for a beautiful fall color season.

In September we had a total of 7.89 inches of rain, with only 7 days in the month having no precipitation. As a result, the ground continues to be moist, and I continue to see standing water in some undeveloped low-lying lots.  Hopefully, two consecutive months with good rainfall (in August I recorded 12.07 inches) has created conditions that will reduce the risk of drought as we go into the fall season. 

--

Total rainfall for the month of October measured 0.68"  Normal rainfall for the month of October is 3.27" October was a very dry month.  The month ended very warm as well.  IT was 80 degrees on October 30th.  The month of November started out wet and cold.  November 1st an upper level disturbance moved through and there was snowfall reported in the cities of Evans, Edgefield, and Aiken here in the CSRA.  This was the earliest snowfall on record for these cities.  Once this weather system was gone, Cold dry weather settled in across the region.  We went 16 days straight without any rainfall.  During this time the leaves on the trees peaked with color and I noticed when there was lawn work being done it was very dusty.  The dry streak came to an end this past week.  Monday November 17th a cold front brought rain to our region.  the gage collected 0.97"  Once this front passed, it left very cold arctic air in place.  On Wednesday morning November 19th there was a record low at Bush Field Airport in Augusta of 15 degrees.  The previous record was 22 degrees.  I saw 20 degrees on my thermometer here at the house. Thursday morning November 20th Bush Field tied a record low of 20 degrees.  It was 25 degrees here at the house. This is very cold for our area for this time of year.  The Normal High and Low temperature for this time of year is 68 and 41.  The Cold temperatures Killed everything in our garden.  Tomato plants just wilted.  Banana plants fried and crumbled, trumpet plant got hit and amarillo flower plants bit the dust too.  Bright green grass in the yard is now spotty with brown patches from frost.  2.82" is the average rainfall for the month of November for this area.  More rain is forecasted on Sunday so maybe the month will end with average precipitation.

This past week has continued the dry trend we have seen this past month.  We received only a trace of rainfall during the day of Friday the 14th.  There are no standing pools of water on the property.  The first three inches of topsoil across the property are dry.  We did not irrigate our full orchard this past week.  We did water 36 new saplings, though.  There have been no signs of heat or water stress on plants this past week; it has been hard to tell with plants going dormant.  Deciduous tree leaves continue to change color and fall.  The various varieties of oaks seem to hold on to their leaves longer than the maples, chinese chestnuts, and pecans.  Pines needles continue to fall lightly.  Plants are exhibiting normal behavior.

properties.description:
We have measured only 0.69 inches of rain since the beginning of November and it is starting to show. The ground is drying out, a hole dug in the yard (by our dog) shows only dry dirt 12 inches below the surface. There is still water in the creek but the pond level is down about 6 inches from full. The water in both the creek and the pond is still black in color. The leaves continue falling with increased volume. Some trees (river birches) have shed all their leaves. The red maple leaves have turned bright yellow and it has lost about half it's leaves. The sycamore leaves have started curling, turning brown, and falling. Recent cold has impacted the plantings in the garden with many plants now wilted. We observed three white tail deer and some racoons in the yard this past week. There appear to be fewer birds at the bird feeders than in past years at this time.

I have observed little impact in our community due to lack of rainfall in the past few months. This in spite of dramatically reduced precipitation found at this station. Some lowering of some lagoons may be because of reduced rainfall, but could also be due to other acts since the lagoon levels are managed. They are frequently lowered during times of construction in the community.

Water quality has been apparently unaffected (we have seen impact in the past from too much rain and the resulting floods negatively impacting water quality at the tap).

The total amount measured here for August was 3.98 inches; 6.65 inches for September. There was measurable or trace  precipitation every day from September 23rd to the 30th.

Then the switch was turned off...

There were only 3 days in October with precipitation, totaling only 1.19 inches.

To date there has been only .05 measurable inches of precipitation in November.

Fortunately all of this corresponds to reduced temperatures, too. So the recharge in the summer months may have been helpful. Particularly since the total for all of October to this date is only 1.24 inches.
 
Of course, that could be up to 12 inches of snow, but not likely here in the low country.

properties.description:
It's been a dry week with only 0.12" of precip and a roller coast of temps. On Nov. 10 & 11, we enjoyed sunny, warm days of 66°. Yesterday the high was 27.5° with a low of 16.5°! The cold brought in winter goldfinches (changed to winter plummage) and purple finches. The most commonly seen birds are juncos that are only here in the winter. Our resident birds include Carolina chickadees, tufted titmice, N. cardinals, Carolina wrens, and mourning doves. The light snow yesterday surprised me. We now have a full white cover although we only received 0.5" of fluffy snow. We still enjoy fresh salad greens from an unheated greenhouse and cold frames. We had to reduce our microhydro input to the small jet producing 2.4 kwh of electricity. The quality and quantity of our drinking water spring is unchanged.

wkly rpt: 
Temperature, more than precip. has been the driving force for outdoor activities over the past week.  Early on we saw our first freeze ( freeze - with frost )
This was also the first time we had to turn the heat on in the house so far this year.
In reality, we could use some rain for fall planted items such as shrubs, trees, ground cover crops etc.
The ground is holding some surface moisture due to cloudy days and cooler temps, so nothing is suffering greatly at this time.
Soy bean remains in the fields - not yet harvested, however it is totally dry.
River levels are lower, and driven by winds at slight tidal influence.
There is an upsurge in the sighting of fox presence.
Being that it is now (deer ) hunting season locally, the wild turkeys are seldom seen.
Locally, the crepe myrtles have lost their foliage.
(Bradford) pears are turning their brilliant red.
The oaks are holding their leaves; the sweet gum have turned red and will be dropping within days.
A front that came through about 10 pm on Thursday night had extremely high winds locally. There was no damage, but we did lose electricity for approx. 2-1/2 hours.  The electric company reported that a fallen tree had damaged their equipment.

Most of the trees in our yard have either dropped the bulk of their leaves completely (river birches), or have turned brilliant colors typical of the season (sugar and red maples, hickory and tulip trees) with the exception of the sycamores who apparently are still unawares the seasons are changing. The sycamores continue to have full green leaves. Despite minimal rainfall in the past week, the other plantings do not show any signs of lack of water. The grass is growing well. The stream and the pond water is black, even blacker than it was last week. This is not due to runoff but appears to be typical of this type of waterway in the fall.

properties.description:
This week has been relatively dry with 0.3" from another 2.5" of wet snow, plus .38" of rain. The 10" snow melted over 5 days saturating the ground. We turned on our turbine fully to make a continuous 6 kw. Since we use less than 6kw to run our household, the excess will go back to the power company. Temps have been cold--down to 24°--but the wood stove keeps us cozy. A drive down into lower elevations last week revealed beautiful fall colors from maples, oaks, and beeches. While we still have some leaves on the trees, the colors have subdued after the cold and snow. The heavy snow on leafy trees broke down some large limbs, especially from the Chinese chestnuts, and snapped a couple small trees (yellowwood & sumac). Our drinking water spring quality and quantity is unchanged.

wkly rpt:  This has been an interesting week.  Until mid-week, the temperatures were even a bit higher than normal. Very slight precipitation accumulated.  A lot of last minute "winter prep" chores being done in the region ( shutting down outdoor water systems etc )
The soy bean fields are dried brown, but harvesting has not yet begun. Field prep ( disc ) for possible winter wheat has begun.  
Thank goodness, the winds ( and now the cold temps ) have finally gotten the mosquitos away from us all.
Tonight we are expecting our first frost ( actually a freeze).  Turned on our indoor heat for the first time this year just this morning.
Most all of the beekeepers have harvested any honey; prepped their hives with entrance reducers and reduced quantity of space - some are already feeding.
Local rivers are neither high nor low - but wind is pushing water around to cause some localized flood issues ( not much )

properties.description:
Had I written my report yesterday I would have mentioned that 70% of our trees are bare, although the beeches and oaks are golden to  russet and scarlet. However today it looks like winter--we got over 10" of snow last night!   It's a wet, heavy snow that took out our Internet most of this day, as well as breaking some small trees. I gleaned the last of the summer garden yesterday (a 5 gallon bucket of peppers, a basket of salad greens, and 5 gallons of grapes.) I also picked kale & carrots & covered the broccoli & cabbages. Wet snow soaks slowly into the ground and effectively recharges the water table. When this melts we'll like turn all of the turbine (only small jet on now.) Our drinking water quality and quantity is unchanged.

weekly report ( a bit late );
This has been a "chamber of commerce" fall season week.
Downright chilly at night ( upper 30's/lower 40's) with day time high temps near 80 degrees.
Tree leaves are turning colors; golden rod is nearing the end of its bloom; birds feeding is slowing ( seeds readily available wild now ); tracks show deer foraging ( on our "planted for the bees" clover; 
Honey harvest was reasonably good this fall. ( approx. 50 lbs per hive - normal )
We could use a bit of rain.  However, the ground is not terribly dried out.
Soy bean leaves have turned near to brown, and are finally starting to dry out.  An anticipated first frost coming this next weekend will bring that to culmination and the rest of the tree leaves too.

Nice week around here.

properties.description:
Just returned from a trip from NC through the mountains of Virginia and West Virginia then through Kentucky to southern Indiana. This trip consisted of traveling in USDA hardiness map zones 6 a and b plus 7a. Fall leaves were pretty but a little pas their peak. very disappointed in the lack of reds and oranges on the trip up but some more returning on the same route. Everything looked very lush. Talking with locals along the way most said they had been receiving ample rain. Those in southern Indiana said landscape plants and lawns required very little supplemental water during the summer. Most farm ponds looked at or slightly above normal. At Hyco the lake level rose considerably after the heavy rains in the middle of the month. After a rapid increase, the level reached a peak on the 16th at 410.58 and has been slowly but steadily dropping every since. Even with the large rain the lake stayed clear. There are still many campers at the lake campground due to various construction projects int he area. Hummingbirds and butterflies are gone for the summer. Mums are in full bloom now, leaves are rapidly falling, acorns abound. Early morning find "fog" on the lake due to the cool air temp mixing with warmer water temps. With cool nights,pumpkins galore and most money crop fields empty, it's definitely fall and time for Halloween.

properties.description:
The past week has been dry--no measurable rain for 8 days and a lot of sunshine. Fall color peak was last week here at 2,000 feet although it was subdued this year. There's still plenty of color now. Many beeches are gold to copper, oaks are turning brown & red, hickories & birches are golden, and red maples range from deep yellow, through orange, to tangerine red. Witch hazel is blooming, but wildflowers have turned to fluffy seedheads. Several phoebes were around last week, but gone today. Despite the lack of rain, the small jet on our microhydro is producing 2.5 kw/day (the trees are no longer sucking up all the ground water). While cleaning up the garden for winter, I noticed moisture less than an inch under the surface. Winter veggies are growing well. The quality and quantity of our drinking water spring is unchanged.

Some leaves continue to turn yellow on a few poplars and birches but we have not yet seen any significant leaf colors or of leaves falling. The hardwoods remain green as if it was June or July. The small fish (minnows?) in the stream appear to have grown in size and are averaging over an inch long. The new grass planted several weeks ago continues to flourish.

properties.description:
Mosquitos are horrible this year - everyone is commenting on this
Getting cooler overnights 
Soy bean leaves definitely turning yellow now
Crab Apple trees have mostly shed their leaves already
Poison Ivy leaves starting to redden
Although there was severe storms in the Midwest during the week - they petered out before they made it to this eastern Carolina area - we got less than 2 inches of rain, and no damaging winds
Hurricane in the Atlantic ( hits Bermuda hard ) had little if any effect on the coast (maybe surf /rip tide issues - but little noted )
Sharks on shore at Cape Lookout - likely chasing blue fish was noted on local and national tv
Generally - this has been a week of beautiful fall weather for this general area

With about an inch of rainfall last week, soil moisture in the vegetable garden has improved.  At Roxbury Park in Meggett a week ago before the recent rain, there were very few mushrooms.  Back at the park this weekend after the rain, I anticipated more mushrooms in the park but didn't in fact observe them.  While I was there, Ken Carmen, the park naturalist, told me about a small depressional wetland that has been ephemeral in recent years (drying up part of the year) but this year has retained water the whole year.  It's filled with moss and attracts song birds for bathing.  That day, he'd seen at least 6 different species bathing, including some that are otherwise rare in the park this time of year.

properties.description:
Ah, wonderful rain, even if it did cause an hour delay in the football game I was attending. Hyco Lake level had been steadily dropping and local farm ponds were showing serious signs of lowering. But after 1.56" of rain, things are getting better. Established plantings were showing signs of distress, more birds were spending time at the bird baths. Recreation campground still very active with lots of campers but not much traffic on the lake. Soybeans look like they are close to harvest but have not heard any forecast for that crop. Trees are showing more color each day. After a warm few days and nights, the feel of fall has returned.

properties.description:
mostly a dry week, but dew and standing moisture has made for a bumper crop of mosquitos.
Our dog is extremely ill - and we feel it might be a mosquito born virus - stomach.  hasn't eaten in over 7 days, hard to get her to drink water.  Vomiting anything that goes in.  Vet reports many dogs with similar symptoms.  Our dog does not interact with other dogs.
Sigh.
On the agricultural front - both the corn and the tobacco have already been harvested, we have planted clover for next spring's honey flow.  So we needed that rain.
Cooler temperatures at night, but the days have still been in the 80's.
Soy bean leaves continue to yellow, fall is on its way.

properties.description:
wkly rpt:  This past week saw both secondary tobacco harvested and corn harvested locally.  The soy bean leaves are beginning to yellow. Little cotton was planted locally this year so no report insight on that crop. 
Maple tree leaves are beginning to redden, tulip poplar are beginning to yellow/brown.  Only the natchez crepe myrtles seem to be holding green leaves, all others have begun to change and fall away.  Eleagnus is blooming as is golden rod; and our honeybees are bringing in pollen for the fall brood build up.  All seems as normal as might be expected for this time of year for the honeybees.
Hummingbirds are gone now.  Wild turkey can often be seen or heard near water sources ( creeks, beaver dams).
Cooler weather for two days has brought some slight relief from the otherwise bumper crop of mosquitos this year that everyone seems to be complaining about.
Fall brings a plethora of public events and festivals; mostly on weekends.  A brief rain event on Friday evening did not interrupt these.
River water levels remain high, but not threateningly so.

The past two month August and September have been very dry here in North Augusta.  Many areas around my home where I observe have reported much more rainfall than here.  In August my total rainfall was 2.07"  in September my total rainfall was a little bit more compared to August 2.59" total rainfall.  Normal rainfall for August is 4.32" & Normal rainfall for September is 3.22"  This puts my deficit for the two months at -2.88"  There were about 8 days of observed precipitation in August, & there were 18 days of observed precipitation in September.  I know 18 days of measured rainfall seems like a lot, but the amount of rain that fell on each of these days was not very much.  Each day that I measured rainfall during September, it usually was less than a tenth of an inch.  Some things I have noticed in regards to the dry weather.  Savannah river is very low right now.  Many rocks are exposed out of the water near the bridge that crosses the river on I-20.  Pine trees are dropping needles like crazy here in and around my neighborhood. You can look up in the pine trees and see all the brown needles mixed with the green needles.  Many have been out mowing grass and preforming landscaping chores since the sun has come out the past two days.  (we had a week straight of cloudy cool weather with below average temperatures sept 23rd-29th)  I noticed a lot of dust in the air while folks were mowing.  One final note for this observation is that tree leaves are starting to show some fall color.  Tree leaves are not as bright green as they were back in August.  Finally, the traveling rain gage went to Road Atlanta in Braselton, Georgia twice in August.  Both race events saw some rainfall.  Rainfall for the 1st even at the beginning of the month was just a trace, & for the 2nd event later in the month, there was some heavy rain that fell during one night of the event that dropped 0.85" of rain.

properties.description:
Oh,is the weather ever wonderful on Hyco Lake. The campground was about full over the weekend with many people taking advantage of the sunny weather after several cloudy, rainy days. Good for the lake economy. Leaves are turning, mums in bloom, time to plant pansies. Lake level fluctuated very little over the past week. Hummingbirds are still at our feeders, storing up energy for the long flight to the winter home. Blackbirds passed through, stopping only long enough to eat our dogwood berries. The rain filled the bird baths and many birds have been enjoying the fresh water. From the number of berries on the pyracantha it's going to be a cold winter - they are beautiful now. Only hope there are still some berries for Christmas decorations. Nice cool nights, perfect football weather. Busy getting the gardens and yard ready for winter. Almost time to put plants in the greenhouse - it's ready!

properties.description:
weekly report:  So... it was a very dreary week.. lots of clouds, rain and drizzling rain and mist; cooler temps at night; lots of mosquitos now;
eleagnus and golden rod blooming;  hummingbirds down to 2 or 3, likely going to be gone ( if not already ) in a day or so; swimming pool water temps will not recover from last weeks rain and cool temps - so that is closed up early this year; water levels in area rivers remain high;
the tobacco crop - well, they have left the bottom 2/3 of the plants and leaves in the fields - guess it has lost its quality; corn continues to brown - and if the fields get dry enough the farmers might harvest.. but then again, the ears have likely held more moisture too; soy crop continues to thrive - deer and turkeys are enjoying that; more evidence of foxes ( scat/excrement); a couple area beekeepers got "hit" by black bears in the last month; ( they didn't have protection against this )

We found this week that only 2/3 of an inch of rain is sufficient to not only sustain the existing plants in our yard but that it is also enough to germinate fresh grass seed from our fall over-seeding of the yard. The cooler temperatures probably contributed their part to this result. The soil remains moist but is not "boggy". The creek is clear and continues to flow. There are many small (1" or so) fish visible in the creek. I'm not at all sure what kind they are nor why they are appearing now and not in the spring and early summer. The pond was showing some algal blooms for a few days early in the week but these appear to have cleared out. Birds have not been as plentiful this week as they were earlier in the summer. We are seeing an occasional cardinal at the feeder but not much more. The humminng birds have apparently foresaken our yard for now.

I talked to some rafters who said it was slow, but pretty. Rafting companies still get good business on weekends. We turned off our microhydro. Fall color is showing on sourwoods, dogwoods, sumacs, and maples. The tulip poplars are dropping brown & yellow leaves. While the resident hummingbirds left, I seen two travelling hummers on separate days. I'll keep the feeder available for other stragglers. At least one broad-winged hawk is still here, but some migrating hawks have been seen over the Blue Ridge. Our drinking spring quality & quantity is unchanged.

properties.description:
Until the last two days, the last week has been misty, cloudy, and humid. Then a front back cooler, drier weather and sunshine. I did my last canning of tomatoes with late blight taking most of the rest. I have a bowl of tomatoes to eat and some green ones to ripen. I'll soon be removing and destroying the vines. The fall garden--spinach, kale, carrots, chard, broccoli, cabbage and lettuce are growing well. They like the cooler weather (down to the low 50's at night). Hummingbirds left this week and cabbage butterflies have disappeared (good for the brassicas-kale, broccoli, etc.) Fritilleries & swallowtails are still on the flowers. The French Broad River reached a high of 4,000 cfs last week and is down to 1150 cfs today--that's medium low. Paddlers are still coming, but the season is winding down. We grow shiitake mushrooms to sell and all the rain with warm temps speeded up their growth. The last two days have been slower as it dries up and cools down. So rain is good for some plants and not for others. Our drinking spring is unchanged in quality and quantity.

properties.description:
Since my last report on Sept. 2 (following the longest spell of no rain of 8 days all summer), I have recorded 6.11 inches of rain. Lack of rain is now not the problem, but too much judging by what I am seeing and hearing.
Local landscapers have noted increased fungal growth in lawns and fungus is apparent in garden beds, provided ample moisture to grow on the mulch. But better a little too much than not enough. For those with rain sensors, irrigation systems have not been running as much. The community waters no matter what, but that is pulled from the lagoons and ultimately most returns to them. Others without sensors may be seen sprinkling in the rain, looking quite ridiculous. One can debate the nature of the lawns and gardens in our community, but there is no debate about wasteful use of the resources in cases like this.

From Sept 7th thru till the morning of Sept 14th.. we have rec'd 8.82 inches of rain.  The largest portion of this came within 3 hours on Friday night.. nearly 4-1/4".  Needless to say, this caused immediate field, yard, ditch and some road flooding.  It has drained, leaving the earth soggy and sodden.  
Cooler temperatures did not arrive until this morning, so all this precip., accompanied by humidity and heat made for an oppressive week.
Birds:  Bluebird mating pair is still here; hummingbirds have dwindled from over 30 at the feeders down to 5 or so; the young hawks are flying; the cardinals are returning to the feeders more frequently now.
River levels that were just below flood stage are now at or above it - impacting recreational boating-but mostly in a good way; a new 'scale' is showing up on our crepe mytrles locally - in addition to fungus that causes the leaves to yellow and drop prematurely; moths are very evident now, and we are anticipating another fall of webs and damage to trees - in particular the hollies and long leaf pine that last year were inundated with caterpillars.
Gardens are drowned, peppers which normally  produce heavily at this time of year are dwindling.
The news says the local tobacco crop has been adversely effected by all this rain; corn stalks remain un-harvested in the fields; soy seems unaffected.

properties.description:
We've gotten rain all but two days of the last week. With all the moisture & high humidity of the last two weeks, all our tomatoes have gotten late blight. I'm still picking and canning tomatoes, but I see the end in sight as the blight spreads. We turned on the small jet of our microhydro system, so we're generating 2.4 kwh per day--enough to run our household on the average day. Fall flowers are in their glory with goldenrod, joe-pye-weed, and ironweed in full bloom. One of the last wildflowers, closed gentians, is blooming. Female Diana, great-spangled fritillery, and spicebush swallowtail butterflies are common on our flowers. Birds are migrating through, especially visible up on the Blue Ridge. The French Broad has been up to 6500 cfs and down to 850 cfs in the last week. That's the beauty of a free-flowing river. Today the river is running 1440 cfs. Rafting is good. Our spring water is unchanged.

Two additional indicators of drought: jerusalem artichoke plants are stunted, producing small tubers. Wild jewel weed plants on our normally moist hillsides are wilted, stunted. These wild succulents are a good indicator of soil moisture. The soil over the entire area is DRY.  Observing the grazing habits of deer at this time, we see them eating plants that they would normally ignore. They are eating foliage that normally would be ignored if rainfall, soil moisture were at desirable levels.

properties.description:
There was a desperate need for rain but received 1.46" yesterday and last night. all the plants look so much happier. Wednesday there was an article in the local paper about the need for rain especially soybeans as that crop is just beginning to bloom and set pods. Statewide about 57% of the crop is "good". A good yield is predicted for corn with 43% statewide is "good". The spring hay crop yield was a little low so hoping for a bumper fall crop. 50% of the crop in the field is now rated "good" to "excellent". Lake level was incrementally dropping but picked up after rains to the west of us. It should continue to rise after yesterday's rain. Birds are fluttering about but it's still hot and humid. Relief on the way. Activity on the lake is almost non-existent after the holiday folks left. Campground  only has a couple of RVs left. Summer economy boom is over. Now time to weed and plant the fall vegetable garden. while no fire warnings had been issued, the dryness was a concern. Now that is relieved for a while.

properties.description:
The past week began with 4 dry days. Then we had 4 days with a total of nearly an inch of rain. During the dry spell we had temps down to 55°. We're seeing leaves falling--August is early for falling leaves, even for buckeyes. It's been suggested that the cool temperatures may be contributing to what's starting to look like a very early fall. Buckeye, sycamore, sumac, and dogwood leaves are all beginning to change color and fall. The French Broad River is low, but very good rafting. The rafting companies report a good business. We did have to turn off our microhydro this week due to low water in the creek. (We want to let the creek continue to flow for the sake of the critters.) This impacts our electric generation, but it's not unexpected. With lots of tree transpiration, we have to receive a lot of rain to continue generating all summer. The cost of the electricity lost for the rest of the month is about $28. Our  drinking water (spring) is unchanged in quality or quantity.

The saying "it's not the heat it's the humidity" definitely applies now.  When my glasses fog up when I go outside or when I wake up and the windows are fogged up, it's humid outside! Most vegetable gardens have finished producing. Time to get ready to plant a fall garden. The lake level has steadily risen all week, now 409.84'. All the wheat has been cut. Tobacco priming continues. Birds are still molting. Hummers still around- even with two feeders near each other, only one will drink the nectar at a time while chasing others away. A few flowers are blooming but fall mum are full of buds. Another weather lore is the number of fogs in August foretell the number of snows in the winter. So far we have had at least 4 foggy morning - bring on the snow. Campers still utilizing the sites and still activity on the lake when weather permits. Lots of fishermen early this morning. School starts Monday.

wkly rpt. August 10th thru the 16th:
Small amounts of precip. during the week.  Humidity ranged from very humid to cool and dry.
Tree leaves are changing slightly ( crepe myrtle, red maples)  Foliage is noticeably a different hue, and while the trees have had a spurt of growth lately, it is apparent that other foliage is done growing this season, and although not dying off as of yet, just not growing more.
Web worms are starting to show up in the oak and sweet gum trees already.  Grasses are starting to send up shoots and seed out.
River level(s) remain higher than normal due to rain in the general area (drainage from headwater areas etc.)
Birds have slowed their seed feeder feeding / squirrels seem to have ramped up theirs.
Figs have and continue to ripen.
More mosquitos now than there has been so far this summer.
Honeybees continue to lay brood ( which is good ); are not capping the nectar/honey so either they are eating it ( we are not feeding ours ) or it remains too humid. Swarm and supercedure cells are evident in 50% of our bee colonies. We continue to add equipment to give them space and hopefully thwart fall swarms.
Soy is still not blooming / Corn foliage continues to yellow / tobacco bottom leaves are yellowing / crepe myrtles are just about done blooming / magnolias are blooming.

We've seen a week with rain--1.49" over 7 days. With just a little rain every day the garden stays damp. We have been seeing some new fungus diseases on beans & cukes. The extension service expert said that fungus diseases are showing up because their spores thrive in humid conditions and they're not getting washed off by hard rains. We grow organically, so I'm rarely concerned about some discolored leaves, but I like to know what's going on. The garden remains very productive. The coolness has slowed down the growing of our shiitake mushrooms. Late summer wildflowers are blooming on schedule, including goldenrod, ironweed, and joe-pye-weed. Our water supply (the spring) and our microhydro power are unchanged. The French Broad River level has made for good boating. I hear the rafting companies are doing well.

Oh, wonderful rain. And cloudy days, good for an afternoon nap. This weather has cut down on the number of campers at the lake campground. Very few boaters are on the water,good time to do boat maintenance. Fewer customers at the marina. Lake level is slightly up over the past week. If there is heavy rain to the west then the level will quickly rise as the feeder streams are in that direction. This type of weather is a perfect environment for weeds and grass to grow. But this also means the soil will release the weeds so pulling here I come. Temperatures are definitely below normal and there are no objections from this home. Vegetable garden is still not producing as it has in past years. Birds have begun molting, especially obvious with male Cardinals. Hummingbirds are very active as are our regulars - wrens, American Goldfinches, Titmice and chickadees. Still a lack of butterflies and not seeing many bees even though we have bee balm and other plants that usually attract bees. Farm crops are now looking good, hope they bring good prices for the farmers. Good time to catch up on inside activities.

properties.description:
Wow! 6.99 inches of rain measured here; significantly more than the state yearly average for July of 5.1 inches of rain. But South Carolina itself is on the short side this summer; not surprising in view of the wide range of rainfall from one area to the next.
I wish I had this resource available when I was still in the classroom. The idea that weather factors vary as much as they do was sometimes difficult to get students to understand when, as we know, all weather is only measured at the "airport." 30 miles away.
Here I can measure an inch of rain, and the next nearest gauge (about 1 crow mile away) comes up dry. It works in reverse, too. The little dots on our maps show a great deal of information. But that is why our reports are important.
I have noted little impact from too little or too much rain. Ponds appear at normal levels and plant growth is sustained quite happily. River issues sometimes appear as they are a better indicator in that they drain large areas of the state. 
With the forecast containing significant probabilities for rainfall every day for the next week, drought will not likely be a problem for our corner. Tropical Storm Bertha will likely remain out to sea as it swings around to the northeast and it is unlikely that any of its rain bands will affect us; rainfall already forecast should be sufficient.

Summer has been busy down here in North Augusta.  The garden has been full of red ripe tomatoes and other herbs and vegetables.  Garden plants grew nicely in the month of June, then in July due to the hot and dry conditions, now the plants are starting to die and shrivel up. Cherry, grape, & yellow tomato plants are still very productive with tomatoes, others are not doing so well.  Total rainfall for the month of June was 6.54" This was above average. Average rainfall for June is 4.72"  Total rainfall for July was only 2.23" this is below average.  The average rainfall for July is 4.33"  July has been the 1st month since I have started making these reports that I have reported below average rainfall for the month.  July truly was a dry & hot month.  Temperatures never did reach 100 at the airport, but here in North Augusta I saw two days were my thermometer read 100 degrees.  Each of these days were before we had strong cold fronts pass through the region.  These two fronts were strong enough to pass and actually bring a few days with warm temperatures with low humidity.  We made sure to enjoy those few days with outside activities swimming at the pool.  Most of the heavy rain missed my neighborhood throughout the month of July. I know there were others cities in the state that had flooding with very heavy rain.  Clouds rolled in last night and today we finally got some decent rainfall to end the month 1.03" in about an hour this afternoon.  As of now, it looks like August will start off wet.  The traveling rain gage will go to Road Atlanta in Brasselton, Georgia twice in August.

In July, we had a total of 12.07, not counting one day with just a trace.  It rained 16 out of 31 days plus we had a trace on an additional day.  Although I have no records of rainfall in prior years, from my recollection, this is the wettest July I can recall in recent years.  The ground in our community is very saturated.  When we walked today (August 2 after another .60 inches of rain in the overnight hours), I observed a great deal of lying water in the grassy areas alongside the roadway.  Many yards, drainage ditches and undeveloped lots had substantial lying water. One low-lying lot near my home often has standing water in the center of the lot during wet seasons; what was highly unusual is that today  I observed almost the entire lot covered with standing water, including the edges of the lot. When my husband spotted a Chinese tallow sapling (approximately five feet tall) in a neighbor's yard, I decided to gently tug at it to see if I could pull it out.  The tallow easily came out with the root system, which was every bit of 10-12 inches long, moist and intact.  Generally, saplings this tall have to be cut and sprayed, so the fact it came out easily indicates that the soil is saturated at least that deep in the ground. The weather forecast indicates more rain for the next five days, so I don't anticipate drought conditions any time soon.

This report covers the period 7-18/7-28-2014.
A tour through the middle of Perquiman's county easily shows the disparity in rainfall in a 20 square mile area. The mid-section looks almost tropical, with rich, deep green foliage. The corn is over 7 ft. tall with broad leaves and full ears. Cotton, soy beans and peanuts are all growing well and large, ripe melons are being harvested.
A short distance north and the difference is startling, with spindly corn stalks that are barely 4 ft. tall and just nubbins for ears. The soy beans show only about a 50% germination and a pale green color. The cotton is doing well, but some fields of melons are so bad that the farmer has abandoned them.
Two recent rains of 0.96" on the 23rd. and 0.72" on the 25th. may certainly go a long way toward alleviating the mini-drought.
My grass has grown more this past week than in the previous 30 days. I haven't watered my garden in the last 8 days and it is doing well. The birds are no longer gathering at my two bird baths as they were for the entire month of June and early July.
I hope the precipitation pattern is moving back to the inch-a-week norm for this time of year.

Rain usually arrived within an hour, however amounts varied in the area.  Two afternoons the 'Market Area' in Charleston flooded effecting the vendors in this high tourist season.  One afternoon during the dark clouds and thunder, lightening hit a house on my street.  Rain, very heavy, began more than ten minutes after the strike.  The Island's farmers market closed early due to rain.  Vendors and patrons were disappointed.  Rain before a scheduled concert on the island lowered attendance. Area restaurants, stores and concert vendors saw less sales than expected.  There has been no need for additional watering for my garden and potted fruit trees. My backyard fence has had painting delayed for 10 days due to the rain.

During the first 1/2 of July shower/thunderstorm coverage was even more sparse than last period throughout Pickens and Oconee counties.  At my location about 7 mi. wnw of Pickens only 0.12" of rain fell during the first half of July.  This brings the two month total (May 15-July 15) to only 3.04" which was less than 30% of normal (which is circa 10-11") for that period!  This easily ranks as the driest such period in the 12 years I've been keeping records.  In our area most corn is stunted, while grass production for hay has come to a halt.  Premature yellowing of Tulip-poplar (Liriodendron tulipifera)is common while the proverbial "canary in the mine" for moderate to severe drought,wilting leaves of Flowering Dogwood (Cornus florida), is well underway along with branch die-back in some trees.  Soil column is dry in top 1 to 2 feet or more in well drained areas.  Stream flows have slowed a bit during this period.

The week began with dire news - farmers were saying crops were in danger of being a "disaster" if rain did not come soon. But mercifully .83" fell during the middle of the week. The lake level is still slightly below normal. But there are still many boaters enjoying the water. Shrubs and some young trees around my yard were showing signs of distress but have rebounded. The tomatoes have enjoyed the warm nights and are vigorously growing. Blight has been reported on potatoes in the eastern part of the state and on tomatoes in the west. Fortunately it has bypassed this area. Birds are not visiting the feeders as often, the babies are on their own. Annuals are in still blooming beautifully but it's now a lull between early summer bloomers and late summer / fall blooming perennials. A few more butterflies are in the yard, bees are busy pollinating our flowers. Looking forward to the promised cooler temperatures next week.
