(I don't know what type of gauge he uses).   It is not uncommon for our part of the island to get lower amounts than the other side of the island.  (There are times when the other side gets heavy rain and we do not get a drop.)  For this reason, I have not challenged the 7-inch claim.   The golf course ponds remain high, nine days later.  Small amounts of rain since the heavy storm on the 9th have kept things moist.  During the first 13 days of July, we have received 4.68 inches, which is unusual for this time of the year. I'd seen leaves on trees starting to curl up, the birches were dropping yellow leaves on the ground and the pond level was dropping. There are still some yellow leaves on ground around the birch trees but the leaves still on the trees seem to have recovered their former shapes. The creek is flowing and the pond is full to capacity. The ground is muddy in low-lying areas. All the flowers are flourishing today. Yesterday's thunderstorms appear to have halted and reversed any signs of lack of water.

How dry I am! While we did receive almost .40" of rain this week, we need more. Fortunately no damage from the earliest hurricane on record hitting the NC coast, the rain did make it this far inland. A few plants are beginning to show signs of stress - the sprinklers are in high gear and getting ready for very high temperatures this week. The lake level has been steadily dropping but no problem navigating as we had a wonderful cruise midweek. Flowers are still blooming, birds are still singing, tomatoes are blooming. properties.description:
wkly rpt: June 29th thru July 5th: 
The beginning of the week started extremely hot and humid.  No rain - and the plants were showing the stress.  Water left out for birds was well used and refilled frequently.
Corn has two ears per stalk; tobacco plants are starting to bloom; the soy bean ( no -till ) is now up between what were the rows of winter wheat.
Then.. at the end of the week came Hurricane Arthur. This location was originally forecasted to have minimal ( if any ) impact at all.  Of course, the track of the storm came further west and increased in strength. Thank goodness it was a fast mover ( unlike Irene in 2011 ). There was no damage here.  One dove showed up with a broken wing and a broken leg.  Sad to watch the mate trying to stay with it. 
We needed the rain.. but only received 1.6 inches.  Looks like more rain will come at the end of this week. The last two nights being in the upper 50's and low 60's has made the plants recover nicely.
Tomatoes to this point have been blistered... rotting before they ripen.. and nothing evenly.

The recent rainfall has increased the flow (& muddiness) of the French Broad River. The raft companies all seem to be doing well.

Our spring remains normal. We still have one jet on the microhydro system. The impact value is the electricity cost we are losing by not having the system on fully for the month of June. Lawn mowing is normal--needing to be cut about once a week. The garden is growing well (with no added watering). Blueberries are healthy & productive.

Our station as well as most of north-central and westerrn Pickens Co. and much of Oconee Co. had well below normal rainfall in June.  In my station we had only 2.20" which is about 3 inches below normal and the third driest June since 2002 (Only 2010 and 2008 were drier).  For the Year-to-date 6-month total, it also has been the 3rd driest since 2002 (only drought years of 2007 & 2008 were drier).  So definitely the area I described above is well into incipient drought.  Regular irrigation of horticultural and agricultural assets has been a way of life this month as lawns turn brown. But still, conditions are not as bad as they were in 2007, 2008 and 2010 - probably because of frequent cloudy days and near normal (instead of excessively hot) temperatures over the past two months.  If these conditions persist, the stream flows and spring water may be adversely affected.

Soil moisture in mostly shaded areas is not dry, but has some moisture in the first three inches of depth.  In areas that are exposed to sunlight for most of daylight hours and areas where the soil top is bare, the first three inches of soil are mostly dry.  There are currently no standing pools of water on the property.  Some sunflowers have been wilting, just the medium to tall sunflowers.  There are no other signs of distress on plants from heat or water.  Japanese beetles have been eating some of the foliage of the fruit orchard trees, but the damage is not as bad as previous years, probably due to having more traps to collect them this year.  Increasing numbers of Japanese beetles are appearing compared to the previous week.  A wild raccoon had been raiding our barn for cat food; it was trapped and released.  Deer have continued to nibble on vegetable crops--sweet potato foliage has been completely desimated.  An adult red fox has been seen on the property during daylight hours.

Greetings from Madison County, NC
Yesterday we had a lovely Appalachian rain (light & prolonged). A nice .56" in 24 hours. It's been a relatively dry June: only 2.23" through the 26th. Compare that to 14.20" for June last year.   I've been watering the garden weekly (and tiny plants almost daily) to make up for the lack of rain. So the garden is growing well. Many vegetables, such as tomatoes, peppers, & okra, actually do better with less rain. Blueberries are huge and delicious despite info saying the bushes require an inch of rain per week. They are well mulched.
We have on one jet (out of two) turned off on our microhydro turbine. While last year the turbine was on fully all summer, it is typical to have to cut back as soon as the trees are in full transpiration-all leafed out. The microhydro system is fed by a creek and we always leave enough water in the creek for the wildlife.
Our spring--the source of our drinking water--is unaffected by limited rain.

properties.categories: Agriculture,Plants And Wildlife,Water Supply And Quality
properties.description:
I was anticipating reporting on dryer weather, but then 1.82" arrived yesterday, with more forecast every day this week. (The gauge actually read 1.83" but we have a family of blue birds that like resting on the gauge and guarding their turf. Don't need to say more.) In surveying other reoprots, low country patterns continue; one instrument near Ridgeland, SC, fewer than 20 km away, registered only .16" and one less than 5 km. from here registered zero. But it all helps.
We have a large number of man-made lagoons in our community, all connected together but large pipes underground. As a result they share rainfall and are controlled to maintain a given level, so using them to estimate drought status can be tricky. However, for a few weeks, they had all been low. An indication of too little rainfall, but it turned out they had been lowered due to the new construction of additional lagoons in new parts of the development. Yesterday, as the rain was falling in late afternoon, they actually looked to be above their normal level.
We did receive guidance that additional irrigation time would help the grass and plantings due to higher temperatures (several days over 96 this week). Most of us have controls that bypass an irrigation cycle after a rainfall, so we are not watering during or after rainfall. That is apparently not the case in all instances.

properties.description:
Since at least January 2014, precip. in our area has been sporadic, irregular, overall below normal. We are currently several inches below normal precip. levels.  Without regular bouts of precip., changes in "normal" plant growth & hydrologic activity has been noted. NOW, in  late June 2014, the cumulative effect is becoming clear.  Our springs and our creek are dried up as of late June 2014. In a year of "average" precip., we maintain some flow throughout the summer.  Plant growth, both native and planted, has been off & on. Mostly "off". Plants emerge but then seem to freeze in their growth development.   Plants are much smaller and insect pests seem to be taking a greater toll in the absence of precip. to trigger plant growth.  Trying to gauge, to measure this is difficult but after many years of observation, experience, I see us slipping slowly into a drought situation.  For example:  our apples & nut trees usually gradually produce fruits that are slowly growing, increasing in size.  What I am now seeing is trees shedding fruits (drops) and the ends of branches turning brown and shriveling up.   When usually healthy leafed branches die, you might suspect disease or fungus. My judgement is that I am seeing the slow effects of irregular precip. and overall shortage of moisture.  Based on what I see in late June, the late summer, early fall harvests will be reduced.

wkly rpt: June 15th thru June 21st: The precipitation has started coming at the latter part of this week. Much needed.  CROPS: Wheat has been harvested / Corn started a growth spurt, and some have started to tassle-out / however, the leaves were curling inward due to lack of moisture.  This recent precipitation might just be in time to benefit the field corn crops.  The tobacco seems healthy.
Birds were seeking water wherever they could find it; the barn swallows babies have all flown, and the second set of eggs is now being sat upon; the crepe myrtles are just beginning to bloom here, magnolia is slowing down, all foliage has suffered due to lack of moisture, accompanied by high temperatures and winds.  Fox are being seen more often now, as are the rabbits.  Our buckwheat has dried so it was mowed to redistribute the seed in hopes that it might germinate again this year ( rain is necessary for this ). The river levels remain high due to rain inland.
At this time of year, the honeybees have less to forage upon... they are enjoying our vitex, crepe myrtles and what is left of the white clovers. Having recently harvested honey, many beekeepers will feed their bees over the next 6 to 8 weeks as it is also a period of low forage for them.
I would say that at this location, all plants and animals were beginning to stress due to lack of moisture, but that the recent rainfalls and hopes for a bit more will be a great help

Total rainfall for the month of May here in North Augusta was 5.09"  this was +2.44" above average for the month.  Average rainfall for the month of May is 2.65"  Rainfall so far this month for June has been 1.01"  Average rainfall for June is 4.72"  June is usually our wettest month of the year.  So far, Rainfall has been scattered across the CSRA.  I have only measured rainfall 3 days so far this month.  I know that others have reported much more rainfall than what I have measured.  I have been out to the local Strawberry farm every week for the past 7 weeks for fresh picked berries.  I picked strawberries yesterday and I noticed that the soil was very dry out there.  The soil was so dry that there were large cracks that were big enough for me to put my whole finger down into. Last night a Severe Thunderstorm rumbled through the region.  Total rainfall with this storm was 0.66"  Many trees came down in the town of Belvedere just south of here.  In my neighborhood, there was just some small tree limbs that came down.  My highest wind gust during this storm was measured at 35 MPH.  There were some tree limbs that fell from the trees that were dead from the ice storm back in February.  Temperatures have been near steady in the low to mid 90's since June started.  Yesterday, June 10th was the hottest day so far with a high temperature of 95 degrees.  Tomato plants continue to grow taller in the garden.  Green tomatoes are appearing on the plants.  My yellow cherry tomato plant has produced a handful of ripe yellow tomatoes.  I look forward to more tomatoes as the summer continues.  My garden soil is very soggy right now after last night's severe thunderstorm.  This weekend the traveling rain gage goes to Road Atlanta in Brasselton, GA outside of Atlanta near Gainesville, GA.  Forecast looks like the gage may get some use.

Drought Impact Data: 
StartDate: 2014-06-11
EndDate: NA
Is Condition Monitoring Report
Categories:

Incipient drought is now occurring in western Pickens County, SC.  Except for a 3.14" single day rainfall on May 15, only 2.12" of rain has fallen during a 51 day span from April 20 to June 10.  Irrigation has become an increasingly normal activity for both agriculture and (in my case) horticulture.  Year to date rainfall at SC-PC-1 is only 20.71" or about 7 inches below normal. So far this year every month has had below normal rainfall, with the exception of April (5.71") which was only above normal by less than one inch.

Maize growth has been adversely affected accordingly (stunted growth) along Shady Grove Road two miles west of Pickens. Stream flows, however, still appear to remain near normal probably because of abundant ground water from last year's record rainfall.

wkly rpt: May 25th thru May 31st: It has been two weeks (fourteen days) in which the total precipitation has been only 3/100th of an inch. Many days rain was predicted (with a 30-40% chance to no avail.) The winds have been slightly elevated which has added to the surface drying effects.  The temperatures have been high, with only a day or two "below normal for this time of year".  Tomatoes, although flowering did happen slightly, are not setting fruit.  The peppers are doing well, the blueberries are ripening as are the raspberries. Squashes are beginning to flower and set fruit. Peas struggled this year.
BIRDS: The meat eaters are having a difficult time since no rainfall means little ability to forage worms and even insects; we are noticing a strange situation with the barn swallows in that we have two nests ( with babies ) abandoned - the babies died ; and another nest that was built but not used.  The hummingbird population is less this year than the same period last year.  
CROPS: Tobacco is doing all right - manual labor out weeding; the corn is not doing well; the wheat is dried; the buckwheat is still blooming ( but could have used a little more water ) as is the white clovers.
Magnolias are blooming, but leaves appear stressed - especially on the "little gem: variety.
Last fall we had a huge infestation of web worms which first effected the sweet gums, then the hollies, then the long leaf pines ( different worms/catepillars).  So we are seeing the webs now again on the hollies - especially the Nellie R Stevens variety ( not so much on the American, Savannah or Foster varieties.)
We are spending copious amounts of resources irrigating.
Both time and water ( well and county ).
The honeybees have been foraging on the buckwheat and clover as the persimmon trees are done blooming.  We anticipate extracting  honey within 10 days.

( 2 week report )  Rainfall at the beginning of this period was less than anticipated for THIS location, although nearby had significant precip. amounts. Hail also had been furcated but did not occur here.
Newly planted seeds ( buckwheat sunflowers, wildflowers, cantaloupes, zucchini, beans and carrots ) benefited greatly from the rainfall that was distributed over about three days.  The tobacco plants that had been planted also benefited.
Shallow rooted plants began to suffer in the subsequent days which had high temperatures, sun, and high winds.

Red Crimson clover blossomed and the seed pods are now formed.  White Clover flowers are less than normal due to high temperatures.  Wheat fields have reached their max. height and it is apparent that the pods have formed and the plants have begun their gradual decline prior to harvest.
Foster hollies continue to bloom ( end of bloom period )raspberries bloomed and are now forming fruit; strawberries are ripening; asparagus has formed ferns and are seeding out.

It seems that every flowering plant has gone through their cycles very quickly this spring; either temperature swings or high winds have caused the blooms to disappear quickly this year. 
The honeybees made a lot of brood this spring; swarming has been lower than normal; the bees have been consuming all that they have foraged to feed their young so excess honey is a lot lower than normal this season.
Snakes are starting to be seen, where previously, they had been slow to come out of their dormancy.
Birds are plentiful: canary & common house finches; cardinals; chick-a-dees; bluebirds; barn swallows; hummingbirds; mockingbirds; turkey buzzards; hawks; cow birds and more are seen daily
At the end of this period, rain was desperately needed for crops and landscape plants.

wkly rpt: May 18th thru May 24th: We ended the previous week with sufficient rainfall.. but all the remaining forecasts of rain did not occur.  Temperatures have been swinging from very hot some days, to very cool nights later in the week. Plants are just beginning to show signs of stress.  High winds have also added to the drying effects.  
The birds have mostly had their first clutch of hatchlings ... which are not flying as of yet.  Magnolias and Persimmon Trees are blooming, however, the major honey flow is basically over.  There remains some clover blooming, but most else has finished. Wheat fields have begun to yellow without any chemical application from the farmers thus far. Corn fields vary in their appearance.. some look fairly ragged, while others look healthy. Humidity levels have not been oppressive.  Water levels in area rivers remain high due to rainfall inland. There are no fire warnings or restrictions locally at this time.

Total rainfall for the month of April here in North Augusta was 4.23"  Normal rainfall is 2.84"  Soil was very wet and mushy the week of April 21st.  Rainfall ended on Friday May 2nd.  Since May 2nd there has been no measurable rainfall until today May 15th.  Soil became very dry and there were large cracks appearing in the empty rows of soil in the garden.  Rain finally fell again today May 15th.  Total rainfall today was 3.68"  Normal rainfall for the month of May is 2.65"  We got more than average in just one day today.  Soil is back being wet and mushy in the garden.  The garden was started on April 26th.  it was way too cold before this time to even think about planting tomatoes and cucumbers, herbs, and various pepper plants.  Small one inch tomato plants have grown to be knee high now, and the plants are filled with lots of little yellow flowers.  Banana plants finally came back since the weather warmed up.  May 5th-9th we had 5 days straight of 90+ degree high temperatures.  There were 90+ degree temperatures again on the 12th & 13th.  Birds have been very active with the warm temperatures.  I have noticed blue jays, red cardinals, & others very active in the mornings.  Squirrels have been very active as well.  The traveling rain gage went to Savannah, Georgia in April. No rain fell during that visit to Roebling Road raceway.  This weekend the traveling rain gage will visit Carolina Motorsports Park outside of Kershaw,SC.  I do not expect to measure any rainfall during out short visit.

I lost several plants to the strange winter weather and am concerned about some whose stems are green but still have not leafed out. Strange as it may seem we do need rain - we must slow down while driving on the gravel road to our home or a dust storm follows us. Received .09" last night, hoping for more. wkly rpt: April 13 thru April 19: with nearly 3 inches of rain in a 48 hr period towards the end of the week, the ground remains too soggy to till; lower than normal temperatures and high winds have also delayed planting both agricultural and suburban; pollen levels have decreased; last year at this time, we had multiple mating pairs of barn swallows - this year we have only one, and the late week weather seems to have interrupted their nest building; seems overall to be a wet and cold spring - delaying fresh produce to market; as beekeepers - we are seeing the normal spring brood build-up - however, they are consuming the nectar they are bringing in, rather than storing an excess due to the many days that foraging is not possible; in the meantime, the blooms are still coming on plants, although blossoms are getting blown off the plants; hopefully the weather will improve while the "honey-flow" is still on, or it will impact the amount of honey the bees will make this season, and could impact the overall health of the colonies
Fire threat is low as there is standing water on flat surfaces.

Weather has warmed and irrigation systems are running and the garden plot needs watering every other day.  Lagoons are near normal.  Pollen this year has been awful.  Cleaned the lanai and between some rainfall and continuous fall of the pollen, it was like spreading yellow mustard around.  There have been, dry windy days where there has been open burning.  Often notice this and wonder what burning regulations are in place.  On one occasion, it was so offensive, eyes and throat burned and it was necessary to stay indoors. This is a relatively high populated area of southern Beaufort County - 13-14K alone in Sun City Hilton Head.

properties.categories: Agriculture,Business And Industry,Plants And Wildlife,Society And Public Health,Tourism And Recreation
properties.description:
wkly rpt: 4-6-13 thru 4-12-14: Three days of windy, cooler, rainy weather, followed by windy, dry, sunny. Farmers have broken ground, but are still not planting. Fertilizers and herbicides have been applied. Winter Wheat is now tall enough to blow in waves. Egrets have had their young. Pine pollen was very high. Following the rains, it looked like paint floating on the water in the ditches and culverts; everywhere else it coated anything that wasn't moving with a thick layer of yellow dust. Pear and plum trees have finished their blooms and are leafed out, cherries, apples, dogwoods and azaleas just starting to bloom. Asparagus has broken through and is shooting up stalks. The cooler weather crops like lettuce, spinach, and peas - although growing quickly, are suffering a bit from the quick switch to high (80s ) temperatures and wind. Folks are holding off planting their vegetable gardens in earnest due to anticipated cold snap this coming week. Strawberries and Blueberries are starting to yield the tiny beginnings of fruit. Raspberries are just starting to show the first signs of buds. Canary finches have now returned, along with chick-a-dees, blue birds, and our annual nesting geese pair. Turkey hunting season opened, but they are smart and now we haven't been seeing them as often as before. Many local municipalities have had spring festivals which have been a great success because the weather has been so nice for crowds to be out of doors.
Folks have their boats out on the rivers, enjoying especially sailing for the latter part of the week.

Written in March
by William Wordsworth

The cock is crowing,
The stream is flowing,
The small birds twitter,
The lake doth glitter
The green field sleeps in the sun;
The oldest and youngest
Are at work with the strongest;
The cattle are grazing,
Their heads never raising;
There are forty feeding like one!

Like an army defeated
The snow hath retreated,
And now doth fare ill
On the top of the bare hill;
The plowboy is whooping- anon-anon:
There's joy in the mountains;
There's life in the fountains;
Small clouds are sailing,
Blue sky prevailing;
The rain is over and gone!
Below normal precipitation and temps continue to slow down leafing out. Haven't seen a bear yet either!

properties.categories: Agriculture,Business And Industry,Energy,Fire,Plants And Wildlife,Society And Public Health
properties.description:
wkly rpt March 30th thru April 5th: Above normal temperatures and winds, later in the week, have dried the soil to the point that the local farmers are now tilling as the window to plant corn is limited. The ruby throated hummingbirds (males) migration made it to here on April 1st, and the barn swallows arrived the following day (April 2nd ). The garden stores are suddenly overflowing with both plants and customers purchasing them. Folks are mowing their lawns this week, likely for the first time this year.
Just about every tv weather forecast also includes comments about the extremely high pollen count ( 10 out of 12 for trees); many are suffering from allergies. With discretion regarding winds and permitting, there have been quite a few controlled burns locally, and the scent of smoke wafts on the winds, but is not a threat or hindrance to outdoor activities. While it had been possible to neither heat nor cool indoors, the latter part of the week saw record high temperatures so many air conditioners were run for the first time this year.

My total rainfall here in North Augusta, SC was 2.69" for the month of March.  Normal rainfall is 4.18"  this puts us below average with a deficit of just over an inch for the month.  It seems like it rained a lot more than this, during the month since there were many days in a row each week with cloudy days.  I think I counted about 8 days of full sunshine days, and 12 days with observed rainfall.  The highest temperature I recorded was 80 degrees, and the lowest temperature I recorded was 27 degrees.  My highest wind gust was 37mph.  There was a lot of wind with each passing frontal system.  Each wind event brought down more broken and damaged tree limbs left over from the February 12th Ice storm.  I also noticed on the few days that were sunny, the squirrels and birds were very active.  Yellow Pine Pollen is now starting to collect all over everything outside. Total rainfall in the traveling rain gage was 0.83" at Road Atlanta.

properties.description:
There is an interesting phenomenon in this region: in spite of fairly regular rainfall, fire risk can appear rapidly as humidity levels can drop quickly below 30%. (Which does not seem fair in view of the cool weather.) Rain in the area today negates that warning, but it does not take long for the condition to reappear.
Other conditions appear stable as moisture has been provided in regular intervals. Some water problems in some homes are minimal and not likely caused by water level issues.
We are all looking forward to spring.

It's about time.

properties.categories: Agriculture,Society And Public Health,Tourism And Recreation
properties.description:
Total of 2.25 inches ppt in the past seven days.  Ditches are flowing like streams.  Large areas of pounding in yards.  Islands where Big Allison Creek runs into Lake Wylie near Hwy 274 are completely submerged; however properties on the edges of the lake appear to be safe.  The docks and boardwalks at our high school environmental education area are underwater because the spillway is clogged with tree debris washed down from the feeder creek in the heavy rains.  Winds accompanying the rains have dislodged dead limbs, cones, and remaining fall leaf clusters.  Potholes that were repaired after the last round of winter weather are opening up again, and the loose chunks of asphalt are dangerous when hurled by passing cars.  Because the holes are filled with water, drivers can be deceived by their apparent depth.  The local farmers market officially opened for the season yesterday and they have strawberries, spinach, and lettuces for sale.

We have had 1.56 inches of rain in the past nine days, with the heaviest rain today of close to one inch.  One sees large puddles, particularly in low lying areas as the ground struggles to absorb the heavy rain. In addition, drainage ditches are filling up with water.  I have not observed any signs of drought.  Although we, as well as our neighbors, have lost plants and trees, the kill-off was caused by long periods of unusually cold weather, not the lack of water.  We have observed larger numbers of deer on our sea island than we have seen in recent years, which indicates that the wildlife is not experiencing lack of fresh water. Between the cold and the wet, our outdoor activities have been limited since the beginning of the year.

My total rain/sleet & ice melt total for the month of February is 3.92"  Normal rainfall for this area is 4.06", so we ended the month a bit below average in the rainfall department.  We had a big ice/sleet event February 12th.  This particular storm system came in 3 waves of precipitation.  The 1st wave of energy crossed the region on Tuesday February 11th with precipitation falling mainly as rain.  The rain ended, then early Wednesday morning on February 12th we got 1 1/2" of a combination of freezing rain and sleet.  At this point there was more sleet pellets than freezing rain.  The sleet/ice mix ended in the afternoon on Wednesday, then Wednesday night, the 3rd wave of precipitation came through and brought an additional 1/2" of freezing rain.  This brought my total sleet/ice accumulation for this weather event up to 2.0" total. Many medium to large size  Trees tumbled & crashed to the ground under the weight of the ice accumulation.  Power lines fell as well, and here at my house we went 3 days without electricity.  There was no tree damage in my yard, but many of my neighbors yards were covered in downed trees and tree limbs on THursday morning February 13th.  During the 3rd wave it was tough to sleep listening to all the tree limbs crack and crash to the ground.  It got cold inside the house without any heat too…. the inside temperature dropped to 54 degrees on the thermometer.  There was damage to many cars when trees crashed on them and some people had their roofs damaged as trees crashed down on their houses during this time.  As if the ice storm was not bad enough, we then had the earthquake on Friday February 14th.  No damage to report from this.  Just frazzled nerves across the neighborhood.  There was another after shock that was felt on Sunday February 16th.  You can tell that the ice storm damaged all of the trees around here, because when you look up to the top of the trees the trees are either bent or you can see where limbs cracked off.    I honestly think that the damage from this ice storm was worse than any damage that I saw in south Florida from Hurricane Andrew back in 1992.  
My highest temperature recorded this month was last week on Thursday February 20th. the temperature was 81 degrees.  My lowest temperature recorded was 17 degrees and that was earlier in the month around the 1st.  February 15th and 16th was race weekend.  It was our 1st race event of the season.  When we arrived at Barber in Leeds, Alabama I set my traveling gage out knowing it was going to rain and the gage collected 0.51" of rain. 
 Let's hope all the winter weather is done for good for the year for our region.  Nice warm summer weather will be appreciated in the coming months.

My local farmer sent out a e-newsletter Wednesday indicating they had quite a time during the recent storm trying to keep the weight of the snow and ice from collapsing their tunnels. The letter also announced the opening of strawberry season in seven days, which is two weeks later than they had anticipated.  The cold weather delayed the ripening of the berries in the tunnels.

I have a lot to report for the Month of January…….. The month started out very rainy and wet, then the faucet turned off and plants dried up and turned brown as we shivered in the COLD temperatures.  We ended the month with SNOW!  My total rainfall to report for the month is 3.59"  This is actually below average. Average rainfall is 3.91" for the Month.  Heaviest rainfall occurred on Saturday January 10th 1.72" fell during the afternoon with a thunderstorm.  Ironically, I remembered the old wives tale of thunder/lightning in January means snow in 10 days…Well, it was a little more than ten days after I heard that rumble of thunder, and it did snow.  In fact I measured exactly 2 inches.  When all that snow melted down into my gage the total melted snowfall was 0.23"  The snowfall began around 8pm on 1/28 and lasted through the night into 1/29.  the snow was on the ground for about about 2 days before it all melted away.  I did notice the birds were very active in the morning the day before the snowfall in my backyard.  My daughter brought this to my attention.  I think we saw a red cardinal, a few finches, and some blue jays.  Maybe the birds new what was ahead?  Did I mention it was COLD??????? My lowest temperature reading was 15 degrees.  I cannot remember what day that was.  IF I remember correctly, the day we had the snow on the ground 1/29, the high temperature was only 31 degrees at the airport.  This was a new record low max temperature for that date.  Just in case you were wondering when the last time it snowed here, it was in January back in 2011.  I have plenty of pictures from snowfall January 2011 and January 2014.  My daughter had a blast….Me not so much, it was a big inconvenience & TOO COLD for my taste.  Total days of measured precipitation this month with rain & snow was 12 days.  Kinda shocking that we did not meet average precipitation even with 12 days of measured precipitation.  Currently you can see a picture of my backyard pond with the snowfall on the ground as the cover photo on the NWS Facebook site. Very pretty, worth a look.  Finally, my husband planted rye grass back in the fall with hopes of a pretty green lawn throughout the winter……..rye grass is just as dead as can be, it did grow, grass was green, but it just could not survive the frigid cold temperatures in the teens.  Sago plants were green, now they are brown, palmetto palm fronds still are green, but they have a brownish/yellowish tint to them because of the cold temperatures.  Hope this report is useful.

My total rainfall for the month of December here in North Augusta was 6.25"  Normal rainfall for the CSRA for December is 3.39".  The Warmest temperature was a record High temperature on the 1st day of winter 12/21/13 which was 83 degrees.  The previous record high on this date was 79 degrees.  The normal high temperature for this date is 59 degrees.  Out of 31 days in December, there was observed precipitation on 14 days. That is almost half of the days of the month with rainfall!  Right before Christmas there was 3 days of 80+ degree warm weather.  During this time, I noticed that our banana plants started to sprout a new leaf bloom.  I think it actually grew about 3 inches long before it got killed in the Cold weather Jan 3rd.  That morning the low that I measured on my thermometer was 27 degrees.  It was really windy that morning as well.  My highest wind gust was 31mph.  My Total rainfall for the year here in North Augusta was 51.76" Normal rainfall for the year in the CSRA is 43.57"

November was a very dry month, with the rsin that fell one day this past week (1.1 in)more than doubling the total for the month. A number of days showed a trace of precipitation, and many others showed a fair deposit of dew on the ground and structures.
There are no apparent signs of problems due to the lack of rainfall, but they are likely if this pattern continues. Some watering of lawns is taking place, but typically in line with what rain does fall.

The vegetable garden is still green and growing. Soil moisture is good. No external watering has been required for months for established, well-rooted plants.  Only surface dampening of seed beds has been needed.  Despite several freeze warnings in recent weeks, there is no evidence of frost/freeze damage except for ginger tops.

Total rainfall for the month of November here in North Augusta was 1.97"  Coldest temperature was Thanksgiving morning 26 degrees, warmest day was 86 degrees Monday afternoon November 18th.  Normal rainfall is 2.82" which puts us at a deficit of 0.85" for rainfall for the month of November.  Heaviest Rainfall occurred on November 1st and November 26th & 27th.  Rye grass green at the moment due to recent rainfall.  Heaviest frost occurred Thanksgiving morning which killed absolutely everything or anything growing.

Very little rain over the past month has dried out the ground.  During the summer, when we had a great deal of water, there was standing water in low areas in our community (some of which are wetland).  However, over the past month, these areas no longer have standing water.  The ground in these low lying areas are somewhat damp, but conditions are significantly different from the conditions over the wet summer.

With very little rain since mid-September, two consecutive days with rain this week that totaled slightly more than an inch were most welcome. The ground was very dry, so the fact that it came over a two-day period gave the rain the opportunity to soak into the ground with little run off.  People seem to have turned off their irrigation systems as I have not seen sprinklers running as I drive through the neighborhood.

Since reporting last week (9/1/2013 start date), there has been little relief from the dryness.  Rain was recorded at 0.09", 0.08" reported on 1 day.  Wednesday was windy, with very low humidity and fire hazard warnings were in effect.  Friday was cloudy, damp, and when we received 0.08" of rain.  A quick look at the lagoons shows that the levels are another couple of inches down below the grates (5" total).  Drip line and irrigation were run once this week to help plants and grass.  Because of lack of rain, our bird bath has been in greater use by our feathered friends looking for a drink of water.

properties.description:
Things are drying out presently with only 0.48" of precip thus far this month - normal is closer to 2.4". October was also below average (2.64" vs. 4.47" Oct avg); however, for water year ending Sep 2013 monthly totals exceeded averages 10 out of 12 months. This station had 26.86" annual rainfall above average for the year, or 41% above normal.

Rivers and streams are just now getting back to base (median) flows after being elevated all summer. Area reservoirs (Savannah River basin) are at or near full pool.

A member of CoCoRaHS since 2008, located in the lower, coastal area of Beaufort County near Savannah, GA.

Temps have been much cooler this summer and record rain fell from June-August.  For the "calendar" year, we are still 6.11" over normal.  Precipitation, however, has decreased significantly.  Nearly half way through Nov. we are less than 1/2 of the month's rainfall with almost all of it occurring on 1 day.

I live in a very large gated community with a multitude of lagoons, or water retention ponds.  First thing to notice in dry weather is the water level.  Currently the level is at least 3" below the drainage grates.

While lawns have nearly stopped growing, they are not dormant yet and still need occasional irrigation.  Some stress areas are evident.

A small "artificial" garden plot (lots of mulch & raised beds) still needs watering every 2-3 days.

As mentioned in the 11/7 webinar, I too notice a peculiar taste in the water during the rainy season which has now cleared.

Don't know if that's attributed to the summer birds leaving and the winter migratory birds not here yet.

properties.description:
I have been traveling for the past few weeks, so this is an update based on current observations. Drinking water quality has leveled off with only a slight off-taste and odor, as the water company continues to flush the system with Cl instead of chloramines. (They note that the Cl has more immediate impact but does not last as long in the system as the chloramines.) Rainfall has been sparse, with two significant periods of rain in the 1" range around Oct 23 and Nov 2. (Readings were taken for me in my absence by my good neighbor.) Weather has been excellent, if a bit cool at times (in the 60's and low 70's) for outdoor activities. No signs of flooding or agricultural issues.

Minimal rain this past week, but significant dew almost every morning. No change in conditions. I spoke with the  Communications Manager of the Beaufort - Jasper Water & Sewer Authority this week regarding water quality. It was a good conversation; he detailed their efforts to assure us the best water possible under the circumstances. He said that they would do a bacteriology test at our meter to be sure there are no problems. The overall quality of the water has improved: taste is more acceptable and the pungent smell is signicantly reduced. This is what was projected as flood levels in the Savannah river abated. USGS data for the Savannah river near Hardeeville show that depth is returning to near normal conditions.

Today marks only the 2nd day with no rain in SC...or at leat with only one "Trace" report. Local impact of drought non-existent due to persistent rainfall all summer. Attempting to monitor the numerous ponds in my community, although they are interconnected and may be used for irrigation. I will investigate that. At this point, ponds are at normal levels following elevated levels a week ago. Some plant growth--mostly landscaping--suffering from too much water.
